excerpts: We started with the roti and potato curry.
The roti is so good, especially with the comforting curry.
I wish there was more roti for the price
roti and potato curry.author: Vira P.
roti and potato curry.review:
Out of the many Burmese restaurants in the Richmond District, Burmese Kitchen is one of my top two.  It's funny that they were so close to my office, and then they moved to my neighborhood..  I guess I was meant to dine here!

My friend from NYC never had Burmese food, so this place came to mind as Burma Superstar always has a long line, and we were already on the 38.

We started with the roti and potato curry.  The roti is so good, especially with the comforting curry.  I wish there was more roti for the price (plus there was a lot of curry left over), but that bread is pretty filling.

I got the eggs in tamarind sauce, and the coconut rice per recommendation.  It was delicious! You get three hard boiled eggs in a savory, tangy curry, and it goes really well with the coconut rice.  I couldn't finish it, but I wish I did because it did not fare well as leftovers (except for the rice).  So if you order this dish, make sure you eat it there.  I would order this dish again though, because it's $8.50, much cheaper than the $13.50 for two eggs with curry I've had at another restaurant.

The food is quick, and service is friendly.  And I have to give them props for their decor.  The wall is lined with paper plates that are dyed in different, bold colors.  A good diy option for decor on a budget.  The space is small, but it's never crowded, which I like.  I can't stand having the feeling of being rushed to eat dinner.

I read some of the other reviews regarding the tea leaf salad, and I will have to try that next time I'm here.  I'm not an expert on Burmese food, but it seems like that salad is the key indicator for what makes a Burmese restaurant great.

excerpts: *Roti and Potato Curry ($6.50): Vegan, contain gluten
The potato curry had great flavor and was thick and rich, but I found the roti to be way too oily.
The roti was nice and flaky though.
Based on the tea leaf salad, potato curry and garlic noodles, I'd say Burmese Kitchen is just A-OK.
roti and potato curry.author: Elena N.
roti and potato curry.review:
I'd been craving garlic noodles and a tea leaf salad. Decided to try Burmese Kitchen on Saturday, May 7th for lunch. I ordered delivery through Eat24. Placed my order at 1:28pm and it arrived at 2:37pm.

*Roti and Potato Curry ($6.50): Vegan, contain gluten
*B. K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad ($9.95): Vegan, Homestyle with extra fermented tea leaf, fried garlic, sesame seeds, shredded cabbage, assorted peas, peanuts on side
*Garlic Noodles ($9.50): Sei jyet kau swel, Contain gluten, Egg noodles tossed with garlic oil, green onion, chicken

The potato curry had great flavor and was thick and rich, but I found the roti to be way too oily. The roti was nice and flaky though. The tea leaf salad is very dense, so I split the salad throughout four meals. With all the nuts, etc, you will be chewing a lot. It had a subtle heat due to the peppers. The garlic noodles were good, but they all stuck together in a big clump. I had to cut up the noodles and remix them so I could eat them. Good flavor though. I liked the texture of the egg noodles.

I wanted to try more items, but it was just me ordering the delivery, so I refrained from over ordering. Based on the tea leaf salad, potato curry and garlic noodles, I'd say Burmese Kitchen is just A-OK.

excerpts:
We ordered:

Roti and Potato curry
Tea leaf salad
Tamarind spicy fish
Green beans
Pork with pickled mango
(Except the tea leaf salad, very small portion size).
roti and potato curry.author: Foodlover B.
roti and potato curry.review:
Four of us arrived lunch today, a Saturday, and had the place to ourselves.

We ordered:

Roti and Potato curry
Tea leaf salad
Tamarind spicy fish
Green beans
Pork with pickled mango

Everything was very good.  The tab was $54. Portions were generous. (Except the tea leaf salad, very small portion size).

 It's close to a 38 muni.

It's much nicer vs their old place in the tenderloin. It's decorated very pretty and so much cleaner. We had been to their old place 4-5 times but it got too gross for us. I'm glad they moved!

excerpts:
We got:
- tea leaf salad
- samosa soup
- roti and potato curry
- chicken and potato curry
- pork with pickled mango
- lemongrass beef
- spicy fish
- garlic rice stick with chicken
- mixed vegetable curry

roti and potato curry.author: Kris K.
roti and potato curry.review:
Great Burmese spot that's super cheap and easy to get into. Maybe slightly smaller portions than Mandalay or Burma Superstar, but a little cheaper, and just about as good. Comparably good to Burma Love, but less than half the price. A little more out of the way, especially compared to their previous Civic Center location, but well worth the trip. We had no trouble getting a table for 8 at 7pm on a Saturday. 

We got:
- tea leaf salad
- samosa soup
- roti and potato curry
- chicken and potato curry
- pork with pickled mango
- lemongrass beef
- spicy fish
- garlic rice stick with chicken
- mixed vegetable curry
- ladyfingers (okra)
- coconut rice

Everything was pretty solid - the lemongrass beef, spicy fish, and appetizers were all big hits, and vegetable curry well liked too. It came out to less than $18/head, for quite the feast. Great service too, water was refilled pretty frequently, despite it only being one woman running the place. Several among the group had not had Burmese before and were big fans. 

Will happily return and it'll be another alternative to Burma Superstar for less wait, along with Mandalay.

excerpts: The Roti and Potato curry is great as is the tea leaf salad and the curry coconut chicken.
The staff is very kind and friendly and I have enjoyed their food for years.
Started dining with them at their old location and
this one is much nicer...
roti and potato curry.author: Will M.
roti and potato curry.review: The absolutely most authentic Burmese food I have found in SF.  The Roti and Potato curry is great as is the tea leaf salad and the curry coconut chicken.   The staff is very kind and friendly and I have enjoyed their food for years.   Started dining with them at their old location and this one is much nicer...

excerpts: Fried Samosa:  AWFUL.
The ratio of crust to filling is way off.
Too much crust.
BK
fried samosa.author: Max L.
fried samosa.review:
Just awful greasy, overcooked, small portioned food.

The naan: was so greasy you could squeeze it and fat would ooze out.  Also, only 1 naan per order (and no sauces).

Biryani Rice: not awful
Pumpkin Stew:  No curry flavor, just mushed pumpkin.
Fish with Tamarind Sauce:  DRY
Beef lemongrass:  SO dry.  Tasted like it was frozen and reheated or cooked for 5 days.
Roasted Ginger Pork: as above.
Masala Noodles:  Good.
Papaya Salad: meh.
Fried Samosa:  AWFUL.  The ratio of crust to filling is way off.  Too much crust.
BK Tea Leaf Salad:  Good.

ALL the dishes were way, way too small for the price.

All of this was delivered quickly though.

excerpts: We had the Burmese falafel, tiny but full of flavor, and it packs a spicy kick.
burmese falafel.author: Jorge G.
burmese falafel.review:
Never had Burmese Food before so this was a first. Gotta say, it was an awesome tasty treat. 

We had the Burmese falafel, tiny but full of flavor, and it packs a spicy kick. For entrees we ordered the Curry Pork, Beef Masala and Coconut Curry Chicken. Each was different but amazing. Presentation was nice and portions were a great size. There was enough to share throughout the table and still have some leftovers. 

The Burmese Fried Rice was also great. Don't assume it's anything like Chinese or Japanese fried rice, it was lighter and not as salty. Highly recommend this place if you're a local or visiting town. Parking's a bit of a pain, but it's well worth it.

excerpts: Great burmese falafel and veggie curry!
Burmese Kitchen is a much quicker and affordable alternative to Burma Superstar or B Star, earning it 5 stars
burmese falafel.author: Troy D.
burmese falafel.review: Great burmese falafel and veggie curry! Burmese Kitchen is a much quicker and affordable alternative to Burma Superstar or B Star, earning it 5 stars

excerpts: 2) combo fried platter - Burmese style falafel (

lemongrass fragrance really makes this different super crunchy outside) , samosa ( best i ever had, thin crispy outside and not a overpowering flavored filling), golden tofu ( I don't know what I was eating it was damn good, good frying batter and the golden tofu wasn't any tofu I ever had, thought it was some sort of pumpkin)
combo fried platter.author: Myron L.
combo fried platter.review:
Always wanted to try Burmese food and just happened to drive by this place . Needed a place for lunch . So why not !!!

1) signature tea leaf salad - love the peanuts, sesame,split peas, fried edamame and everything in this salad. Taste rich the way it is and refreshing when you squeeze lime to it. Don't let the size fool you. It's filling with all those nuts and beans. Got one Togo because it was so good and was offered to have the nuts separated into another bag so it won't get soggy before eating!

2) combo fried platter - Burmese style falafel (lemongrass fragrance really makes this different super crunchy outside) , samosa ( best i ever had, thin crispy outside and not a overpowering flavored filling), golden tofu ( I don't know what I was eating it was damn good, good frying batter and the golden tofu wasn't any tofu I ever had, thought it was some sort of pumpkin) dish comes with tamarind dipping sauce 

3) rainbow noodle salad - color and refreshing . Order this with dried shrimp and that flavor really made the dish unique. When I ate it. It seemed like nothing special but that taste got me wanting more 

4) coconut noodle soup - coconut curry base soup. Similar to laksa is the best way I can describe it for those who had it (my brother said it remind him of Portuguese style curry that grandma used to make) nice coconut aroma. Comes with some crispy something that gives a bite eating this dish with the curry soup. Not bad but wish the flavor was stronger for my taste . 

5) sour leaf shrimp - was told this dish is something you won't find elsewhere and specially grown to be served here to have a taste of home(burma) . Ignoring the shrimp, this reminds me of a Chinese style dried mustard green . But this dish is made fresh with flavors of bamboo shoot and a bit of salty sweetness. Interesting to try. 

6) Burmese milk tea - light in flavor and 30%sweet. Not bad. But wish I got the fresh coconut instead ! Happy to have tried Burmese style milk tea still. 

Service was really top notch. Friendly, warm and welcoming .  recommending dishes more authentic or special for Burmese food to someone who has never had anything but making sure we didn't over order. Offered to course our dishes so we can savor the flavor and take our time. The tea leaf salad was so good . Had to get it to go and was offered to place the nuts in a separate bag to prevent it being soggy incase it wasn't eaten right away . 

I had a 10%off from yelp app for this place but didn't use it because I was just that satisfied . Don't just take my word . Always fun to try something new and different . You may like it or well...at least you tried it!

excerpts: The samosa soup, combo fried platter, Golden tofu salad, and coconut rice are great.
I've gone twice now and had the same waitress each time, she's very helpful and kind.
The owners are also very kind and friendly.
The wife told me about how they make the golden tofu.
I will be coming here more often.
combo fried platter.author: Dylan J.
combo fried platter.review: Great food, lots of vegan options. Sent the menus of about 5 or 6 Burmese restaurants in SF to my Burmese friend and he says this has the most authentic range of options, and there's a lot of them. The tea leaf salad sounded bad to me but it was great. The samosa soup, combo fried platter, Golden tofu salad, and coconut rice are great. I've gone twice now and had the same waitress each time, she's very helpful and kind. The owners are also very kind and friendly. The wife told me about how they make the golden tofu. I will be coming here more often.

excerpts: The combo fried platter was overly fried and quite crispy, with an unimpressive sauce.
combo fried platter.author: Michelle G.
combo fried platter.review:
The menu shows two different tea leaf salads. The only difference I could see was something about extra tea leaves and one had tomatoes while the other didn't. I ended up asking, and it turns out both have tomatoes, one just has more tea leaves.

While I enjoyed the house tea leaf salad a lot, the two other things we ordered weren't just disappointing, they were gross and thinking of them now, a few days later, makes me feel disgusted. The combo fried platter was overly fried and quite crispy, with an unimpressive sauce. The coconut noodle soup was the worst--it had a weird texture that stuck to my mouth, the coconut milk might have been a bit sour or something, the flavor wasn't great, and the crunchy things (no idea what they were) tasted burnt.

tl;dr: Get the house tea leaf salad and nothing else.

excerpts: Tea Leaf Salad, Combo Fried Platter,  Fish & Sour Leaf Soup, Spicy Fish & Chicken Biryani.
There are so many other things on the menu that are delicious
but these dishes are above and beyond so good!
The soup and spicy fish are definitely spicy but if you can handle the spice - try them!
combo fried platter.author: JoAnn C.
combo fried platter.review: Don't go anywhere else for Burmese food - the food and service here are superb! Several things that you must try...Tea Leaf Salad, Combo Fried Platter,  Fish & Sour Leaf Soup, Spicy Fish & Chicken Biryani. There are so many other things on the menu that are delicious but these dishes are above and beyond so good! The soup and spicy fish are definitely spicy but if you can handle the spice - try them!

excerpts: Samosas Soup:
Karl the Fog visited and this soup was perfect for tonight's weather.
It was hearty, warm, and spiced w/ turmeric.
samosas soup.author: Jay C.
samosas soup.review:
Vegan Factor: 4.5 Stars
Lots of vegan options. And they're clearly marked and called out in the descriptions!

Food: 4 Stars
1. B.K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad: A unique version of the ubiquitous tea leaf salad. a. The tea leaves, traditional in that they weren't diced, were extra fermented--it was more chewy than others, b. less cabbage, c. more nuts! (first time I've seen edamame seeds on this type of salad). The proportions b/w the three was different which made this TLS memorable.

2. Samosas Soup: Karl the Fog visited and this soup was perfect for tonight's weather. It was hearty, warm, and spiced w/ turmeric. The soup also had well-fried falafels (which I rarely see in this soup type) and crunchy cabbage for additional texture.

3. Spicy Lotus Roots: We decided on this since I've never seen it on a Burmese menu. The roots were well flavored. Texturally, I was craving something to counterbalance the crunchiness of the roots. But that's just my Western sensibilities talking! I checked and this is how this dish is usually made. Try this dish if you're looking for something different from the usual, especially since this is the first Burmese restau I've been to that serves this dish in this way.

Repeatability Factor: 4 Stars
Totally. Another win for the Burmese community. And tea leaf salads are my current comfort food.

excerpts: Outside of delivery the meals I ordered was delicious (fish and sour leaf soup, spicy shrimp and Burmese fried rice).
This was my first time eating from here
and I'll definitely be back.
So yummy.
fish and sour leaf soup.author: Kafilat Y.
fish and sour leaf soup.review: Was craving spicy seafood so I ordered from this place through Eat24 and let me tell you, delivery from this place was 5star worthy!! Received my food well ahead of time and it tasted like it just came fresh out of the kitchen to my door since everything was still hot (rare for many places). Outside of delivery the meals I ordered was delicious (fish and sour leaf soup, spicy shrimp and Burmese fried rice). This was my first time eating from here and I'll definitely be back. So yummy.

excerpts: My favorites are the Ginger and Tea Leaf salads, the Fish and Sour Leaf Soup and the Mixed Vegetable Curry, all wonderful comfort foods.
fish and sour leaf soup.author: Lynn S.
fish and sour leaf soup.review:
I Just had another wonderful dinner at Burmese Kitchen. The food is always flavorful, delicious and authentic Burmese. Other Burmese restaurants, like Mandalay and Burma Star, charge much more and their food doesn't can't compare. This is where you go for an authentic treat -- the real deal! All Served in a lovely setting reflecting the charm of Burma (Myanmar), yet simple and cozy. 

My favorites are the Ginger and Tea Leaf salads, the Fish and Sour Leaf Soup and the Mixed Vegetable Curry, all wonderful comfort foods. Top off with delicious Rich Semolina Cake!

Best of all is the personal touch of the lovely owners, Dennis and Leigh. They constantly tend to quality and consistency. A lot of care, attention and love goes into preparation. And they are never too busy to get to know their customers. 

This little gem deserves a lot more attention and a lot more foot traffic. But a place this warm and friendly, which such great food,  won't go unnoticed for long.

excerpts: Other dishes were good as usual especially the always great tea leaf salad
tea leaf salad.author: Mike J.
tea leaf salad.review:
3.5 Service was really off last time I was here.  Was on a date and the server literally rolled her eyes at us when we reminded her she forgot to bring our salad.

Garlic noodles are usually great but tasted like they were out of a package last time.  Other dishes were good as usual especially the always great tea leaf salad

Usually I have a 4-5 star experience here so I'll be back

excerpts: I got the tea leaf salad and the chicken curry from here
and it actually was pretty good, until I got close to finishing the curry and unfortunately found two hairs that are most certainly not mine.
Very, very gross.
tea leaf salad.author: Bayan N.
tea leaf salad.review: I got the tea leaf salad and the chicken curry from here and it actually was pretty good, until I got close to finishing the curry and unfortunately found two hairs that are most certainly not mine. Very, very gross.

excerpts: The flavors in the tea leaf salad still pop, and I haven't ordered a bad salad here yet.
Try the papaya salad, a fine and significantly less nuclear take on the Thai version.
The coconut rice is in perfect balance and fantastic.
Order anything with pumpkin.
We last went with pumpkin curry with shrimp.
I'm curious to try more of their vegetables.
There's enough menu here to justify plenty of repeat visits.
And you certainly won't have trouble finding a table.
Let's keep going again and again until that changes.

If San Francisco has veered sharply away from dirt cheap food, we can still vote with our dollars, and if the Burmese can be at this level, I'll take Burmese on every corner, and maybe eventually more than one per neighborhood outside the Richmond.
tea leaf salad.author: James D.
tea leaf salad.review:
The friendly folks here deserve more traffic than they get. Of course you can always go to that _other_ place down the street--the one with the 3,000 photos and 5,000 reviews and lines to match--but this is a place you can actually eat before going about your day, assuming you're on the team that eats to live and not the one that lives to eat. Although I'll admit the other place ain't bad, so go if you must. Then come here next time!

I actually have fonder memories of this fine eatery when it inhabited the Loiny Loin, on Larkin Street in striking distance from law school and Civic Center BART/MUNI. They had fewer pretensions and lunch sets that would fill you up for effectively no money. Times have changed, and San Francisco as we knew it isn't coming back, which has probably been said by someone somewhere every day in the history of our fine city. I suppose I'm withholding one star in tribute to its former glory.

So it took me 2-3 visits to acclimate myself to the restaurant this became, but I'm happy with it now. The flavors in the tea leaf salad still pop, and I haven't ordered a bad salad here yet. Try the papaya salad, a fine and significantly less nuclear take on the Thai version. The coconut rice is in perfect balance and fantastic. Order anything with pumpkin. We last went with pumpkin curry with shrimp. I'm curious to try more of their vegetables. There's enough menu here to justify plenty of repeat visits. And you certainly won't have trouble finding a table. Let's keep going again and again until that changes. If San Francisco has veered sharply away from dirt cheap food, we can still vote with our dollars, and if the Burmese can be at this level, I'll take Burmese on every corner, and maybe eventually more than one per neighborhood outside the Richmond.

excerpts:
Okra: 3.5 stars

Tea Leaf Salad: 3.5 stars
tea leaf salad.author: Letitia L.
tea leaf salad.review:
Yummy food for a bit less of a hassle than Burma Superstar and the other famous Burmese places. They deliver on Eat24!


---- APPETISERS ----

Roti: 4 stars
Yummy but don't get the $9 one with curry, get the $3 one and dip it into your curry dish.

---- CURRY ----

excerpts: We ordered falafel, tea leaf salad, roti with potato curry, garlic noodle, and lemongrass beef.
I never liked deep fried stuff - but the falafel here changes my mind totally.
Super crusty outside, fresh and tender inside - with their homemade sauce - perfection!
tea leaf salad.author: Fiona K.
tea leaf salad.review:
Recommend every burmese food lovers to come and explore. This is not the first time I come to Burmese Kitchen, but tonight's orders are just too delicious to be true. By the time of ordering, we expected to pack some unfinished dishes to go, but we ended up finishing everything on the table.
We ordered falafel, tea leaf salad, roti with potato curry, garlic noodle, and lemongrass beef. 
I never liked deep fried stuff - but the falafel here changes my mind totally. Super crusty outside, fresh and tender inside - with their homemade sauce - perfection!

excerpts: I ordered the BK Style Signature Vegan Tea Leaf Salad for pick-up.
For $12+ with tax, it was a really small but tasty serving (emphasis on SMALL)!
My only other complaint is that I received a notice that my order was placed, and I actually sat outside waiting to hear when it was ready.
I ended up just walking in
and it had been sitting on the counter for a while.
They're quick--just not quick to update the status.
tea leaf salad.author: Christine L.
tea leaf salad.review: I ordered the BK Style Signature Vegan Tea Leaf Salad for pick-up. For $12+ with tax, it was a really small but tasty serving (emphasis on SMALL)! My only other complaint is that I received a notice that my order was placed, and I actually sat outside waiting to hear when it was ready. I ended up just walking in and it had been sitting on the counter for a while. They're quick--just not quick to update the status.

excerpts: However, the tea leaf salad and lemongrass beef were both very good.
Lemongrass beef wasn't very lemongrassy and was quite greasy, but very tender and tasty.
tea leaf salad.author: Casey P.
tea leaf salad.review:
I've ordered takeout from here twice and it's pretty good although there have been a couple of disappointments:

-Coconut chicken noodle soup was pretty bland, seemed watered down, wouldn't order it again. Burma Love's version is MUCH more flavorful. Pricier too. 
-Coconut rice was good, but not very coconutty-seemed more like some other fat added 

However, the tea leaf salad and lemongrass beef were both very good. Lemongrass beef wasn't very lemongrassy and was quite greasy, but very tender and tasty.

excerpts: I read some of the other reviews regarding the tea leaf salad, and I will have to try that next time I'm here.
I'm not an expert on Burmese food, but it seems like that salad is the key indicator for what makes a Burmese restaurant great.
tea leaf salad.author: Vira P.
tea leaf salad.review:
Out of the many Burmese restaurants in the Richmond District, Burmese Kitchen is one of my top two.  It's funny that they were so close to my office, and then they moved to my neighborhood..  I guess I was meant to dine here!

My friend from NYC never had Burmese food, so this place came to mind as Burma Superstar always has a long line, and we were already on the 38.

We started with the roti and potato curry.  The roti is so good, especially with the comforting curry.  I wish there was more roti for the price (plus there was a lot of curry left over), but that bread is pretty filling.

I got the eggs in tamarind sauce, and the coconut rice per recommendation.  It was delicious! You get three hard boiled eggs in a savory, tangy curry, and it goes really well with the coconut rice.  I couldn't finish it, but I wish I did because it did not fare well as leftovers (except for the rice).  So if you order this dish, make sure you eat it there.  I would order this dish again though, because it's $8.50, much cheaper than the $13.50 for two eggs with curry I've had at another restaurant.

The food is quick, and service is friendly.  And I have to give them props for their decor.  The wall is lined with paper plates that are dyed in different, bold colors.  A good diy option for decor on a budget.  The space is small, but it's never crowded, which I like.  I can't stand having the feeling of being rushed to eat dinner.

I read some of the other reviews regarding the tea leaf salad, and I will have to try that next time I'm here.  I'm not an expert on Burmese food, but it seems like that salad is the key indicator for what makes a Burmese restaurant great.

excerpts: I got the tea leaf salad, vegetable curry, and coconut rice.
The tea leaf salad at Burma Superstar or Burma Love is SIGNIFICANTLY better.
tea leaf salad.author: Kavita P.
tea leaf salad.review:
I ordered this from Postmates based on the reviews and was very disappointed. Not sure if the experience is better in the restaurant. 

I got the tea leaf salad, vegetable curry, and coconut rice. The tea leaf salad at Burma Superstar or Burma Love is SIGNIFICANTLY better. The vegetable curry was pretty tasteless and the coconut rice is, again, much better at Burma Superstar. 

I know it's cheaper than the other well known place, but I'd rather pay more for the higher quality food.

excerpts: They offer a Tea Leaf Salad and an Tea Salad boost type salad with some extras in it, though they don't make a big production out of the salad and mix it up in front of you and instead of your server doing the thing with the lemon, they just give you some slices if lime on the side to  squish yourself.
For the salad flavor here, it really doesn't compare to Burma Superstar.
tea leaf salad.author: Candice G.
tea leaf salad.review:
A decent option for Burma Superstar rejects. 

The prices here are about half the price of Burma Superstar, though the ambience isn't quite there and the portion size just slightly smaller. 

They offer a Tea Leaf Salad and an Tea Salad boost type salad with some extras in it, though they don't make a big production out of the salad and mix it up in front of you and instead of your server doing the thing with the lemon, they just give you some slices if lime on the side to  squish yourself. For the salad flavor here, it really doesn't compare to Burma Superstar. Drier here and more bitter with less depth of flavor than at other places, unfortunately. 

I really liked the milk tea I got, though it seemed like maybe it was just English Breakfast with extra cream in it and the portion could have been better for the price on this one.

My brother got the pork curry and there was so much meat. Lots of bang for your buck portio-wise on this dish. My dad and I split the Spicy Lady Fingers (okra) and got 3 different types of rices for each of our dishes. The Spicy Lady Finger pulled through with actually being spicy, which I always appreciate.

We also got a side of roti that for some reason came as we were finishing our main courses but it was really good. I'd for sure get more orders of roti next time. 

Service was fine. Not outstanding but got the job done and seemed like a real one woman show. The ambience could still use some work but I have to give them credit for the creativity with the paper plate wall art. Pretty impressive.

excerpts: The tea leaf salad sounded bad to me but it was great.
tea leaf salad.author: Dylan J.
tea leaf salad.review: Great food, lots of vegan options. Sent the menus of about 5 or 6 Burmese restaurants in SF to my Burmese friend and he says this has the most authentic range of options, and there's a lot of them. The tea leaf salad sounded bad to me but it was great. The samosa soup, combo fried platter, Golden tofu salad, and coconut rice are great. I've gone twice now and had the same waitress each time, she's very helpful and kind. The owners are also very kind and friendly. The wife told me about how they make the golden tofu. I will be coming here more often.

excerpts: I just ordered a delivery and got the worlds tiniest tea leaf salad.
These are smaller than normal takeout containers and they didn't even bother to fill it up.
What a rip off!
I'm so bummed because I wanted my visiting relatives to try the famous tea leaf salad
but this is barely enough of a side salad for a single person!
tea leaf salad.author: Kim T.
tea leaf salad.review: I just ordered a delivery and got the worlds tiniest tea leaf salad. These are smaller than normal takeout containers and they didn't even bother to fill it up. What a rip off! I'm so bummed because I wanted my visiting relatives to try the famous tea leaf salad but this is barely enough of a side salad for a single person!

excerpts: We got the tea leaf salad to begin with, which had a great mix of garlic, peanut and citrus flavors.
A Burmese staple and must have here for sure.
Then we had the Rainbow Noodles which was a burst of flavors - cilantro with a hint of spice and fresh slices of cucumber and papaya made this dish to die for.
Last but not least we split the pork coconut curry.
tea leaf salad.author: Yoo J.
tea leaf salad.review:
Had dinner here on a Wednesday night and this hidden gem is amazing!! The flavors are strong but balanced and everything we ordered was delicious. 

We got the tea leaf salad to begin with, which had a great mix of garlic, peanut and citrus flavors. A Burmese staple and must have here for sure. Then we had the Rainbow Noodles which was a burst of flavors - cilantro with a hint of spice and fresh slices of cucumber and papaya made this dish to die for. Last but not least we split the pork coconut curry. The meat was tender and the coconut flavor wasn't overpowering (as I find often times is the case). 

Service is great, everyone is so polite and kind. Highly recommend!

excerpts: However, the tea leaf salad and pumpkin stew were decent.
In addition, the service was great as our waiter was very attentive.
tea leaf salad.author: Cheri C.
tea leaf salad.review:
As a fan of Burmese food, I was disappointed that the quality of this food was mediocre. It wasn't anything special. If you've been to Burma Superstar or Burma Love before, I would stick to those places for a better quality Burmese food. 

We ordered the garlic rice stick dish, which was nothing spectacular. It was basically a clump of noodles that stuck together, with not much taste. The quality of the beef lemongrass, ginger chicken & ginger pork all weren't that great. They also didn't stand out as a Burmese type of flavor. 

However, the tea leaf salad and pumpkin stew were decent. In addition, the service was great as our waiter was very attentive.

excerpts: While the tea leaf salad is truly a star, everything we've ever ordered there has been beautiful and delicious!
tea leaf salad.author: Tara R.
tea leaf salad.review: A must when in S.F. While the tea leaf salad is truly a star, everything we've ever ordered there has been beautiful and delicious!

excerpts: We ordered the tea leaf salad, mohinga fish chowder soup, beef lemongrass curry, string beans, and coconut rice.
We enjoyed all of the dishes, especially the tea leaf salad.
I appreciate how the coconut rice doesn't have that artificial coconut flavor.
The monhinga soup was something different- curry soup base, noodles, cracker w/
split peas on top.
tea leaf salad.author: Joanna L.
tea leaf salad.review:
Skip the long lines at Burma and come here. 

We ordered the tea leaf salad, mohinga fish chowder soup, beef lemongrass curry, string beans, and coconut rice. We enjoyed all of the dishes, especially the tea leaf salad. I appreciate how the coconut rice doesn't have that artificial coconut flavor. The monhinga soup was something different- curry soup base, noodles, cracker w/ split peas on top. The string beans didn't have too much oil.

The restaurant decor is nice, yet the bathroom in back is dingy. Friendly service though and reasonable prices. I recommend.

excerpts: Obviously try the tea leaf salad (I prefer the NO Signature tea leaf, they offer two options), and the Burmese samosas and falafel are awesome.
I'm also a huge fan of their biryanis.
tea leaf salad.author: Austin M.
tea leaf salad.review:
Better than Burma Superstar, cheaper than Burma Superstar, and no ridiculous line to wait in. I hesitate to even recommend this place because I'm afraid of everyone discovering it.

Obviously try the tea leaf salad (I prefer the NO Signature tea leaf, they offer two options), and the Burmese samosas and falafel are awesome. I'm also a huge fan of their biryanis.

excerpts: I'd been craving garlic noodles and a tea leaf salad.
Decided to try Burmese Kitchen on Saturday, May 7th for lunch.
I ordered delivery through Eat24.
*B. K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad ($9.95): Vegan, Homestyle with extra fermented tea leaf, fried garlic, sesame seeds, shredded cabbage, assorted peas, peanuts on side
*Garlic Noodles ($9.50):
The tea leaf salad is very dense, so I split the salad throughout four meals.
With all the nuts, etc, you will be chewing a lot.
It had a subtle heat due to the peppers.
The garlic noodles were good, but they all stuck together in a big clump.
I had to cut up the noodles and remix them so I could eat them.
Good flavor though.
Based on the tea leaf salad, potato curry and garlic noodles, I'd say Burmese Kitchen is just A-OK.
tea leaf salad.author: Elena N.
tea leaf salad.review:
I'd been craving garlic noodles and a tea leaf salad. Decided to try Burmese Kitchen on Saturday, May 7th for lunch. I ordered delivery through Eat24. Placed my order at 1:28pm and it arrived at 2:37pm.

*Roti and Potato Curry ($6.50): Vegan, contain gluten
*B. K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad ($9.95): Vegan, Homestyle with extra fermented tea leaf, fried garlic, sesame seeds, shredded cabbage, assorted peas, peanuts on side
*Garlic Noodles ($9.50): Sei jyet kau swel, Contain gluten, Egg noodles tossed with garlic oil, green onion, chicken

The potato curry had great flavor and was thick and rich, but I found the roti to be way too oily. The roti was nice and flaky though. The tea leaf salad is very dense, so I split the salad throughout four meals. With all the nuts, etc, you will be chewing a lot. It had a subtle heat due to the peppers. The garlic noodles were good, but they all stuck together in a big clump. I had to cut up the noodles and remix them so I could eat them. Good flavor though. I liked the texture of the egg noodles.

I wanted to try more items, but it was just me ordering the delivery, so I refrained from over ordering. Based on the tea leaf salad, potato curry and garlic noodles, I'd say Burmese Kitchen is just A-OK.

excerpts: Their iced tea, tea leaf salad, rainbow salad, potato curry - everything consistently tastes amazing.
You won't find a friendlier atmosphere or owner either.
I've eaten here at least once every couple weeks ever since I moved to the area.
Favorite restaurant around here, hands down.
tea leaf salad.author: Tyler B.
tea leaf salad.review: This place is the real deal. Their iced tea, tea leaf salad, rainbow salad, potato curry - everything consistently tastes amazing. You won't find a friendlier atmosphere or owner either. I've eaten here at least once every couple weeks ever since I moved to the area. Favorite restaurant around here, hands down.

excerpts: You could go to Burma Superstar, wait forever, pay a ton, and never get real tea leaves in your tea leaf salad; or you could head to Burmese Kitchen, where there's never a wait and they use real tea leaves they ferment themselves for their salads/dishes.
I highly recommend the springing for the B.K. Tea Leaf Salad and don't pass up on the Coconut R ice (it's got that perfect hint of coconut
tea leaf salad.author: Brandon J.
tea leaf salad.review:
You could go to Burma Superstar, wait forever, pay a ton, and never get real tea leaves in your tea leaf salad; or you could head to Burmese Kitchen, where there's never a wait and they use real tea leaves they ferment themselves for their salads/dishes. 

I highly recommend the springing for the B.K. Tea Leaf Salad and don't pass up on the Coconut R ice (it's got that perfect hint of coconut and it's moist AF). 

I've been twice now and tried a variety of their dishes and they've not yet failed. If you're looking for something a little different, get the Shrimp with Sour Leaf or try the Spicy Lady Fingers (okra). 

The only con on this place, the take-out can be hit or miss.

excerpts: * B. K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad.
It was okay.
It has an interesting combination of nuts, but to me the flavor was a bit mild/dry.
My favorite style of tea leaf salads are more on the juicy/sour side and the tea leaves with more intense flavor.
tea leaf salad.author: Gui K.
tea leaf salad.review:
Ordered:

* B. K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad. It was okay. It has an interesting combination of nuts, but to me the flavor was a bit mild/dry. My favorite style of tea leaf salads are more on the juicy/sour side and the tea leaves with more intense flavor.
* Pumpkin Stew. Simple and straightforward. Tastes good.
* Fish with Tamarind Sauce. My favorite dish of the three. The tamarind add a nice savory flavor to the fish, without being too strong.
* Burmese styled fried rice (side dish). I don't remember having this before. It was flavorful.

Good prices, but portions are on the smaller side.

The place is clean and looks new. It was quite empty during a Saturday during dinner time, which was a bit surprising. Staff is friendly and attentive.

excerpts: My new marker for all Burmese places is whether or not they have a good tea leaf salad and then trying out some of the curries.
Burmese Kitchen gets the job done, but I wouldn't take someone who is familiar with Burmese cuisine here already.
tea leaf salad.author: Arezou A.
tea leaf salad.review:
One of the many Burmese restaurants to choose from in the Richmond.

Pros-

Not as crowded/packed as the others. A lot easier to get a seat here and you can make reservations

Food comes out fairly quickly 

I felt like it was on the cheaper side, but I think all Burmese places are fairly cheap dining options

Cons-

I wasn't as impressed by the food! My new marker for all Burmese places is whether or not they have a good tea leaf salad and then trying out some of the curries. Burmese Kitchen gets the job done, but I wouldn't take someone who is familiar with Burmese cuisine here already. Take someone here who hasn't tried Burmese food before though, and they'll think this place is delicious. 

Service can be slow- there's like two people working a full room. Not their fault, but you'll notice your water to be half empty for most of the time.

Overall, great place to come to if you're feeling Burmese and don't want to bother waiting forever at Burma, B Star or Mandalay.

excerpts: B.K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad (homestyle with extra fermented tea leaf, fried garlic, sesame seeds, shredded cabbage, assorted peas & peanuts, $9.75):
Frankly I'm not sure if the extra $2 is worth it over the regular tea leaf salad; I was just enticed by the name.

It is definitely one of the most flavorful tea leaf salads I've ever had--pungently aromatic tea leaf, blended into multidimensional character with the assorted peas, topped with a flamboyant coating of sesame seeds.
tea leaf salad.author: Edna C.
tea leaf salad.review:
Every time I try a new Burmese place, I find a new favorite... I guess it's an inevitable paradox when Burmese food is so good and each place stands out so distinctively!

(+++) B.K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad (homestyle with extra fermented tea leaf, fried garlic, sesame seeds, shredded cabbage, assorted peas & peanuts, $9.75): Frankly I'm not sure if the extra $2 is worth it over the regular tea leaf salad; I was just enticed by the name. It is definitely one of the most flavorful tea leaf salads I've ever had--pungently aromatic tea leaf, blended into multidimensional character with the assorted peas, topped with a flamboyant coating of sesame seeds. It comes already mixed so it may look as good as other restaurants where all the ingredients are presented in little piles, but the taste is exquisitely exotic.

(++) Ong Noh Kau Swel (coconut chicken soup egg noodle, diced chicken in coconut broth, fried split peas, and hard boil egg, $9.50): An outstandingly balanced coconut soup--just the right amount of coconut without being too creamy. It could have used more chicken, but the soft noodles and overall composition of comforting ingredients essentially make this fancy chicken noodle soup.

(++) Pork Curry (Pork with pureed onion, garlic, mustard seeds & spices, $8.50): The slow-cooked tender pork and housemade blend of curry make this memorable despite its plain name and presentation. I really like how the curry is vegetable based so it's satisfying but light.

Compared to other Burmese places Burmese Kitchen is a little more more hole-in-the-wall, and by hole-in-the-wall, I just mean in size and fame. It's a smaller place and not as frequently discussed as Burma Superstar or Mandalay, but nonetheless a nice restaurant with a relaxing and refined ambiance (though they could do away with the collage of painted paper plates).

excerpts: Tea Leaf Salad.
Beef Marsala and fried rice.
I will be back.
My mouth is in Disneyland right now!
Yummmm
tea leaf salad.author: Cecil V.
tea leaf salad.review: Tried for the first time! The food was so good! It was a Grand Slam! OMG so good. Tea Leaf Salad. Beef Marsala and fried rice. I will be back. My mouth is in Disneyland right now! Yummmm

excerpts:
Favorites are:
Ginger salad
Coconut soup
Chicken curry
Tea leaf salad
tea leaf salad.author: Ross R.
tea leaf salad.review:
One of our favorite restaurants in all of San Francisco.

Seriously. We go here at least once a week and it's the best Burmese we've had after trying all of them. Amazingly delicious food at the most reasonable prices. 

There's no flair and you don't come here for the decor or ambiance, you come for amazingly authentic delicious food. 

Favorites are:
Ginger salad
Coconut soup
Chicken curry
Tea leaf salad 
Roti

Park on clement st, skip the overhyped overpriced restaurants and walk on block here. You won't regret it.

excerpts: The chicken curry noodle soup and the tea leaf salad are also terrific.
tea leaf salad.author: Diana S.
tea leaf salad.review:
I've been a loyal customer here ever since I worked around the corner from their old Tenderloin location. This is one of my top 5 favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I used to eat here multiple times a week, I've sent probably a hundred people here to eat on my recommendation, and every time I have the chance to choose catering venues, I choose Burmese Kitchen.

The best dish here is the Tamarind Fish - no other Burmese restaurant has it, and I've searched for a recipe for years with no luck. I love it with coconut rice. The chicken curry noodle soup and the tea leaf salad are also terrific. 

This place deserves ten times the business it gets, easily. It should have lines out the door!

excerpts:
well.. 

-The "popular" tea leaf salad was lack luster.
tea leaf salad.author: Brad N.
tea leaf salad.review:
Nothing really "wow" worthy.  Don't you hate it when you regret choosing a place after you've left?  well.. 

-The "popular" tea leaf salad was lack luster.  Hardly any discernible flavor profile beyond nuts and the wedge of lime. 
-The "popular" coconut chicken curry was honestly ok, not bad.  But if coconut wasnt in the name, I wouldnt have know it was there.  OH and you get 1 drumstick and 1 thigh.  
-Garlic Egg Noodles:  when you say garlic noodles, you expect a garlic-forward flavor.  Not necessary vampire-killing levels, but something to remind you thats the reason you ordered the dish in the first place.  It was rather more oily than anything else.

Overall super BLEH experience.  Maybe it was an off day, but sadly you only have one chance at a first impression.

excerpts: Tea Leaf Salad:
tea leaf salad.author: Max L.
tea leaf salad.review:
Just awful greasy, overcooked, small portioned food.

The naan: was so greasy you could squeeze it and fat would ooze out.  Also, only 1 naan per order (and no sauces).

Biryani Rice: not awful
Pumpkin Stew:  No curry flavor, just mushed pumpkin.
Fish with Tamarind Sauce:  DRY
Beef lemongrass:  SO dry.  Tasted like it was frozen and reheated or cooked for 5 days.
Roasted Ginger Pork: as above.
Masala Noodles:  Good.
Papaya Salad: meh.
Fried Samosa:  AWFUL.  The ratio of crust to filling is way off.  Too much crust.
BK Tea Leaf Salad:  Good.

ALL the dishes were way, way too small for the price.

All of this was delivered quickly though.

excerpts: Tea Leaf Salad - your standard Tea Leaf salad that's in all Burmese restaurants.
tea leaf salad.author: Henry W.
tea leaf salad.review:
After spending some time near the border of Burma for a couple of months, my standards for Burmese cuisine naturally became unrealistically high - preventing me from enjoying some of the Burmese food here in San Francisco. 

That is, until I discovered Burmese Kitchen.. 

Most of the food here is similar to what I had near the border of Burma - very homey, comfort food with bold, spicy flavors. 

The best thing here is the Tamarind Fish with onion/garlic combined with Coconut Rice. The coconut rice is here is just amazing - it has a strong coconut scent and flavor which pairs well with almost all the dishes here, especially the Tamarind Fish. The Tamarind fish is a white fish fillet covered with a tamarind/onion/garlic puree. It's perfectly sweet, sour, and salty with a little spicy kick to it. 

Close runner ups:
Tamarind Leaf Salad - one of my favorite things to eat and hard to find anywhere - young tamarind leaves, onions, peanuts, and spices. It has that nice crunch and sweet/sourness that is so prevalent in Burmese food.

Tea Leaf Salad - your standard Tea Leaf salad that's in all Burmese restaurants. I find theirs to be less salty than the rest of the field, which is a good thing.

Garlic Chicken - cooked with turmeric, lemongrass, minced garlic, bell pepper, & onion, the chicken is super tender and flavorful. Tastes great along with coconut rice. 

I love how this place has the local family feel rather than the trussed up western fusion feel. Also, prices are reasonable compared to some other more popular Burmese places.

excerpts: Tea leaf salad is great.
Very protein rich even though it is vegetarian.
There were a lot of different type of nuts.
Most unusual is the sprouted beans.
tea leaf salad.author: Victoria E.
tea leaf salad.review:
Hungry after a nap on a Saturday afternoon. Needed food. Burma Superstar is a bit too far to walk and I often try to avoid the cliched Clement Street anyhow. Our sushi place on Arguello is closed for a week (what?!), Cha Cha Cha is a bit far to walk and probably too crowded. In situations like this, Yelp came to the rescue. I've read about this place, it's a respectful walk of 0.5 miles from the nap joint. Decided to take a walk and give this place a swirl. Is it different from Burma Superstar and Mandalay? I wondered.

It has a lot of Indian influence. Whereas Madalay on California and 6th is more Chinese influenced. Try to avoid Burma Superstar whenever I can as I don't like waiting in line. Wiki'ed Burmese cuisine and I understood its food are influenced by both, as they boarder both countries. Tea leaf salad is great. Very protein rich even though it is vegetarian. There were a lot of different type of nuts. Most unusual is the sprouted beans. Pork with pickled mango a bit bizarre but definitely interesting. Plus the pork was super tender. Again, it felt a certain version of Indian. Coconut rice was however very fluffy and more southeast Asian.

Burmese coffee was mellow with a hint of sweetness to it (tell your wait staff to not put too much sugar or condensed milk in it). 

There are a number of other things I'd try off the menu. It's a good way to give your body enough of a jolt to start the evening. 

We took our time to eat and then exited the restaurant as people started to drizzle in. The wind had picked up. You can hear the fog horn from afar. the sun had gone back into the cloud. A very quiet Saturday afternoon in this quiet Inner Richmond neighborhood. It's hard to imagine how many restaurants are within one mile radius from where we were.  I felt happy and content once again. This place serves yummy food. A keeper.

excerpts: We had the tea leaf salad, garlic chicken, and chicken curry.
Everything was excellent and fresh.
The garlic chicken was the winner overall.
tea leaf salad.author: Linsey F.
tea leaf salad.review: We had a great experience here dining on a Sunday evening. Staff are incredibly friendly and helpful. Already going back for another visit. We had the tea leaf salad, garlic chicken, and chicken curry. Everything was excellent and fresh. The garlic chicken was the winner overall.

excerpts: I enjoyed everything we ate, which was the pumpkin stew, potato curry, and tea leaf salad.
I love pumpkin, so that wasn't a hard sell, but fermented tea leaves?
That doesn't sound pleasant at all.
tea leaf salad.author: Lisa S.
tea leaf salad.review:
Having vegan and vegetarian friends is both a curse and a blessing. It's a curse, because I love eating meat, and our meal choices are always limited. It's a blessing, because I sometimes try new foods and places that I wouldn't otherwise attempt.

Case in point, Burmese kitchen. I've never thought to myself, "Hey! I want some Burmese food" or "Hey! I want some vegetarian Burmese food!" This was my friend's suggestion, and even after I agreed, I wasn't sold.

The meal was quite good, though. I enjoyed everything we ate, which was the pumpkin stew, potato curry, and tea leaf salad. I love pumpkin, so that wasn't a hard sell, but fermented tea leaves? That doesn't sound pleasant at all. Luckily, it totally was, and I'd order it again in a heartbeat.

The area outside isn't the greatest, but if you're not too worried about it, this is a nice spot for some food.

excerpts: Signature Tea leaf salad - Better than Bstar or any other Burmese place.
tea leaf salad.author: Christine M.
tea leaf salad.review:
This place is a staple Sunday night takeout joint. Was genuinely heartbroken when I learned this was just a one year pop up! 

The falafel balls -- THESE BALLS! Can't get enough. Everyone who I've forced to try them has raved about them and the sauce is incredible.

Signature Tea leaf salad - Better than Bstar or any other Burmese place. Definitely more dense and flavorful than the other tea leaf salads that have a greater claim to fame in the hood.

Beef Jerky - Tender and spicy AF. Tasted great the next day too.

I've also had a handful of other entrées that are reliably delicious including the lemongrass beef and beef curry.

Order from here. Just do it!

excerpts: We started off with a tea leaf salad, pretty small, and slightly different from others I've tried.
Theirs was mixed with cabbage and had edamame in it.
It was just ok, a little bit salty.
tea leaf salad.author: Linz C.
tea leaf salad.review:
I drove by this place the other day was like whaaaaat another Burmese restaurant? I must try. My parents and I came here for a late lunch and the restaurant was fairly empty. Service was great, the owner was there to chat with us and give us recommendations, very nice. 

We started off with a tea leaf salad, pretty small, and slightly different from others I've tried. Theirs was mixed with cabbage and had edamame in it. It was just ok, a little bit salty. I thought there was too much tea leaf and nuts, and not enough cabbage. 

Next we had the Moh hinga fish chowder which is my favorite Burmese dish and I enjoyed theirs very much. It had a little hint of spicyness to it and I love the crunchy lentils. 

The pumpkin pork dish was my favorite! The pork was very tender and moist and the kabocha was delicious! I could eat it everyday. The lemongrass beef however was very dry and I didn't expect it to be so saucy but it was almost like a curry dish. 

For dessert we had the semolina cake which sounded really weird but surprisingly we enjoyed it. It tastes sweet/coconut-y and just dissolves in your mouth. 

Will be back to try more of their menu!

excerpts: Omg the Tea Leaf Salad is so authentic, better than Burma Superstar.
If you want authentic cuisine like the Prawn Sour Leaf dish (sauteed greens, Prawns, carrots, and some other spices) with a nice subtle sour tang check this place out!
tea leaf salad.author: Sarah F.
tea leaf salad.review: Omg the Tea Leaf Salad is so authentic, better than Burma Superstar.  If you want authentic cuisine like the Prawn Sour Leaf dish (sauteed greens, Prawns, carrots, and some other spices) with a nice subtle sour tang check this place out!

excerpts: Tea leaf salad - Realllly yummy salad.
It's slightly different from B-Star and Burma Superstar, but I actually like it just as much.
tea leaf salad.author: Jennifer S.
tea leaf salad.review:
SPICY FISHHHHH!!

B and I came here after watching the episode of Anthony Bourdain go to Myanmar and we were no disappointed at all.

We ordered:
Milk Tea - super refreshing, but keep in mind that this is NOT BOBA Milk Tea! I liked it, B thought it was a little watered down.

Spicy Fish - Recommended by the lady who helped us and by far the BEST dish we had that night. It's not super spicy, but has a little bit of heat. Really tender filets of fish and get it with coconut rice!!

Tea leaf salad - Realllly yummy salad. It's slightly different from B-Star and Burma Superstar, but I actually like it just as much. B said it was too salty and would've been better over rice..haha

Coconut noodles - I totally forgot what these were called on the menu, but its this noodle in a yellow coconut curry sauce. It smells WONDERFUL, however its not as flavorful as it smells. That being said, it was still really good and the leftovers we had great heated up again in the microwave!

Overall, LOVEEEED this cute little restaurant. Service was fast and super friendly. Definitely recommend it!

excerpts: I tried the Tea Leaf salad
, it was really good.
It tasted fresh and it was full of flavor.
It was a savory salad that had a slightly bitter flavor.
It was refreshing.
tea leaf salad.author: Hiroshi K.
tea leaf salad.review: This is a nice small Burmese restaurant.  It is clean.  The staff is very friendly.  The food is very good. I tried the Tea Leaf salad, it was really good.  It tasted fresh and it was full of flavor. It was a savory salad that had a slightly bitter flavor.  It was refreshing. I also tried the fish chowder. It was also good. It was flavorful and had a nice crunchy texture to it.  I also like the fried appetizer combination and their semolina dessert.  I also visited this place at it's old location on Larkin Street.  Their food is still very good.

excerpts:
Tea leaf salad: crunchy goodness - def try
Coconut tapioca: warm & perfectly sweet

Skip the long lines and overrated-ness of Burma star
tea leaf salad.author: Sarah G.
tea leaf salad.review:
Get ready for a tastebuds adventure! Second time round here and I'll be back plenty more. Food is so delicious, everything I've tried was full of flavor and satisfying. Awesome service and great value.

Roti: clouds of heaven
Chicken coconut curry noodle soup: absolute fave
Tea leaf salad: crunchy goodness - def try
Coconut tapioca: warm & perfectly sweet

Skip the long lines and overrated-ness of Burma star

Everything tastes better than skinny feels

excerpts: BK style signature tea leaf salad - comparable to Burma Superstar, but without the crunchy romaine lettuce.

I like the Burma Superstar one better but this one is still good =)
--
Samusa soup (
oh man, it comes with their version of a falafel too.

SO GOOD)
--
Coconut rice (just a side, but so simple and so good)
tea leaf salad.author: Emily C.
tea leaf salad.review:
Great alternate Burmese option when Burma Superstar or Mandalay is just too busy and B Star doesn't hit the spot. Portion, price, quality all comparable =) and service is much faster than the aforementioned places since it is smaller/less busy.

Got quite a few dishes to share between 5 of us and here were my standouts (did not dislike anything!)

-- BK style signature tea leaf salad - comparable to Burma Superstar, but without the crunchy romaine lettuce. I like the Burma Superstar one better but this one is still good =)
-- Samusa soup (oh man, it comes with their version of a falafel too. SO GOOD)
-- Coconut rice (just a side, but so simple and so good)

excerpts: The tea leaf salad, pumpkin curry, coconut noodle soup and spicy fish are all delicious.
tea leaf salad.author: Melissa S.
tea leaf salad.review:
Love this spot! Cozy, family run restaurant that is delicious, speedy and doesn't break the bank.

Has been a favorite of mine for years. The tea leaf salad, pumpkin curry, coconut noodle soup and spicy fish are all delicious.

excerpts:
tea leaf salad was really good but a little on the small side
rice noodle salad was really good, kind of peanut-y.
yum.
coconut curry chicken by far the best.
i could've eaten it for days with the coconut rice.
prawn with pumpkin curry (really butternut squash, not pumpkin) also really good

Our waitress was super sweet and the decor is really cute and cozy.
tea leaf salad.author: Katie C.
tea leaf salad.review: We just stopped in for appetizers and got the Tea leaf salad and potato curry with roti and they were both so delicious, the salad was a bit small but very flavorful. Our waitress was super sweet and the decor is really cute and cozy.

excerpts:
*Recommendations**

B.K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad (v)
Homestyle with extra fermented tea leaf, fried garlic, sesame seeds, shredded cabbage, assorted peas & peanuts

Sautéed Spicy Lady Finger (v,s)
Stir-fried okra w/ onion & Jalapeno

Chicken Coconut Curry
Bone in chicken leg in coconut milk w/ onion curry
tea leaf salad.author: Jon R.
tea leaf salad.review:
This was my first time eating Burmese cuisine and I'm in love!

If you've never eaten Burmese food, it's like a mix between Indian and Thai. 

The restaurant itself is very cozy, the staff are incredibly friendly, helpful, and very knowledgable, so if at any time you have a question/concern ask your server and they will help you choose something delicious.

**Recommendations**

B.K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad (v)
Homestyle with extra fermented tea leaf, fried garlic, sesame seeds, shredded cabbage, assorted peas & peanuts

Sautéed Spicy Lady Finger (v,s)
Stir-fried okra w/ onion & Jalapeno

Chicken Coconut Curry
Bone in chicken leg in coconut milk w/ onion curry

Sei Jyet Kau Swel Garlic Noodles (g)
Angel hair rice noodle or egg noodles tossed w/ garlic oil, green onion, choice of vegetarian, chicken, or pork

I understand there's another super popular Burmese restaurant just a block away but the wait is always insane and they don't take reservations. This place does. 

Enjoy!

excerpts: B.K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad:
A unique version of the ubiquitous tea leaf salad.
a.
The tea leaves, traditional in that they weren't diced, were extra fermented--it was more chewy than others,
b. less cabbage,
c. more nuts!
(first time I've seen edamame seeds on this type of salad).
tea leaf salad.author: Jay C.
tea leaf salad.review:
Vegan Factor: 4.5 Stars
Lots of vegan options. And they're clearly marked and called out in the descriptions!

Food: 4 Stars
1. B.K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad: A unique version of the ubiquitous tea leaf salad. a. The tea leaves, traditional in that they weren't diced, were extra fermented--it was more chewy than others, b. less cabbage, c. more nuts! (first time I've seen edamame seeds on this type of salad). The proportions b/w the three was different which made this TLS memorable.

2. Samosas Soup: Karl the Fog visited and this soup was perfect for tonight's weather. It was hearty, warm, and spiced w/ turmeric. The soup also had well-fried falafels (which I rarely see in this soup type) and crunchy cabbage for additional texture.

3. Spicy Lotus Roots: We decided on this since I've never seen it on a Burmese menu. The roots were well flavored. Texturally, I was craving something to counterbalance the crunchiness of the roots. But that's just my Western sensibilities talking! I checked and this is how this dish is usually made. Try this dish if you're looking for something different from the usual, especially since this is the first Burmese restau I've been to that serves this dish in this way.

Repeatability Factor: 4 Stars
Totally. Another win for the Burmese community. And tea leaf salads are my current comfort food.

excerpts: Our first time here, and we ordered: BK Signature Tea Leaf salad, Samosa soup, and Spicy lotus root.
Tea leaf salad - different than most tea leaf salads i've had.
One criticism is that the tea leaves did not have enough oil and was overpowered and dominated by the seeds and nuts.
It was a different take on
tea leaf salad which we appreciated;
tea leaf salad.author: Will H.
tea leaf salad.review:
Our first time here, and we ordered: BK Signature Tea Leaf salad, Samosa soup, and Spicy lotus root.

Tea leaf salad - different than most tea leaf salads i've had. One criticism is that the tea leaves did not have enough oil and was overpowered and dominated by the seeds and nuts. It was a different take on tea leaf salad which we appreciated; the roasted seeds and nuts (including edamame, yellow peas, peanuts) all tasted good and were crispy which we enjoyed, but again it was perhaps too much, where you could not taste the tea leaves as much.

Samosa soup - first time to have samosa soup, which had pieces of falafel and samosas in there, along with potatoes, cabbage, yellow peas. It was an enjoyable soup with decently balanced flavor. I could have done without the cabbage though; I generally love cabbage, but it didn't add anything to this particular dish, though I'm not sure if it's traditionally made with cabbage or not.

Spicy lotus root - also a different dish. The lotus root retained the soy sauce flavor well, which is impressive considering how hard it is to retain flavor with the lotus root. Caution, this was a really spicy dish. I like spicy food, and had a hard time with how spicy it was. 

Several white and red wine selections at a nice price of $6 per glass. There were a lot of vegan and vegetarian options.

A solid 3.5-4 for me, and would likely repeat to try some other dishes.

excerpts: Loved their signature tea leaf salad and the curry coconut chicken.
tea leaf salad.author: Megan M.
tea leaf salad.review:
My new Burmese life hack. I've spent hours waiting for a spot at Burma Superstar when Burmese Kitchen's food is just as great. 

The staff was incredibly friendly and accommodating. Food was awesome. Loved their signature tea leaf salad and the curry coconut chicken. Lime juice was also great. 

Can't wait to go back!

excerpts: We ordered Samosa soup, vegetable stew, tamarind fish and the signature tea leaf salad.
Rather than being a visual spectacle, it was a much more unique, authentic salad.
The owner told us it was home style - with more tea leaf.
The split peas were fantastic, and throughout the courses it was clear that every dish was only comprised of freshly prepared ingredients.
The tamarind fish is the best fish I've had.
Atmosphere was cozy and the owners were great.
tea leaf salad.author: Sylvia K.
tea leaf salad.review: Loved it! I always enjoy Burmese food, but this was the best! It was truly authentic and home cooked. We ordered Samosa soup, vegetable stew, tamarind fish and the signature tea leaf salad. Rather than being a visual spectacle, it was a much more unique, authentic salad. The owner told us it was home style - with more tea leaf. The split peas were fantastic, and throughout the courses it was clear that every dish was only comprised of freshly prepared ingredients. The tamarind fish is the best fish I've had. Atmosphere was cozy and the owners were great.

excerpts: As for the food, we ordered the tea leaf salad, a roti with yellow potato curry, the mohinga, and garlic noodles with chicken.

The tea leaf salad was mostly nuts and lentils, and while I liked the crunch of it, I could tell that it wasn't freshly made because it came pre-mixed, versus the presentation I much prefer where they have small piles of each ingredient that they mix in front of you or let you mix yourself.
tea leaf salad.author: Leslie H.
tea leaf salad.review:
We stopped by Burmese Kitchen on Saturday night around 7:30 after being told that the wait at Burma Superstar would be about 2 hours. I kind of wish I had waited, but then I wouldn't have eaten until 9:30... Burmese Kitchen is small, but bustling. It looked like a lot of other people had the same idea of avoiding the wait and getting their food NOW. 

The restaurant itself is pretty small, with a signup sheet attached to the door and two extra chairs just inside, but no real designated waiting area. We waited about 10 minutes to be seated, when the first wave of diners seemed to all finish up at the same time. Their tables are all a bunch of two-tops that they can move as needed to accommodate larger parties. Unfortunately, the corner table we were given was really close to the other two-top. So close that when the hostess came by to take our orders, she had to wedge herself between the two tables. Also, when she was taking orders for the table next to us, she definitely kept hitting me in the shoulder. I think that they could make it a much better dining experience if they removed one of the two-tops from that row. 

As for the food, we ordered the tea leaf salad, a roti with yellow potato curry, the mohinga, and garlic noodles with chicken. None of it was really that good.

The tea leaf salad was mostly nuts and lentils, and while I liked the crunch of it, I could tell that it wasn't freshly made because it came pre-mixed, versus the presentation I much prefer where they have small piles of each ingredient that they mix in front of you or let you mix yourself. It tasted pretty good, but I wouldn't really call it a salad given the lack of vegetables and leafy greens. 

The roti and curry were good, but disappointing in the disproportionate amount of roti to curry: only one roti, though you can order an additional roti for $4. For the small size, I didn't think it was worth it. The curry was underseasoned, even if the potatoes were cooked through, they had no taste, no spice, no flavor. 

The mohinga was okay, but also rather bland. The noodles were beyond overcooked to the point of dissolving in my mouth at each bite. I couldn't really taste any of the fish, maybe it dissolved as well? I did like the crispy lentil cakes, which added the only texture found in the soup. 

My garlic noodles were a HUGE disappointment, so bland and fishy tasting, even though I added chicken. The chicken was old and chewy and had an off flavor, and it didn't mix well with the noodles. The noodles themselves were like thin-cut egg noodles that clumped together and had absolutely no flavor. The only texture came from the fried garlic that garnished the dish, but quickly fell off. I would never recommend ordering this to anyone, especially not at $10 a pop. 

I would say that we made the wrong choice in coming to Burmese Kitchen instead of waiting for Burma Superstar. $42 including tax and tip, and so not worth it. The touted friendly service never made an appearance during our visit, but maybe it's because they were super understaffed and trying to rush diners in and out as quickly as possible.

excerpts: However, I really enjoyed their fermented tea leaf salad and the saffron rice.
tea leaf salad.author: P H.
tea leaf salad.review: I gave it 3 stars instead of 4 because the pork we ordered was chewy and imo poorly flavored and looked way to grey for me to enjoy. However, I really enjoyed their fermented tea leaf salad and the saffron rice.

excerpts: Roasted ginger pork, chicken potato curry, and the tea leaf salad are some real good eats.
Husband and wife run the place, and they're both very personable.
They check on each customer to make sure they have a good meal.
I particularly like the thick, professional looking menus.
tea leaf salad.author: Henry T.
tea leaf salad.review: Good eats. We ordered a lot of food. My new obsession may now be coconut rice. Wow! I could inhale bowls of that stuff. Roasted ginger pork, chicken potato curry, and the tea leaf salad are some real good eats. Husband and wife run the place, and they're both very personable. They check on each customer to make sure they have a good meal. I particularly like the thick, professional looking menus.

excerpts: Favorites are tea leaf salad, pork with pickled mango and coconut curry chicken noodle soup.
Texture and flavors are spot on!
tea leaf salad.author: Jessica S.
tea leaf salad.review:
Unassuming restaurant but delicious Burmese food and friendly service. I've tried all the Burmese restaurants in SF and this is the best and most authentic (my Dad is from Burma). Skip the lines at Burma Superstar or the attitude of Mandalay. Just eat at Burmese Kitchen!

Favorites are tea leaf salad, pork with pickled mango and coconut curry chicken noodle soup. Texture and flavors are spot on!

excerpts:
We ordered:

Roti and Potato curry
Tea leaf salad
Tamarind spicy fish
Green beans
Pork with pickled mango
(Except the tea leaf salad, very small portion size).
tea leaf salad.author: Foodlover B.
tea leaf salad.review:
Four of us arrived lunch today, a Saturday, and had the place to ourselves.

We ordered:

Roti and Potato curry
Tea leaf salad
Tamarind spicy fish
Green beans
Pork with pickled mango

Everything was very good.  The tab was $54. Portions were generous. (Except the tea leaf salad, very small portion size).

 It's close to a 38 muni.

It's much nicer vs their old place in the tenderloin. It's decorated very pretty and so much cleaner. We had been to their old place 4-5 times but it got too gross for us. I'm glad they moved!

excerpts: The standouts: the tea leaf salad (the best some of us have ever had), falafel, pork with sauerkraut (I know!), and fish noodle chowder.
tea leaf salad.author: Art C.
tea leaf salad.review:
We thought we'd try this Burmese eatery after visiting them in their previous location in the 'loin a couple of times and thoroughly enjoying their food. Spoiler alert: we thoroughly enjoyed their food at their new location as well.

Actually I quite like their new digs. The restaurant seems brighter and there's a nice ambiance to the place. Other people mentioned "high" prices but I found their prices to be pretty reasonable. We came here with six people and spent less than $200 including tip and $20 corkage fee for two bottles of wine ($10/bottle). Also they do a brisk take-out business so definitely not too pricey.

Anyways, like I said, the food was quite good. There were a couple of misses, but their menu is extensive so that's to be expected. I think all-in-all their food stacks up nicely to both Burma Superstar and Mandalay. The standouts: the tea leaf salad (the best some of us have ever had), falafel, pork with sauerkraut (I know!), and fish noodle chowder.

Downside: Service was actually a bit spotty for us. It was friendly but they forgot some things and we had to constantly fight for their attention when we needed something. But the food was definitely the standout. We'll be back.

excerpts: My friends and I were very sad for this place moving from the Civic Center area, but happy that we still get to have their tea leaf salad!
Speaking of Tea Leaf Salad
- it was good, as we remembered it.
I have had tea lead salad from various Burmese restaurants, but I like theirs the best because it is crunchier than others (they must have more nuts and seeds).
tea leaf salad.author: Yuri T.
tea leaf salad.review:
This is the first time we made it to the new location (on 2/21).  My friends and I were very sad for this place moving from the Civic Center area, but happy that we still get to have their tea leaf salad! :)

Speaking of Tea Leaf Salad - it was good, as we remembered it.  I have had tea lead salad from various Burmese restaurants, but I like theirs the best because it is crunchier than others (they must have more nuts and seeds).  They also have slices of serrano peppers on the side, if you wanted it a bit more spicy.

My other favorite here is Pork and Pumpkin.  You may think it's weird to have pumpkin in a savory dish, but it is truly yummy with pork.  Theirs is really saucey, so try it.  It has never failed me.

Every time we go to this place, we always explore different dish as the other entree dish.  This time, we tried Beef Dal.  I am not much of beans/peas person, and it was OK.  For my taste, it was a bit too much bumpy texture (it has mushed split peas, as well as chana dal, which is another type of peas), but my bf who really likes chana dal liked it.

Overall, a pretty great experience!  However, I still wish it's not that far away in SF...

tea leaf salad.author: Kris K.
tea leaf salad.review:
Great Burmese spot that's super cheap and easy to get into. Maybe slightly smaller portions than Mandalay or Burma Superstar, but a little cheaper, and just about as good. Comparably good to Burma Love, but less than half the price. A little more out of the way, especially compared to their previous Civic Center location, but well worth the trip. We had no trouble getting a table for 8 at 7pm on a Saturday. 

We got:
- tea leaf salad
- samosa soup
- roti and potato curry
- chicken and potato curry
- pork with pickled mango
- lemongrass beef
- spicy fish
- garlic rice stick with chicken
- mixed vegetable curry
- ladyfingers (okra)
- coconut rice

Everything was pretty solid - the lemongrass beef, spicy fish, and appetizers were all big hits, and vegetable curry well liked too. It came out to less than $18/head, for quite the feast. Great service too, water was refilled pretty frequently, despite it only being one woman running the place. Several among the group had not had Burmese before and were big fans. 

Will happily return and it'll be another alternative to Burma Superstar for less wait, along with Mandalay.

excerpts: Started out with the tea leaf salad, it was tasty but too much chewing for my tastes.
The dish contains a lot of assorted peas and peanuts, hence the chewing.
tea leaf salad.author: Alicia A.
tea leaf salad.review: Was attracted by the fancy flashing lights next door for the spicy hot pot restaurant. Looked at the menu and wasn't feeling it. This was right next door, as we looked at the menu, the waiter gave us a take out menu to look at. We decided to give them a try as many of their dishes were gluten free and the hospitality of the waiter. There was only 1 other table besides us. Quaint and small eatery that produces some tasty and spicy dishes.  Started out with the tea leaf salad, it was tasty but too much chewing for my tastes. The dish contains a lot of assorted peas and peanuts, hence the chewing. We also tried the rainbow salad, it was different from other places. Not bad but it was wetter than I remembered. It was delicious though. We ordered the garlic chicken and the pork chana del for our entrees. The garlic chicken had a lot of flavor and a nice little kick to it. Chunks of tender breast meat with our cloves of garlic and lemon grass infused throughout the dish. Pairs well with rice. The pork chana del was very saucy and had a lot of yellow split peas and that dish goes well with rice also. Even though the dishes looks small when it comes out, you will be stuffed! We had leftovers for the next day.  It was such a pleasant surprise for this unassuming restaurant on busy Geary St. Try it! at least, no long lines for Burma Star.

excerpts:
each
- Signature Tea Leaf Salad was awesome
- Service was prompt and they paid attention to us
- Burmese milk coffee was so tasty and hit the spot on a cold night with a long drive ahead.
tea leaf salad.author: Smita D.
tea leaf salad.review:
What a great find. 
- Cons: Parking may be tough, but if you are patient, you can find it. It is MUCH better than trying to park downtown. If you are willing to walk a block, parking is easy. 
- Small, but we made a reservation and surprisingly it was not packed. 

Pros: 
- Vegetarian friendly (although I must say the chicken masala noodles and spicy pork were awesome!)
- Great flavors and textures
- VERY reasonable prices-- all dishes less than $10. We had 6 adults eat well for about $100, and had plenty of leftovers.
- The rice sides (coconut, biryani, Burmese fried) were tasty and a great buy for the volume at 2.50 each
- Signature Tea Leaf Salad was awesome
- Service was prompt and they paid attention to us
- Burmese milk coffee was so tasty and hit the spot on a cold night with a long drive ahead.

Overall a great find and I will be back when I am in the area.

excerpts: Tea leaf salad very delicious.
tea leaf salad.author: Marlui A.
tea leaf salad.review:
This place is new in the area. Server are very attentive, tea are brought and making sure we were doing good. Place is clean.

Food is very tasty, spices and flavor are just perfect. The curry fish was so good with coconut rice. Tea leaf salad very delicious. 

Good competitive with Mandalay down the block.  

New Burmese place for me, easy parking. Come early best advice.

excerpts:
We had:

- Tea leaf salad - pretty good.
tea leaf salad.author: Shendi X.
tea leaf salad.review:
Solid - definitely would like to come back a few times to try more! We had:

- Tea leaf salad - pretty good. I prefer when the elements arrive separately, then are mixed in front of you - it arrives mixed here, but can't complain much about the taste
- Samosas - actually really delicious. I thought this would be a whatever appetizer, but the potato was of impeccable texture and consistency!
- A chicken noodle dish whose name I can't remember - I think it was the third on one the list. Neither here nor there. Skip
- Fish in tamarind sauce - probably the best thing we had. Not for the faint of nose, if you're not used to pungent smells. The taste can't be beat, though
