- Ginger pork - would have liked it to be a bit more tender. Would skip it next time
- Coconut rice - the most superior option of all the rices. So good!

Also, quite reasonable - every entrée is about $10. It's also super clean and well-decorated. I'm a fan!

excerpts: We had the tea leaf salad and curry chicken with tapioca for dessert.
tea leaf salad.author: Alex K.
tea leaf salad.review: The food and service are both great!  We had the tea leaf salad and curry chicken with tapioca for dessert.

excerpts: I got the tea leaf salad and garlic noodles.
I love Burmese food, but since I was testing out the waters I wanted to keep it basic.
It wasn't the worst food I've ever had, but let's just say I only ate the food because I didn't want to waste my money.
The tea leaf salad lacked flavor and the garlic noodles were so greasy.
Not coming back.
tea leaf salad.author: Lioness C.
tea leaf salad.review: I got the tea leaf salad and garlic noodles. I love Burmese food, but since I was testing out the waters I wanted to keep it basic. It wasn't the worst food I've ever had, but let's just say I only ate the food because I didn't want to waste my money. The tea leaf salad lacked flavor and the garlic noodles were so greasy. Not coming back.

excerpts: A must have is their green tea leaf salad, hands down the best compared to all the Burmese restaurant I've been to.
tea leaf salad.author: Dechen S.
tea leaf salad.review: One of my favorite Burmese restaurant. A must have is their green tea leaf salad, hands down the best compared to all the Burmese restaurant I've been to. My favorites and regular choice here is the spicy fish (you can ask them to make it mild), Garlic Eggplant, beef and potato curry with rice, delicious all together.

excerpts: Everyone raves about the tea leaf salad.
I had been to the restaurant 4 or 5 times before actually trying it.
tea leaf salad.author: Nick C.
tea leaf salad.review:
Burmese Kitchen is possibly the greatest restaurant in San Francisco. Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence, so here's why.

Burmese food is unique, but not too weird. It's different enough to be refreshing but familiar enough to be comforting.

It's reasonably priced. The entrees are around 10 bucks and can be shared if you both get rice. IMPORTANT: get the coconut rice. It blew away all my expectations about how tasty something as simple as rice can be.

The interior isn't too fancy, but it's clean. Very appropriate for a casual date. (They also serve drinks.)

There's usually not a line. This is so important to me. When I want to eat, I want to eat.

Service is prompt and friendly. The son that's pretty much always working there is cool.

It's family owned so you feel like you're supporting the neighborhood.

There are plenty of veggie and gluten free options. Everyone raves about the tea leaf salad. I had been to the restaurant 4 or 5 times before actually trying it. It's tasty, but there's so much more to the restaurant than the salad!

My personal favorite is pork with dal. I get it every single time and change out the other entrees. Burmese Kitchen has become my first stop any time someone from out of town visits me in the Richmond.

excerpts: The tea leaf salad was delicious!
So much love goes into making the food, and it really shines through.
Definitely a favorite in the City
tea leaf salad.author: Kasian G.
tea leaf salad.review:
Amazing atmosphere! Wonderful Service!
This is a hidden gem, I'm lucky to have found myself hear. The food the most authentic Burmese in the City. The tea leaf salad was delicious! So much love goes into making the food, and it really shines through. Definitely a favorite in the City

excerpts: We got the tea leaf salad, coconut chicken soup, spicy fish, chicken curry, and chin baung jaw shrimp & sour leaf.
If this isn't highlighted enough in the other reviews, the tea leaf salad was AMAZING!
I was extremely impressed how fresh the leaves were and how flavorful the marinate was.
We only ordered one dish for the four of us
and it wasn't enough.
Coconut chicken soup is probably one of my favorite burmese dishes because it's almost at every family party I've been to
so my relatives get a lot of practice making it.
While it was still pretty good at Burmese kitchen, I wasn't mind blown.
But again, it's hard for me to judge.
tldr; The must haves are the tea leaf salad and coconut rice with chicken (and spicy fish if you can handle heat).
If you want to try something more unique to Burmese culture try the coconut chicken soup but stay safe and if you're adventurous the chin baung jaw.
tea leaf salad.author: Edric K.
tea leaf salad.review:
I'm pretty picky when it comes to Burmese food.  Both of my parents are from Burma and are pretty active in the Burmese community in the Bay Area so I'm always skeptical when it comes to Burmese food.  The first and last restaurant I went to was Rangoon Ruby in Palo Alto and was fairly unimpressed in terms of quality per dollar. So I went to Burmese Kitchen with low expectations and had them shattered.

I went with three of my friends and decided to order family style.  We got the tea leaf salad, coconut chicken soup, spicy fish, chicken curry, and chin baung jaw shrimp & sour leaf.

If this isn't highlighted enough in the other reviews, the tea leaf salad was AMAZING!  I was extremely impressed how fresh the leaves were and how flavorful the marinate was.  We only ordered one dish for the four of us and it wasn't enough.  I'd recommend 1 for every 2 people unless you plan on filling up with a variety of dishes.

Coconut chicken soup is probably one of my favorite burmese dishes because it's almost at every family party I've been to so my relatives get a lot of practice making it.  While it was still pretty good at Burmese kitchen, I wasn't mind blown.  But again, it's hard for me to judge. I think it's worth trying if you haven't had it before.

We had the spicy fish and chicken curry with coconut rice and I'd HIGHLY RECOMMEND you do the same!  This is definitely a dish I'd get the next time I come here.  The chicken was very tender and would fall off the bone and paired perfectly with the rice.  The fish was a little too hot for someone in our group, but if you're fine with spicy food it was this is also a must!

If you're looking for something uniquely Burmese, I'd give the chin baung jaw shrimp & sour leaf a try.  Admittedly it was a little weird for two of my friends since sour food isn't really popular in most cultures but if you want to be adventurous I think this is definitely something different.

tldr; The must haves are the tea leaf salad and coconut rice with chicken (and spicy fish if you can handle heat).  
If you want to try something more unique to Burmese culture try the coconut chicken soup but stay safe and if you're adventurous the chin baung jaw.

excerpts: We always order the same things --- Rainbow salad, tea leaf salad, coconut noodle soup.
tea leaf salad.author: Sai S.
tea leaf salad.review:
We have ordered takeout about 10 times now. We always order the same things --- Rainbow salad, tea leaf salad, coconut noodle soup. 

I was going to get it four stars but I bumped it up to five stars because of two things. Consistency and speed. These items are consistently the same and consistently really good. They also make their food relatively quickly which is much appreciated for takeout. Combine that with reasonable prices and you get five stars from me!

excerpts: While I enjoyed the house tea leaf salad a lot, the two other things we ordered weren't just disappointing, they were gross and thinking of them now, a few days later, makes me feel disgusted.
Get the house tea leaf salad and nothing else.
tea leaf salad.author: Michelle G.
tea leaf salad.review:
The menu shows two different tea leaf salads. The only difference I could see was something about extra tea leaves and one had tomatoes while the other didn't. I ended up asking, and it turns out both have tomatoes, one just has more tea leaves.

While I enjoyed the house tea leaf salad a lot, the two other things we ordered weren't just disappointing, they were gross and thinking of them now, a few days later, makes me feel disgusted. The combo fried platter was overly fried and quite crispy, with an unimpressive sauce. The coconut noodle soup was the worst--it had a weird texture that stuck to my mouth, the coconut milk might have been a bit sour or something, the flavor wasn't great, and the crunchy things (no idea what they were) tasted burnt.

tl;dr: Get the house tea leaf salad and nothing else.

excerpts: We ordered the house special tea leaf salad, garlic noodles with shrimp, and chicken biryani.
Both the noodles and the biryani were outstanding, and the leaf salad also did not disappoint.
In sum: delicious food, great service, and affordable prices.
Plus they serve food until 10. A+.
tea leaf salad.author: Yana Y.
tea leaf salad.review: We came in about 20 minutes before close yet were greeted kindly, without the typical annoyed looks restaurant staff reserve for guests keeping them late. We ordered the house special tea leaf salad, garlic noodles with shrimp, and chicken biryani. Both the noodles and the biryani were outstanding, and the leaf salad also did not disappoint. In sum: delicious food, great service, and affordable prices. Plus they serve food until 10. A+.

excerpts: We got the signature tea leaf salad, fish chowder and lemongrass beef.
All three dishes were flavorful and not very pricey, especially compared to the other local sf Burmese restaurants.
tea leaf salad.author: Julie H.
tea leaf salad.review: We dropped by for a quick meal after Ft Funston and were really pleased. We got the signature tea leaf salad, fish chowder and lemongrass beef. All three dishes were flavorful and not very pricey, especially compared to the other local sf Burmese restaurants.

excerpts: I love tea leaf salad, but their tamarind leaf salad is a notch above.
The soups and the stews are fantastic; the sauerkraut pork is the one I always go back to.
tea leaf salad.author: Les P.
tea leaf salad.review:
Probably my favorite restaurant in the city. They've been great since their prior location in the Tenderloin, but I feel like they've gotten even better at their new Geary spot. Their dishes are generally more varied and delicious than at other nearby Burmese establishments.

First off, this is the only place I know of that has tamarind leaf salad. I love tea leaf salad, but their tamarind leaf salad is a notch above. The soups and the stews are fantastic; the sauerkraut pork is the one I always go back to. But I try something new every time and they never disappoint.

The prices are extremely reasonable too, for what you are eating. I would call it $$$ food at a $ price.

excerpts: Had their tea leaf salad which was one of the best I've had in SF!
I feel like it had more toasted nuts, beans and seeds than other places and had more flavor as well.
The roti paratha was a bit underdone, but was not too oily which was nice and the curry sauce it came with was rich in flavor.
We also tried the fish stew noodles which was comforting, with a good combination of textures from the crispy samosa like crackers and toasted mung beans.
Noodles could have been less soggy though and would have liked to see more fish.
All in all a solid meal and will def be back.
tea leaf salad.author: Olivia T.
tea leaf salad.review: Had their tea leaf salad which was one of the best I've had in SF!  I feel like it had more toasted nuts, beans and seeds than other places and had more flavor as well.  The roti paratha was a bit underdone, but was not too oily which was nice and the curry sauce it came with was rich in flavor.    We also tried the fish stew noodles which was comforting, with a good combination of textures from the crispy samosa like crackers and toasted mung beans.  Noodles could have been less soggy though and would have liked to see more fish.  All in all a solid meal and will def be back.

excerpts: The tea leaf salad is currently the best I've had.
tea leaf salad.author: Tyrone V.
tea leaf salad.review: I'd say Burmese Kitchen is closer to 4 and a half stars, but I'll round up for this review (pending future visits, of course). Chose Burmese Kitchen for a random Thursday lunch, due to the very reasonable entree prices (the lunch menu is a good deal). The tea leaf salad is currently the best I've had. The rainbow salad, while full of flavors, lacked the synergy of flavors that I've come to expect (three and a half stars, I'd say). The restaurant is small and the service is friendly and attentive. I'd like to visit again to try the catfish chowder soup and nan gyi thohk.

excerpts: Fabulous tea leaf salad and super spicy chicken curry
so beware.
tea leaf salad.author: Monica R.
tea leaf salad.review: Yes we had the same experience of waiting an hour or enjoy a Burmese meal without the wait. Fabulous tea leaf salad and super spicy chicken curry so beware.

excerpts: Ordered the tea leaf salad, veg soup and lemongrass beef.
Delicious!
tea leaf salad.author: LA R.
tea leaf salad.review: Great local takeout spot! Ordered the tea leaf salad, veg soup and lemongrass beef. Delicious!

excerpts: get the regular tea leaf salad.
very peanuty tho.
roti was oily and over priced.

just 1 piece for $6+
coconut curry was creamy.
awesome when mixed with coconut rice.
tea leaf salad.author: Jason C.
tea leaf salad.review:
get the regular tea leaf salad. very peanuty tho.
roti was oily and over priced. just 1 piece for $6+
coconut curry was creamy. awesome when mixed with coconut rice.
overall everything was good, but not very memorable.

if anything, try the salad, as thats the only thing that really stood out.

excerpts: We started off with the tea leaf salad which to me had way too many nuts and lentils.
Very crunchy and the presentation wasn't like how Burma presents it.
I was not a fan.
We then ordered the combo platter appetizer.
Let me just say none of this was homemade, rather frozen and deep fried upon ordering.
The samosas and falafel were exactly like the ones you get from trader joes frozen section.
tea leaf salad.author: Kehaulani K.
tea leaf salad.review:
I'm a huge fan of Burma Superstar and Mandalay! When this place opened up in my hood I figured based on the reviews it would be amazing. 

We started off with the tea leaf salad which to me had way too many nuts and lentils. Very crunchy and the presentation wasn't like how Burma presents it. I was not a fan.
We then ordered the combo platter appetizer. Let me just say none of this was homemade, rather frozen and deep fried upon ordering. The samosas and falafel were exactly like the ones you get from trader joes frozen section. Totally let down.

For our main entrees we had the pork with pickled mango, garlic noodles and coconut rice. The pork was the only dish that had flavor and was actually decent. The meat was tender and has a well balanced array of spices. The garlic noodles however came in a huge blob and stuck together, very bland. Sadly the coconut rice cannot compete with burmas. There was not even a hint of coconut.

Sorry Burmese kitchen but I won't be returning.

excerpts: Tea Leaf Salad, Combo Fried Platter,  Fish & Sour Leaf Soup, Spicy Fish & Chicken Biryani.
There are so many other things on the menu that are delicious
but these dishes are above and beyond so good!
The soup and spicy fish are definitely spicy but if you can handle the spice - try them!
tea leaf salad.author: JoAnn C.
tea leaf salad.review: Don't go anywhere else for Burmese food - the food and service here are superb! Several things that you must try...Tea Leaf Salad, Combo Fried Platter,  Fish & Sour Leaf Soup, Spicy Fish & Chicken Biryani. There are so many other things on the menu that are delicious but these dishes are above and beyond so good! The soup and spicy fish are definitely spicy but if you can handle the spice - try them!

excerpts: Their Tea Leaf Salad is also a must have.
Every time I come here I am greeted like family.
Friendly wait staff.
Burmese Kitchen is a must try when I'm in the area!
tea leaf salad.author: Hosick F.
tea leaf salad.review:
Love the Burmese food here!  My mom cooks Burmese food and the dishes here rank up there with her cooking.  I usually get Spicy Garlic Fish or Shrimp.  The Tamarind Fish is also very delicious.  The sauces are very flavorful.  

Their Tea Leaf Salad is also a must have.  Every time I come here I am greeted like family.  Friendly wait staff.  Burmese Kitchen is a must try when I'm in the area!

excerpts:
We had the following:

- tea leaf salad
- roasted ginger chicken
- basa fish fillet in tamarind sauce

Overall, both the service and meal were quite good, especially the tea leaf salad.
tea leaf salad.author: Ty L.
tea leaf salad.review:
This space is a bit bittersweet to me since my favorite Korean place, To Hyang, used to occupy this space. Although I'm sad that they're no longer here, I am happy to see that another family run establishment has taken it's place. That aside, on to the review!

I really like this place even though I didn't get to try out as many dishes as I wanted. There were only two of us and so we could only order so much. We had the following:

- tea leaf salad
- roasted ginger chicken
- basa fish fillet in tamarind sauce

Overall, both the service and meal were quite good, especially the tea leaf salad. I kept seeing people around me getting the noodle dishes, so I'll definitely have to try that out next time. 

Lastly, given the proximity to B Star and Burma Superstar, for quality, authenticity, and price, I'd definitely recommend this place over the former. So do yourself a favor, give them a shot! :D

excerpts: Bermese kitchen had an excellent Tea leaf salad, enough to share for two people.
tea leaf salad.author: Melissa R.
tea leaf salad.review: Bermese kitchen had an excellent Tea leaf salad, enough to share for two people. I ordered the Chicken Masala noodles which were delicious with tons of flavor but not an overpowering amount. The home Thai hot tea was a great choice to cleanse the pallet after each bite.

excerpts: Tea leaf salad - When we've ordered this at the old location, it was good.
But when we ordered it this time, the flavors seemed to be brighter
, fresher, fuller.

Normally when we would take friends to their previous location, we'd get this just because it is a Burmese staple, but now, I can confidently say that this is THE BEST tea leaf salad I've ever had in the bay area!
tea leaf salad.author: Roxanne K.
tea leaf salad.review:
Disclaimer: My husband's relatives own this restaurant, but my review is as unbiased as can be!

I usually am wary about going to a newly opened restaurant because they still have some kinks to work out, but this was different.  Yes, they were a fully functioning and awesome restaurant before their move, but OMG has it gotten so much better!  Everything tastes fresher.

Roti & potato curry - I LOVE THIS DISH.  My only wish is that they serve it with more roti, but that can be easily solved by ordering 2! :)

Tea leaf salad - When we've ordered this at the old location, it was good.  But when we ordered it this time, the flavors seemed to be brighter, fresher, fuller.  Normally when we would take friends to their previous location, we'd get this just because it is a Burmese staple, but now, I can confidently say that this is THE BEST tea leaf salad I've ever had in the bay area!

Mohinga - fish chowder - A very hearty soup dish that can be eaten as a main dish or shared between 3-4 people.

Dan Pauk - biryani chicken - My hubby's favorite and this was no exception.  The rice is cooked to perfection and the chicken  wonderfully seasoned with curry and other spices.

Spicy fish - The fish is lightly fried and served with a chili/garlic sauce. If you can't handle the heat though, maybe skip this or be sure the rest of your group can.  Hehe.

Chicken curry - can't go wrong with chicken curry!

Coconut rice - This pairs so well with the chicken curry. If you like coconut milk, this is a must try! Don't be afraid, it's not too sweet.  It's a light flavor of coconut milk that's slightly toasted/nutty.

Service is great.  Attentive staff without being overbearing.  Parking is a bit tough, but honestly, this restaurant is well worth the walk and wait.  However, I think the neighborhood is a step up from their last location.  Give Burmese Kitchen a chance!  You won't be disappointed!

excerpts:
Tea Leaf Salad
Mohinga which is considered the National Dish of Burma!!
tea leaf salad.author: Kiel V.
tea leaf salad.review:
If you enjoy Burmese food, you will like it here.. 
Recommendations:

Tea Leaf Salad
Mohinga which is considered the National Dish of Burma!! 

I've been enjoying this stuff since I was a little kid.. 

This is great and it is delicious!! 

The other Burmese places may be flashier but this place has great food!! Let the food be the decider..

excerpts: Old lunch favorites are still on the menu, but went for dinner so kept the carbs down, with: BK Tea Leaf Salad (better than ever!), Shrimp with Sour Leaf (most unusual flavor!), and a few bites of Burmese Fried Rice (most interesting variations).
A couple of Samosas for an appetizer (very fat and savory).
As usual, the owners circulate among the guests, both regaling guests with stories of the restaurant business and Burmese cuisine and music and soliciting feedback on how they are doing.
Still tinkering with decor and acoustics, but on their way!
Great night out on Geary!
The new locations is so much better than their old neighborhood, too!
tea leaf salad.author: A. M.
tea leaf salad.review:
Wonderful food and great hosts!  So glad to see them finally reopen after their move!
Old lunch favorites are still on the menu, but went for dinner so kept the carbs down, with: BK Tea Leaf Salad (better than ever!), Shrimp with Sour Leaf (most unusual flavor!), and a few bites of Burmese Fried Rice (most interesting variations).  A couple of Samosas for an appetizer (very fat and savory).  As usual, the owners circulate among the guests, both regaling guests with stories of the restaurant business and Burmese cuisine and music and soliciting feedback on how they are doing.  Still tinkering with decor and acoustics, but on their way!  Great night out on Geary!   The new locations is so much better than their old neighborhood, too!

excerpts: The tea leaf salad is the best.
tea leaf salad.author: Erik Y.
tea leaf salad.review: The best Burmese restaurant in town. The tea leaf salad is the best. Fish chowder was delicious, everything was really good. Could not have found a better place in San Francisco.

excerpts: Ordered the tea leaf salad.
Deliciously authentic.
The atmosphere here is also very nice.
The owner is very friendly.
Definitely supporting this neighborhood gem #supportsmallbusiness
tea leaf salad.author: Rachelle L.
tea leaf salad.review: Ordered the tea leaf salad. Deliciously authentic. The atmosphere here is also very nice. The owner is very friendly. Definitely supporting this neighborhood gem #supportsmallbusiness

excerpts: The Roti and Potato curry is great as is the tea leaf salad and the curry coconut chicken.
The staff is very kind and friendly and I have enjoyed their food for years.
Started dining with them at their old location and
this one is much nicer...
tea leaf salad.author: Will M.
tea leaf salad.review: The absolutely most authentic Burmese food I have found in SF.  The Roti and Potato curry is great as is the tea leaf salad and the curry coconut chicken.   The staff is very kind and friendly and I have enjoyed their food for years.   Started dining with them at their old location and this one is much nicer...

excerpts: We started off with the tea leaf salad.
tea leaf salad.author: Nate C.
tea leaf salad.review:
I really enjoyed the food and service here. I've never been to Burma, but this is what I expect authentic Burmese food to taste like. 

We started off with the tea leaf salad. Not too sure what people are talking about, but the portion and ratio of tea leaves to the other ingredients gave the salad a great fresh flavor. 

After indulging on the salad, we got the chicken curry with some coconut rice. I personally love all things coconut and rice is no exception. The rice had just the right amount of stickiness and coconut flavor. The spices in the curry was also good. I loved it since it was the right amount of spice for my palate. 

The service was very attentive and I enjoyed the staff. 

Overall, great value especially for the quality and flavor. I definitely will be back.

excerpts: In my personal opinion, they have the best tea leaf salad around.
tea leaf salad.author: A S.
tea leaf salad.review: I'm so glad I followed Burmese Kitchen to their new location. Despite the handful of Burmese restaurants in the area, none rival their exquisite flavor, and level of attentiveness and friendliness. In my personal opinion, they have the best tea leaf salad around. I also love the yellow pea dish and biryani rice with saffron. A wonderful option for vegans! This place is a gem!

excerpts: They have 2 different types of tea leaf salad, a regular tea leaf salad and the signature tea leaf salad that comes with more fermented tea leaves.
I recommend ordering the signature tea leaf salad.
It was definitely delicious, but the only thing was that it was a small portion.
We ended up having to order 2 of them to have enough for 3 people.
tea leaf salad.author: Kyle S.
tea leaf salad.review: I absolutely love Burmese tea leaf salads, so it was a must-order dish for me. They have 2 different types of tea leaf salad, a regular tea leaf salad and the signature tea leaf salad that comes with more fermented tea leaves. I recommend ordering the signature tea leaf salad. It was definitely delicious, but the only thing was that it was a small portion. We ended up having to order 2 of them to have enough for 3 people. The fish chowder was delicious, was spicier than I had anticipated it would be, but was still manageable. We also ordered the lady fingers (okra), which was a nice veggie dish. Overall, this place was a pretty good Burmese restaurant - definitely a place to try if you'd like to try Burmese food and avoid the long line at Burma Superstar.

excerpts: They also have a lot of healthy options, like tea leaf salad and light but rich okra.
I'd eat here over Burma Superstar any day.
tea leaf salad.author: George W.
tea leaf salad.review: Burmese Kitchen is just the best. It's delicious and has a low-key family vibe. Every dish is perfectly executed, fresh and flavorful. They also have a lot of healthy options, like tea leaf salad and light but rich okra. I'd eat here over Burma Superstar any day.

excerpts: Tea Leaf Salad--
Best one in the city, and we've tried them all.
tea leaf salad.author: Mariko S.
tea leaf salad.review:
What a find! Came here to try it after hearing it reopened--and it was such a good decision! The restaurant itself is intimate, a great spot for a date night. The orange wall and clean wooden tables give it a nice modern look while still remaining comfy and welcoming.

We had: 

Tea Leaf Salad--Best one in the city, and we've tried them all. It isn't too spicy, is a great portion, and very flavorful.

Samosas--So good! Not greasy at all, and stuffed with deliciously seasoned potatoes and peas...

Roti--Thousand layer bread, so delicate and flaky. mmm

Beef & Potato Curry--The beef was so tender and juicy--it melted in your mouth. The potatoes were hot and perfectly cooked, and the curry spices were just right. Exactly what we were looking for on a cold, rainy SF night. 

Tapioca Pudding--brought my fiancee back to her childhood. It was prepared just like her grandma used to make, warm with a bit of coconut/condensed milk. She was in heaven.

And our server--Lee was very sweet to take a few minutes to chat with us about the old location and the new one. She was quick and very busy with many full tables!

Overall--they prices were fair for the right amount of food, and you can taste the love and family recipes. So satisfying, and might be habit forming. 

We will definitely be back!

excerpts: Each bite and sip of tea at BK brings me back to my days living in Burma--the owners offer a unique experience by welcoming all guests to taste the best of Burma's culture, such as Mohinga and lahpet thoke (tea leaf salad) which the owner personally travels to Burma to bring back the tea leaves.
Best of SF!
tea leaf salad.author: Carolyn W.
tea leaf salad.review: Most people will never get the chance to travel to Burma but a trip (preferably many) to the Burmese Kitchen will bring you to the Far East through each of its authentic plates. Each bite and sip of tea at BK brings me back to my days living in Burma--the owners offer a unique experience by welcoming all guests to taste the best of Burma's culture, such as Mohinga and lahpet thoke (tea leaf salad) which the owner personally travels to Burma to bring back the tea leaves. Best of SF!

excerpts: Small tea leaf salad to start, then tamarind fish and yellow peas.
I like that it's not super crowded all the time like Burma Superstar.
You walk in and immediately order, and the food is pretty quick.
tea leaf salad.author: Josh J.
tea leaf salad.review: This place is the bomb! I eat the lunch special 3 times a week. Small tea leaf salad to start, then tamarind fish and yellow peas. I like that it's not super crowded all the time like Burma Superstar. You walk in and immediately order, and the food is pretty quick.

excerpts: Tried the tea leaf salad (didn't taste very fresh), garlic noodles (quite flavorless & noodles were partially hard/overcooked), samolina cake (just okay) --
the only dish I enjoyed was the chicken coconut curry.
However, it probably wasn't enough to make me come back.
I hate to encourage the "mainstream" choice, but in this case, Burma Superstar really stands out as the superior option for Burmese food in the area.
tea leaf salad.author: Kristina W.
tea leaf salad.review: I typically love Burmese food, but I wasn't a fan of the food I ordered here. Tried the tea leaf salad (didn't taste very fresh), garlic noodles (quite flavorless & noodles were partially hard/overcooked), samolina cake (just okay) -- the only dish I enjoyed was the chicken coconut curry. However, it probably wasn't enough to make me come back. I hate to encourage the "mainstream" choice, but in this case, Burma Superstar really stands out as the superior option for Burmese food in the area.

excerpts: I loved their tea leaf salad, roti, chicken curry and biryani rice.
I also couldn't stop oogling at the food at other tables
so I can't wait to go back with the hubby and try something new.
tea leaf salad.author: C L.
tea leaf salad.review: I didn't think I would encounter another restaurant that could give Burma Superstar a run for its money but Burmese Kitchen is absolutely delicious.  I loved their tea leaf salad, roti, chicken curry and biryani rice. I also couldn't stop oogling at the food at other tables so I can't wait to go back with the hubby and try something new.

excerpts: Tea Leaf Salad.
This is light yet hardy, fresh and delicious.
tea leaf salad.author: June L.
tea leaf salad.review:
LOVE this restaurant! Atmosphere and service are great and the food, most importantly, is amazing. I've eaten here twice so far and both times have been equally satisfying. This place beats Burma Superstar without a doubt; it's way more authentic and food tastes fresher. Although it's busy, it's still fairly new so not too many people know about it (which is great because I frankly hate waiting in lines!). Coming back here next week for round three! See below for recommended orders.

What we loved:
Tea Leaf Salad. This is light yet hardy, fresh and delicious. 
Roti & Potato Curry: this was a wild card for us but turned out to be excellent! Very filling and flavorful.
Chin Baung Hin Yay Fish & Sour Leaf: This is SPICY and so delicious. I'm not a fan of fish soups but this was seriously so good! Incredibly flavorful, not overpowering, spicy - but just the right amount, and hardy! 
Garlic Chicken: three other tables ordered the same thing and each of us were in awe at how perfectly tender and delicious this dish was. We even eyed each other in affirmation of heavenly cooked the meat was -- so juicy!

excerpts: The tea leaf salad is amazing too (order the signature one for an extra generous helping of tea leaves), as is the tamarind salad, the samusas and the roti.
tea leaf salad.author: E. K.
tea leaf salad.review:
We have been going to Burmese Kitchen since it opened at its previous location on Larkin Street and have come to prefer it to some of the other popular Burmese restaurants in San Francisco because we find the food to be really exceptional and unique. It's also great that you don't have to wait in line for an hour! If you're a vegetarian you will be very satisfied by the options at Burmese Kitchen: Vegetarian food doesn't get more delicious and nutritious than this! We especially love the Golden Tofu Salad, which is unlike anything we'd ever tried before. Not to be confused with standard tofu made from soybeans, this tofu is made in house from yellow beans. I'm not sure what goes into the salad (fried onions, definitely) but it is so rich and tasty I could easily eat it every day. The tea leaf salad is amazing too (order the signature one for an extra generous helping of tea leaves), as is the tamarind salad, the samusas and the roti. If you eat seafood and enjoy spice you may like the spicy fish, fish soup with sour vegetables, or fish chowder (more mild). The pumpkin prawns are good too. Because my husband doesn't eat meat other than seafood, we haven't really tried many of the meat options, though some friends did order a chicken stew of some kind that they seemed to really enjoy. 
As a final note, we love the management here! They're always really kind and genuine and have been so friendly towards our young son, who is fast becoming a fan of Burmese cuisine. All in all, one of our very favorite restaurants in town!

excerpts: We ordered the tea leaf salad and a few other dishes.
The tea leaf salad did stand out and was tasty.
Price was affordable and reasonable.
We would come back here again.
tea leaf salad.author: Allan W.
tea leaf salad.review: Honey and I came here for dinner to try her favorite cuisine, Burmese. The place is family-like and small, also looks like a hole in the wall, which is fine. We ordered the tea leaf salad and a few other dishes. The tea leaf salad did stand out and was tasty. Price was affordable and reasonable. We would come back here again.

excerpts: Great tea leaf salad, and delicious coconut chicken.
Coconut rice is a really nice addition.
tea leaf salad.author: Uddhav A.
tea leaf salad.review: Superb Food. Great tea leaf salad, and delicious coconut chicken. Coconut rice is a really nice addition.

excerpts: The Tea Leaf Salad it amazing.
It was light, yummy and had an amazing aroma.
The food is reasonably priced, but a little on the expensive side for the curries in my opinion.
tea leaf salad.author: Toni A.
tea leaf salad.review: The Tea Leaf Salad it amazing. It was light, yummy and had an amazing aroma. The food is reasonably priced, but a little on the expensive side for the curries in my opinion.

excerpts:
Not impressive by any means 

Had a dish of mango salad as I wanted to taste something other than tea leaf salad ..
tea leaf salad.author: Y U.
tea leaf salad.review:
Not impressive by any means 

Had a dish of mango salad as I wanted to taste something other than tea leaf salad .. It was ok with quite less quantity for 10$ and then had garlic noodles which was quite not sauted as well. There was no taste as such and was really bland. When this was mentioned to server his only response was to get some soy sauce.

The ambience of this place is not so nice. Regular table chairs with minimum deco

excerpts: The tea leaf salad (get the extra fermented one) is delicious in flavor and texture, and as much as I love Burma Superstar
I think this one is my favorite.
Lots of awesome fish and veggie options and super friendly staff.
I make it a point to visit here every time I'm in SF.
tea leaf salad.author: Andy H.
tea leaf salad.review: There's a lot to love about this place. The tea leaf salad (get the extra fermented one) is delicious in flavor and texture, and as much as I love Burma Superstar I think this one is my favorite. Lots of awesome fish and veggie options and super friendly staff. I make it a point to visit here every time I'm in SF.

excerpts: We started with the tea leaf salad, which was very tasty.
You could really taste the fermented tea leaves and that contrasted really well with the crispy peas, peanuts, cabbage, & garlic chips.
tea leaf salad.author: Quentin J.
tea leaf salad.review:
We usually go to Volcano Curry when we're in this neighborhood, but we decided to try this place because we haven't had Burmese in a while. We started with the tea leaf salad, which was very tasty.  You could really taste the fermented tea leaves and that contrasted really well with the crispy peas, peanuts, cabbage, & garlic chips. Next we had the roti with the yellow potato curry.  We both commented that it was excellent comfort food. The bread was nice and hot, and there were big chunks of potato in the curry. The roti was pretty small, so we had to eat some curry without bread, but it was still excellent. Next came the garlic egg noodles. They weren't very special - definitely the least inspired dish, but I did like the crispy garlic in it.  Finally we had the lemongrass beef. I don't think I've ever had this dish before, so the closest comparison I can come up with is mas-su-man beef.  It was the same style of stewed beef, with a similar type of gravy on it, but with a milder flavor. 
It's a cute little restaurant and the service was quick and friendly. We'll definitely be back and this time order two of the tea salads and two of the roti with the yellow potato curry.

excerpts: The tea leaf salad was good.
I was not excited about my entrees though.
Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing.
tea leaf salad.author: Bill O.
tea leaf salad.review: The tea leaf salad was good. I was not excited about my entrees though. Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing.

excerpts: We ordered the yellow curry, fried rice, tea leaf salad, and something else.
Everything was so delicious.
I would say that if you want to avoid the crowd over other burmese restaurants, this would be a great place to go.
The ambience is so welcoming and homey.
The service was also great.
Loved it!
tea leaf salad.author: Justina L.
tea leaf salad.review: Burmese kitchen has some really great burmese food. We ordered the yellow curry, fried rice, tea leaf salad, and something else. Everything was so delicious. I would say that if you want to avoid the crowd over other burmese restaurants, this would be a great place to go. The ambience is so welcoming and homey. The service was also great. Loved it!

excerpts: Tea leaf salad was also quite good (not like Burma or Mandalay though).
We were quite disappointed with our entrees: coconut chicken curry and vegetable curry.
Both were clumpy and bland.
Adding rooster sauce didn't even help.
Coconut rice was excellent!
For $50, not worth our money.
tea leaf salad.author: Ms. B.
tea leaf salad.review: Just ok. We ordered delivery tonight. Samosas were incredible. Tea leaf salad was also quite good (not like Burma or Mandalay though). We were quite disappointed with our entrees: coconut chicken curry and vegetable curry. Both were clumpy and bland. Adding rooster sauce didn't even help. Coconut rice was excellent! For $50, not worth our money.

excerpts: The Tea Leaf Salad, Fried Samosas, Beef Biryani, and Fish with Tamarind Sauce were particularly splendid.
tea leaf salad.author: Abbas A.
tea leaf salad.review: Burmese Kitchen is hands down a must-eat restaurant with great, authentic food and a friendly atmosphere. The food's high quality and affordability make this restaurant far superior to the bland, culture-less, so-called "Asian" restaurants in other popular (US) cities. The Tea Leaf Salad, Fried Samosas, Beef Biryani, and Fish with Tamarind Sauce were particularly splendid.

excerpts:
Two tea leaf salad--definitely order the house special tea leaf salad!
Plump, spicy (and not greasy!) samosas
Sour leaf vegetable with shrimp (finally found a place that has my fave after all these years!)
tea leaf salad.author: Aggie A.
tea leaf salad.review:
Best Burmese food I've had (beside Mom's) at very reasonable prices!

Two tea leaf salad--definitely order the house special tea leaf salad!
Plump, spicy (and not greasy!) samosas
Sour leaf vegetable with shrimp (finally found a place that has my fave after all these years!)
Two biryanis (chicken and beef)

There are lots more, but these are the only ones that I can remember!  Most of the items hover around $10-$12/dish so it's about $ to $$.

Definitely go try it out, if you haven't tried it yet!

excerpts: The food is every bit as good: the tea leaf salad is a must-have; the spicy fish is as described and very garlicky as well.
tea leaf salad.author: Frank W.
tea leaf salad.review:
I was a regular at their old location in the Tenderloin. This new venue is bright, clean, and spacious. It is a huge improvement. 

The food is every bit as good: the tea leaf salad is a must-have; the spicy fish is as described and very garlicky as well. The service is friendly and easygoing. 

It's what makes the city great. Casual, cheap, and high quality. 

The owner told me lunch business is light but dinner is much more popular, compared to downtown. For a neighborhood place, this is fantastic. I had been wanting to get there to check it out. I would recommend it even if you have to drive: it is excellent.

excerpts: The tea leaf salad was wonderful.
So was the tamarind fish -- service was very friendly.
Although the place was small, they accommodated a group of 6 well.
Prices great!!!!
tea leaf salad.author: RD S.
tea leaf salad.review: The tea leaf salad was wonderful. So was the tamarind fish -- service was very friendly. Although the place was small, they accommodated a group of 6 well. Prices great!!!!

excerpts: Ordered the Spice Beef Jerky (good), Garlic Chicken (good and with lots of garlic), Tea Leaf Salad (excellent) and Garlic Egg Noodle (ok -
not sure what the hype on this dish was all about.
Will definitely try other dishes from the restaurant.
tea leaf salad.author: Hoa T.
tea leaf salad.review: found this place through UberEats.   Ordered the Spice Beef Jerky (good), Garlic Chicken (good and with lots of garlic), Tea Leaf Salad (excellent) and Garlic Egg Noodle (ok - not sure what the hype on this dish was all about.  Will definitely try other dishes from the restaurant.

excerpts: Tea Leaf Salad is fantastic.
Also my first time sitting at a community table, which allows you to get seated much faster with another party.
Don't worry though, they won't bug you!
tea leaf salad.author: Chris O.
tea leaf salad.review: Tea Leaf Salad is fantastic. Also my first time sitting at a community table, which allows you to get seated much faster with another party. Don't worry though, they won't bug you!

excerpts: Coconut chicken soup, tea leaf salad of course and lemongrass beef.
Burmese iced coffee is more on the light watery side compared to a thai or Vietnamese iced coffee.
Really friendly service.
To prevent wait time makes reservation
tea leaf salad.author: Juliana L.
tea leaf salad.review: Great food! Coconut chicken soup, tea leaf salad of course and lemongrass beef. Burmese iced coffee is more on the light watery side compared to a thai or Vietnamese iced coffee. Really friendly service. To prevent wait time makes reservation

excerpts:
3.5 stars

Had the roti with potato curry, moh hinga, special tea leaf salad, chicken curry, pork & pumpkin, mixed vegetable curry and coconut rice.
tea leaf salad.author: Chew B.
tea leaf salad.review:
3.5 stars

Had the roti with potato curry, moh hinga, special tea leaf salad, chicken curry, pork & pumpkin, mixed vegetable curry and coconut rice. The dishes had flavor but didn't have something distinctive to make them stand out. While the moh hinga was tasty, the chicken in the chicken curry was not fresh. Both Burma Superstar and Mandalay do a slightly better job. Service was attentive and it was easy to get in which is a strong positive for Burmese Kitchen.

excerpts: The tea leaf salad is authentic, the mohinga soup is delicious, and the mixed vegetable curry was tasty.
I enjoyed a cup of burmese milk tea while I waited for the food, this was also quite authentic.
You must try this restaurant!
tea leaf salad.author: Katelyn S.
tea leaf salad.review: This is the best Burmese food I have had since I went to Myanmar last year. The tea leaf salad is authentic, the mohinga soup is delicious, and the mixed vegetable curry was tasty. I enjoyed a cup of burmese milk tea while I waited for the food, this was also quite authentic. You must try this restaurant!

excerpts: The tea leaf salad is not too bad.
Sorry, I will not recommend this restaurant.
tea leaf salad.author: Melvon M.
tea leaf salad.review: The prawn and pumpkin was not fresh and salty. The string bean dish was ok. The vegetarian curry has a few pcs of main vegetables except for broccoli. Nothing special. The tea leaf salad is not too bad. Sorry, I will not recommend this restaurant.

excerpts: Had the pork w pickled mango, coconut rice, roti, signature tea leaf salad, Spicy lotus, hot milk tea....
all v good.
V recommend everything.
tea leaf salad.author: Juan T.
tea leaf salad.review: V good. V authentic. V quick service. V polite. V helpful. V good suggestions. Had the pork w pickled mango, coconut rice, roti, signature tea leaf salad, Spicy lotus, hot milk tea....all v good. V recommend everything.

excerpts: Tea leaf salad - this dish is hyped here more than in Burma.
It's a mix of tea leaf, nuts, sesame, some veggies, and tomato.
tea leaf salad.author: Sammantha T.
tea leaf salad.review:
This was my first time at the new location and the place is clean and nicely decorated.  The staff is friendly and attentive.  I went on a  Friday evening and they were packed!  I usually don't go to Burmese restaurants because my folks make it at home and that's pretty much what I eat almost everyday.  However, Burmese Kitchen is a great place to take your friends out and try different things on the menu because hey, Burmese restaurants are pretty rare.  This place has legit Burmese food and reminds me of everything I love about Burmese cuisines.

Roti and Curry - Delicious!  The roti is a thicker kind and it's delicious with almost anything, in this case, potato curry!  Vegetarian option.

Mohinga - international dish of Burma.  I tried this dish in other Burmese restaurants, but this one hits home.  It's burmese catfish soup with noodle and fried yellow pea.  This dish is eaten as breakfast, lunch, and/or dinner in Burma.  

Coconut chicken curry (Oh nok kaw swe) - I personally prefer this over mohinga.  Both are very delicious.

Tea leaf salad - this dish is hyped here more than in Burma.  It's a mix of tea leaf, nuts, sesame, some veggies, and tomato.  It's fresh and uniquely Burmese.

Fish with Tamarine Sauce - this was my favorite dish.  The fish was tender and had the perfect flavor with rice.  Highly recommended!

Other dishes to consider:
- Pork with Pickled Mango
- Spicy shrimp
- Nan Ji Thok - rice noodle mixed with veggies and chicken.  This doesn't come in soup, but is still tasty!
- Burmese tea - Burmese tea houses are big in Burma (similar to tea houses in China).   You gotta try the tea for the full Burmese experience.

Overall, my experience at Burmese Kitchen was positive.  Friendly staff and great food!

excerpts: Their tea leaf salad, eggplant with garlic sauce, chicken masala and the garlic noodles are our favorite dishes.
Definitely skip the lines elsewhere and try Burmese Kitchen.
tea leaf salad.author: Liz O.
tea leaf salad.review: A hidden gem, given that most people go to Burma Superstar and Mandalay nearby. Their tea leaf salad, eggplant with garlic sauce, chicken masala and the garlic noodles are our favorite dishes.  Definitely skip the lines elsewhere and try Burmese Kitchen.

excerpts: Favorites are the tea leaf salad (always fresh & with plenty of tea leaves) and garlic noodles and potato curry and the fried combo starter.
Yum.
tea leaf salad.author: Stacey H.
tea leaf salad.review:
I discovered Burma Kitchen in their old location on Larkin St. I had many delicious lunches there & was bummed when they closed. Imagine my delight when they re-opened in my neighborhood! Yay!

The food is fabulous and the prices are reasonable, this place is so much better than Superstar or Mandalay. I've been working my way through the menu (except for pork & beef) and haven't had a bad thing yet, although I don't recommend getting samosas for takeout because they get soggy when they get cold. Most things have been good, some even spectacular. I wasn't terribly impressed with the pumpkin stew but it was my personal taste, not anything they did wrong. Favorites are the tea leaf salad (always fresh & with plenty of tea leaves) and garlic noodles and potato curry and the fried combo starter. Yum.

excerpts: Tea leaf salad was all peanuts.
Tea leaves flavorless.
Samosas were filled with unspiced mashed potatoes.
Bad food presentation.
Go to Mandalay, B-Star or Burma Superstar.
tea leaf salad.author: Hilary K.
tea leaf salad.review: Not good. Tea leaf salad was all peanuts. Tea leaves flavorless. Samosas were filled with unspiced mashed potatoes. Bad food presentation. Go to Mandalay, B-Star or Burma Superstar.

excerpts: Went here for lunch, no wait and easy metered parking, delicious food though small portions of tea leaf salad for lunch special.
Very nice people, think the owner was working there.
I'll definitely be returning for dinner some time.
tea leaf salad.author: L J.
tea leaf salad.review: I love Burmese food! Went here for lunch, no wait and easy metered parking, delicious food though small portions of tea leaf salad for lunch special. Very nice people, think the owner was working there. I'll definitely be returning for dinner some time.

excerpts: I dream about Burmese Kitchen's tea leaf salad, ginger salad, spicy sliced bamboo and falafel soup.
These dishes are authentic, flavorful, fresh and wonderful.
We're vegetarian and love the variety of veggie dishes that aren't simply a meat dish made with tofu.
The decor is simple and clean.
The staff is friendly and helpful.
We miss lunch at the Tenderloin location but love getting dinner at the new location -- easy parking and hardly any wait.
A real winner.
tea leaf salad.author: Wendy T.
tea leaf salad.review: I dream about Burmese Kitchen's tea leaf salad, ginger salad, spicy sliced bamboo and falafel soup. These dishes are authentic, flavorful, fresh and wonderful. We're vegetarian and love the variety of veggie dishes that aren't simply a meat dish made with tofu. The decor is simple and clean. The staff is friendly and helpful. We miss lunch at the Tenderloin location but love getting dinner at the new location -- easy parking and hardly any wait. A real winner.

excerpts: Ordered the tea leaf salad, ginger chicken, and garlic chicken, and a lime juice.
Don't except fancy, just good authentic food and you can't beat the price!
tea leaf salad.author: Sarah A.
tea leaf salad.review: Excellent home cooked food.  Ordered the tea leaf salad, ginger chicken, and garlic chicken, and a lime juice.  Don't except fancy, just good authentic food and you can't beat the price!

excerpts: The tea leaf salad was delicious as was the sour leaf fish soup.
I remember meeting the owner years ago when he first opened in the Loin, and I wish him many more happy years of brisk business in the new location.
tea leaf salad.author: Ms. M N.
tea leaf salad.review: Back in SF for a visit after moving to NYC a year ago, I've been craving Burmese food and was sad to hear Burmese Kitchen in the Loin had closed. Quick research revealed the new location on Geary, and it did not disappoint! The tea leaf salad was delicious as was the sour leaf fish soup.  I remember meeting the owner years ago when he first opened in the Loin, and I wish him many more happy years of brisk business in the new location.

excerpts: Like the reviews mention, the tea leaf salad is one of the best that I've had; it's just like the home-made ones.
tea leaf salad.author: Carolyn L.
tea leaf salad.review: I rarely eat out for Burmese food. My parents are from Burma, so I tend to be disappointed with the Burmese restaurants out there. However, I was utterly surprised at how authentic the food is here. My friends enjoy Burmese cuisine, so we decided to come to Burmese Kitchen based off of the reviews. We ordered family style and everyone, including myself, was beyond satisfied with this decision. Like the reviews mention, the tea leaf salad is one of the best that I've had; it's just like the home-made ones. Of all of the dishes, my favorite was the fish noodle soup (mohinga), the biryani rice with chicken, and the shrimp and sour leaf. My friends loved the coconut noodle soup and spicy fish. To be honest, everything that we ate was delicious. They could not stop raving about the food and how it was one of the best they've had in the city. Also, I found out that Burmese Kitchen caters. I would definitely consider ordering some dishes for my next work potluck event. Everyone always asks me to bring home-made Burmese cuisine. I've found a place that I would be happy to vouch for as authentic.

excerpts: We started with the special BK tea leaf salad which is like normal tea leaf salad with extra tea leaves so it has a more intense flavor that I really enjoyed.
We also ordered roti with curry, nan gyi thok, coconut rice, okra, and the pickled mango pork.
Everything was great but the pork was absolutely delicious- flavorful, tender, and a tiny bit sour.
I highly recommend!
tea leaf salad.author: Natalie G.
tea leaf salad.review: Wow! I'm a big Burmese food fan and I'm so glad I found this place. I went for lunch on a Sunday and had an excellent meal. The service was lovely and food was amazing. We started with the special BK tea leaf salad which is like normal tea leaf salad with extra tea leaves so it has a more intense flavor that I really enjoyed. We also ordered roti with curry, nan gyi thok, coconut rice, okra, and the pickled mango pork. Everything was great but the pork was absolutely delicious- flavorful, tender, and a tiny bit sour. I highly recommend!

excerpts: The Tea leaf salad is covered in sesame seed goodness, the Garlic Chicken is amazing with the Coconut rice.
And my friends that have had other dishes have had nothing but good things to say about them as well.
Welcome to the Inner Richmond guys, hope you stick around!!
tea leaf salad.author: Tom K.
tea leaf salad.review: Not that the neighborhood really needed another Burmese joint, but Im glad these nice folks relocated to my neck of the woods! The food is most excellent and there is no line to get in. I usually go with take out after work so I can't say much of the wait staff except that everyone has been nothing but genuinely nice every time I've been in. The Tea leaf salad is covered in sesame seed goodness, the Garlic Chicken is amazing with the Coconut rice. And my friends that have had other dishes have had nothing but good things to say about them as well. Welcome to the Inner Richmond guys, hope you stick around!!

excerpts: We ordered a tea leaf salad, the samusa soup and the boiled eggs in tamarind sauce.
The salad cannot compare to the famed tea lead salad of Burma Superstar lore, but it was reasonably good.
The samusa soup was tasty and very healthy.
The boiled eggs in tamarind sauce was a new experience, and tasted much like an Indian curry.
Very flavorful and highly recommended.

The service was very friendly and helpful - even engaging us in conversation long after the other customers had left and never making us feel like it was time to go (despite the fact that we stayed quite late!).
tea leaf salad.author: Nikhil V.
tea leaf salad.review: This restaurant used to be in the Tenderloin; the Inner Richmond location is new. We were greeted by a very homey atmosphere, with the music turned just a little lower than the volume of conversation, and no greeter/gatekeeper at the door. But the waiter was attentive and seated us right away. The tea was a good temperature, properly steeped, and happened to be imported from Burma. We ordered a tea leaf salad, the samusa soup and the boiled eggs in tamarind sauce. The salad cannot compare to the famed tea lead salad of Burma Superstar lore, but it was reasonably good. The samusa soup was tasty and very healthy. The boiled eggs in tamarind sauce was a new experience, and tasted much like an Indian curry. Very flavorful and highly recommended. The service was very friendly and helpful - even engaging us in conversation long after the other customers had left and never making us feel like it was time to go (despite the fact that we stayed quite late!).

excerpts: Our favorites are the tofu salad (chickpea tofu), pickled ginger salad, and tamarind leaf salad.
ginger salad.author: Alex M.
ginger salad.review: Best Burmese food in San Francisco. My girlfriend is Burmese from Shan state and attests that this is the most authentic in terms of menu and ingredients. It's also the only place that has authentic Burmese tea. We've eaten here many times and never been disappointed. Great selection of dishes for vegans and vegetarians (and meat lovers too). The salads are much better than Burma Superstar. Our favorites are the tofu salad (chickpea tofu), pickled ginger salad, and tamarind leaf salad.

excerpts:
Favorites are:
Ginger salad
Coconut soup
Chicken curry
Tea leaf salad
ginger salad.author: Ross R.
ginger salad.review:
One of our favorite restaurants in all of San Francisco.

Seriously. We go here at least once a week and it's the best Burmese we've had after trying all of them. Amazingly delicious food at the most reasonable prices. 

There's no flair and you don't come here for the decor or ambiance, you come for amazingly authentic delicious food. 

Favorites are:
Ginger salad
Coconut soup
Chicken curry
Tea leaf salad 
Roti

Park on clement st, skip the overhyped overpriced restaurants and walk on block here. You won't regret it.

excerpts: Get some of their more interesting salads, like the ginger salad or the rainbow salad.
ginger salad.author: Josh B.
ginger salad.review:
Strongly recommended for lunch.  They have a set of lunch specials for $10 to $12 which should pretty much cover everyone's tastes.  

And really, BK is currently the best Burmese food in the city.  Definitely better than Superstar.  Get some of their more interesting salads, like the ginger salad or the rainbow salad.

excerpts: We also got a ginger salad, which started off tasty
but it was overdressed and after a few bites it was hard to continue eating it.
The rice was overcooked and there was something "off" about it.
Lastly we had garlic noodles.
Those were the best because the veggies were steamed, so the dish was healthy, which I appreciate.
ginger salad.author: S Z.
ginger salad.review:
Meh. Neither my friend nor I were impressed by our meals. I tried to order two dishes that they were out of, so I ended up getting the garlic eggplant. It lacked flavor and some of the pieces of eggplant did not seem fully cooked. We also got a ginger salad, which started off tasty but it was overdressed and after a few bites it was hard to continue eating it. The rice was overcooked and there was something "off" about it. Lastly we had garlic noodles. Those were the best because the veggies were steamed, so the dish was healthy, which I appreciate. Just don't expect sauce or much flavor other than crunchy garlic on top. 

Overall I was excited to have another Burmese spot but unfortunately this place did not live up to SF standards.

excerpts: Choice of salad: tea leaf or ginger salad.
The salad was small but sufficient.
ginger salad.author: Kaykay K.
ginger salad.review:
We went for lunch. Reasonably priced. Good portions. My husband ordered the "Meatlover" lunch plate: a choice of 1 meat dish, and 1 vegetable dish for $11 including steamed rice. Add $1 for coconut rice, brown rice, fried rice or biryani rice.  He chose the pork with pickled mango, pumpkin stew, and biryani rice - all for $12. (Their lunch menu is posted online).

I ordered the Soup and Salad for $12. Choice of soup: fish chowder, samosa soup, or chicken coconut noodle soup. Choice of salad: tea leaf or ginger salad. The salad was small but sufficient. The chicken coconut noodle soup was good and filled me, and I left satisfied.

The owner was very friendly. He said he was testing out the lunch hours. So far it has been slow at lunch, but busy at dinnertime. If lunch remains slow, he may close for lunch and offer only dinner hours.  So folks, come on down.  Keep this place open at lunchtime, please!

excerpts: I dream about Burmese Kitchen's tea leaf salad, ginger salad, spicy sliced bamboo and falafel soup.
These dishes are authentic, flavorful, fresh and wonderful.
We're vegetarian and love the variety of veggie dishes that aren't simply a meat dish made with tofu.
The decor is simple and clean.
The staff is friendly and helpful.
We miss lunch at the Tenderloin location but love getting dinner at the new location -- easy parking and hardly any wait.
A real winner.
ginger salad.author: Wendy T.
ginger salad.review: I dream about Burmese Kitchen's tea leaf salad, ginger salad, spicy sliced bamboo and falafel soup. These dishes are authentic, flavorful, fresh and wonderful. We're vegetarian and love the variety of veggie dishes that aren't simply a meat dish made with tofu. The decor is simple and clean. The staff is friendly and helpful. We miss lunch at the Tenderloin location but love getting dinner at the new location -- easy parking and hardly any wait. A real winner.

excerpts: The samosa soup, combo fried platter, Golden tofu salad, and coconut rice are great.
I've gone twice now and had the same waitress each time, she's very helpful and kind.
The owners are also very kind and friendly.
The wife told me about how they make the golden tofu.
I will be coming here more often.
golden tofu salad.author: Dylan J.
golden tofu salad.review: Great food, lots of vegan options. Sent the menus of about 5 or 6 Burmese restaurants in SF to my Burmese friend and he says this has the most authentic range of options, and there's a lot of them. The tea leaf salad sounded bad to me but it was great. The samosa soup, combo fried platter, Golden tofu salad, and coconut rice are great. I've gone twice now and had the same waitress each time, she's very helpful and kind. The owners are also very kind and friendly. The wife told me about how they make the golden tofu. I will be coming here more often.

excerpts: If I could only eat one food forevermore, it would be the golden tofu salad from Burmese Kitchen!
So fresh and delicious.
(It's chickpea tofu, not soy tofu).
They have the best coconut rice.
They are super nice as well.
We came in 15 minutes before close and they served us no problem.
Wish I lived closer, I would go all the time.
golden tofu salad.author: D R.
golden tofu salad.review: If I could only eat one food forevermore, it would be the golden tofu salad from Burmese Kitchen! So fresh and delicious. (It's chickpea tofu, not soy tofu). They have the best coconut rice. They are super nice as well. We came in 15 minutes before close and they served us no problem. Wish I lived closer, I would go all the time.

excerpts:
My current favorites: 
Tofu Thok (Golden Tofu Salad)
golden tofu salad.author: Kevin C.
golden tofu salad.review:
My current favorites: 
Tofu Thok (Golden Tofu Salad) 
Moh Hinga Fish Chowder
Pork with Pickled Mango
Kyat Tha Dan Pauk (Chicken Biryani)
Burmese Milk Tea
Tapioca Dessert

Trust me, this place is legit. My parents were both born and raised in Burma, and we've been twice this week. And they are well aware that Burma Superstar, Mandalay and Pagan are close by. We'll definitely be back soon to try more items.

Also, the owners are splendid - hella nice people. They make every visit a joy.

excerpts: We especially love the Golden Tofu Salad, which is unlike anything we'd ever tried before.
Not to be confused with standard tofu made from soybeans, this tofu is made in house from yellow beans.
I'm not sure what goes into the salad (fried onions, definitely) but it is so rich and tasty
I could easily eat it every day.
golden tofu salad.author: E. K.
golden tofu salad.review:
We have been going to Burmese Kitchen since it opened at its previous location on Larkin Street and have come to prefer it to some of the other popular Burmese restaurants in San Francisco because we find the food to be really exceptional and unique. It's also great that you don't have to wait in line for an hour! If you're a vegetarian you will be very satisfied by the options at Burmese Kitchen: Vegetarian food doesn't get more delicious and nutritious than this! We especially love the Golden Tofu Salad, which is unlike anything we'd ever tried before. Not to be confused with standard tofu made from soybeans, this tofu is made in house from yellow beans. I'm not sure what goes into the salad (fried onions, definitely) but it is so rich and tasty I could easily eat it every day. The tea leaf salad is amazing too (order the signature one for an extra generous helping of tea leaves), as is the tamarind salad, the samusas and the roti. If you eat seafood and enjoy spice you may like the spicy fish, fish soup with sour vegetables, or fish chowder (more mild). The pumpkin prawns are good too. Because my husband doesn't eat meat other than seafood, we haven't really tried many of the meat options, though some friends did order a chicken stew of some kind that they seemed to really enjoy. 
As a final note, we love the management here! They're always really kind and genuine and have been so friendly towards our young son, who is fast becoming a fan of Burmese cuisine. All in all, one of our very favorite restaurants in town!

excerpts: Our favorites are the tofu salad (chickpea tofu), pickled ginger salad, and tamarind leaf salad.
tamarind leaf salad.author: Alex M.
tamarind leaf salad.review: Best Burmese food in San Francisco. My girlfriend is Burmese from Shan state and attests that this is the most authentic in terms of menu and ingredients. It's also the only place that has authentic Burmese tea. We've eaten here many times and never been disappointed. Great selection of dishes for vegans and vegetarians (and meat lovers too). The salads are much better than Burma Superstar. Our favorites are the tofu salad (chickpea tofu), pickled ginger salad, and tamarind leaf salad.

excerpts: Bring a bottle of red and start off with their very own, Tamarind Leaf Salad.
You can't get this anywhere else.
We usually order the fish or coconut soup and a chicken curry dish with a side of coconut rice.
All of the above are excellent.
tamarind leaf salad.author: Sharon J.
tamarind leaf salad.review: Bring a bottle of red and start off with their very own, Tamarind Leaf Salad. You can't get this anywhere else. We usually order the fish or coconut soup and a chicken curry dish with a side of coconut rice. All of the above are excellent.

excerpts: Tamarind Leaf Salad - one of my favorite things to eat and hard to find anywhere - young tamarind leaves, onions, peanuts, and spices.
tamarind leaf salad.author: Henry W.
tamarind leaf salad.review:
After spending some time near the border of Burma for a couple of months, my standards for Burmese cuisine naturally became unrealistically high - preventing me from enjoying some of the Burmese food here in San Francisco. 

That is, until I discovered Burmese Kitchen.. 

Most of the food here is similar to what I had near the border of Burma - very homey, comfort food with bold, spicy flavors. 

The best thing here is the Tamarind Fish with onion/garlic combined with Coconut Rice. The coconut rice is here is just amazing - it has a strong coconut scent and flavor which pairs well with almost all the dishes here, especially the Tamarind Fish. The Tamarind fish is a white fish fillet covered with a tamarind/onion/garlic puree. It's perfectly sweet, sour, and salty with a little spicy kick to it. 

Close runner ups:
Tamarind Leaf Salad - one of my favorite things to eat and hard to find anywhere - young tamarind leaves, onions, peanuts, and spices. It has that nice crunch and sweet/sourness that is so prevalent in Burmese food.

Tea Leaf Salad - your standard Tea Leaf salad that's in all Burmese restaurants. I find theirs to be less salty than the rest of the field, which is a good thing.

Garlic Chicken - cooked with turmeric, lemongrass, minced garlic, bell pepper, & onion, the chicken is super tender and flavorful. Tastes great along with coconut rice. 

I love how this place has the local family feel rather than the trussed up western fusion feel. Also, prices are reasonable compared to some other more popular Burmese places.

excerpts: First off, this is the only place I know of that has tamarind leaf salad.
I love tea leaf salad, but their tamarind leaf salad is a notch above.
The soups and the stews are fantastic; the sauerkraut pork is the one I always go back to.
tamarind leaf salad.author: Les P.
tamarind leaf salad.review:
Probably my favorite restaurant in the city. They've been great since their prior location in the Tenderloin, but I feel like they've gotten even better at their new Geary spot. Their dishes are generally more varied and delicious than at other nearby Burmese establishments.

First off, this is the only place I know of that has tamarind leaf salad. I love tea leaf salad, but their tamarind leaf salad is a notch above. The soups and the stews are fantastic; the sauerkraut pork is the one I always go back to. But I try something new every time and they never disappoint.

The prices are extremely reasonable too, for what you are eating. I would call it $$$ food at a $ price.

excerpts: We had the Roti, Tamarind leaf salad, tamarind fish and coconut chicken noodle soup.
All delicious.
The table next to us had a huge plate of biriani that looked really tasty.
I need to come back!
Prices are very reasonable and beers are $3.50.
There's wine by the glass for $6 but it isn't very good.
The service is well intentioned but forgetful.
We had to remind them about what we ordered and they forgot a few things.
But it was a busy Friday night and there was a big table of 8 having a birthday.
tamarind leaf salad.author: Priscilla C.
tamarind leaf salad.review: Great food!  Bustling little pop up with spotty service but forgivable because of it's mom and pop feeling. This was the first Burmese food I've had that actually reminded me of the food I had in Myanmar. The salads are not as pretty as Burma Superstar but taste more authentic. We had the Roti, Tamarind leaf salad, tamarind fish and coconut chicken noodle soup. All delicious. The table next to us had a huge plate of biriani that looked really tasty. I need to come back!  Prices are very reasonable and beers are $3.50. There's wine by the glass for $6 but it isn't very good.  The service is well intentioned but forgetful. We had to remind them about what we ordered and they forgot a few things. But it was a busy Friday night and there was a big table of 8 having a birthday.

excerpts: BK style signature tea leaf salad - comparable to Burma Superstar, but without the crunchy romaine lettuce.

I like the Burma Superstar one better but this one is still good =)
--
Samusa soup (
oh man, it comes with their version of a falafel too.

SO GOOD)
--
Coconut rice (just a side, but so simple and so good)
bk style signature tea leaf salad.author: Emily C.
bk style signature tea leaf salad.review:
Great alternate Burmese option when Burma Superstar or Mandalay is just too busy and B Star doesn't hit the spot. Portion, price, quality all comparable =) and service is much faster than the aforementioned places since it is smaller/less busy.

Got quite a few dishes to share between 5 of us and here were my standouts (did not dislike anything!)

-- BK style signature tea leaf salad - comparable to Burma Superstar, but without the crunchy romaine lettuce. I like the Burma Superstar one better but this one is still good =)
-- Samusa soup (oh man, it comes with their version of a falafel too. SO GOOD)
-- Coconut rice (just a side, but so simple and so good)

excerpts: roasted ginger chicken was not roasted.
Think stewed and kind of greasy.
-tamarind fish didnt taste like tamarind.
It was boring.
Tamarind is not boring;  this should have been good.
-the
waiter was sort of a doosh.
In an empty restaurant he sat a couple in the worst seat in the place.
Really?
Not us, thankfully ( I would have protested.)
Also, he kept refilling husband's water, but not mine.
Weird.
As each dish came to the table he presented it to husband as if it were a fine bottle of wine.....sort of strange.
Waaaay strange, actually.
Maybe he had a little man-crush?
Or maybe he figured husband was most likely to be the bill payer
so he was sucking up?
roasted ginger chicken.author: El B.
roasted ginger chicken.review:
Husband says this is what Burmese food tastes like in a Burmese rest home. Could be that we just didn't order well, and we've only been the one time, so...? I would go back if a friend really wanted to eat here, but it certainly wouldn't be my first choice in this neighborhood filled with really good food. 

The good things:
-nice interior. Not really fancy ( example: paper plate 'sculpture' thing on the wall) but comfortable, pretty and clean. 
-tea leaf salad. Husband likes Burma Superstar and Mandalay's better, but I thought it was pretty good. I would get it again.
-cocnut rice. It was not at all soggy with just a hint of coconut. I liked it.
-not expensive. We ate dinner for about $30. 

The not that great things:
-the bathroom needs help. Not disgusting, and nothing stored there, but seriously not nice.
-the roasted ginger chicken was not roasted. Think stewed and kind of greasy.
-tamarind fish didnt taste like tamarind. It was boring. Tamarind is not boring;  this should have been good.
-the waiter was sort of a doosh. In an empty restaurant he sat a couple in the worst seat in the place. Really? Not us, thankfully ( I would have protested.) Also, he kept refilling husband's water, but not mine. Weird. As each dish came to the table he presented it to husband as if it were a fine bottle of wine.....sort of strange. Waaaay strange, actually. Maybe he had a little man-crush? Or maybe he figured husband was most likely to be the bill payer so he was sucking up? Who knows, but it was creepy.


Ok well husband just went to brush his teeth to get the taste of the ginger chicken out of his mouth, and then he's going to pour us some wine. I hope he presents the bottle to me for approval before he pours.

excerpts:
We had the following:

- tea leaf salad
- roasted ginger chicken
- basa fish fillet in tamarind sauce

Overall, both the service and meal were quite good, especially the tea leaf salad.
roasted ginger chicken.author: Ty L.
roasted ginger chicken.review:
This space is a bit bittersweet to me since my favorite Korean place, To Hyang, used to occupy this space. Although I'm sad that they're no longer here, I am happy to see that another family run establishment has taken it's place. That aside, on to the review!

I really like this place even though I didn't get to try out as many dishes as I wanted. There were only two of us and so we could only order so much. We had the following:

- tea leaf salad
- roasted ginger chicken
- basa fish fillet in tamarind sauce

Overall, both the service and meal were quite good, especially the tea leaf salad. I kept seeing people around me getting the noodle dishes, so I'll definitely have to try that out next time. 

Lastly, given the proximity to B Star and Burma Superstar, for quality, authenticity, and price, I'd definitely recommend this place over the former. So do yourself a favor, give them a shot! :D

excerpts: We ordered the tea leaf salad, mohinga fish chowder soup, beef lemongrass curry, string beans, and coconut rice.
We enjoyed all of the dishes, especially the tea leaf salad.
I appreciate how the coconut rice doesn't have that artificial coconut flavor.
The monhinga soup was something different- curry soup base, noodles, cracker w/
split peas on top.
fish chowder.author: Joanna L.
fish chowder.review:
Skip the long lines at Burma and come here. 

We ordered the tea leaf salad, mohinga fish chowder soup, beef lemongrass curry, string beans, and coconut rice. We enjoyed all of the dishes, especially the tea leaf salad. I appreciate how the coconut rice doesn't have that artificial coconut flavor. The monhinga soup was something different- curry soup base, noodles, cracker w/ split peas on top. The string beans didn't have too much oil.

The restaurant decor is nice, yet the bathroom in back is dingy. Friendly service though and reasonable prices. I recommend.

excerpts: Next we had the Moh hinga fish chowder which is my favorite Burmese dish and I enjoyed theirs very much.
It had a little hint of spicyness to it
fish chowder.author: Linz C.
fish chowder.review:
I drove by this place the other day was like whaaaaat another Burmese restaurant? I must try. My parents and I came here for a late lunch and the restaurant was fairly empty. Service was great, the owner was there to chat with us and give us recommendations, very nice. 

We started off with a tea leaf salad, pretty small, and slightly different from others I've tried. Theirs was mixed with cabbage and had edamame in it. It was just ok, a little bit salty. I thought there was too much tea leaf and nuts, and not enough cabbage. 

Next we had the Moh hinga fish chowder which is my favorite Burmese dish and I enjoyed theirs very much. It had a little hint of spicyness to it and I love the crunchy lentils. 

The pumpkin pork dish was my favorite! The pork was very tender and moist and the kabocha was delicious! I could eat it everyday. The lemongrass beef however was very dry and I didn't expect it to be so saucy but it was almost like a curry dish. 

For dessert we had the semolina cake which sounded really weird but surprisingly we enjoyed it. It tastes sweet/coconut-y and just dissolves in your mouth. 

Will be back to try more of their menu!

excerpts: I also tried the fish chowder.
It was also good.
It was flavorful and had a nice crunchy texture to it.
I also like the fried appetizer combination and their semolina dessert.
I also visited this place at it's old location on Larkin Street.
Their food is still very good.
fish chowder.author: Hiroshi K.
fish chowder.review: This is a nice small Burmese restaurant.  It is clean.  The staff is very friendly.  The food is very good. I tried the Tea Leaf salad, it was really good.  It tasted fresh and it was full of flavor. It was a savory salad that had a slightly bitter flavor.  It was refreshing. I also tried the fish chowder. It was also good. It was flavorful and had a nice crunchy texture to it.  I also like the fried appetizer combination and their semolina dessert.  I also visited this place at it's old location on Larkin Street.
