Their food is still very good.

excerpts: The fish chowder is pretty good too.
fish chowder.author: Joseph L.
fish chowder.review:
Solid garlic noodle. The fish chowder is pretty good too. It's also not as crowded as the other Burmese places in town.

Tip: you can order delivery from them right on Yelp!

excerpts: This place has excellent Mo Hingah (fish chowder).
Good curry roti too.
fish chowder.author: Winston C.
fish chowder.review: My family is Burmese. I grew up with good home cooked Burmese food. This place has excellent Mo Hingah (fish chowder). Good curry roti too.

excerpts: We got the signature tea leaf salad, fish chowder and lemongrass beef.
All three dishes were flavorful and not very pricey, especially compared to the other local sf Burmese restaurants.
fish chowder.author: Julie H.
fish chowder.review: We dropped by for a quick meal after Ft Funston and were really pleased. We got the signature tea leaf salad, fish chowder and lemongrass beef. All three dishes were flavorful and not very pricey, especially compared to the other local sf Burmese restaurants.

excerpts: Also, they offer an amazing Mo-Hing-Ya (Burmese style fish chowder) ...
Way way much better than B Star as well.
,, people plz don't wait an hour for B Star.
Come here!!
fish chowder.author: Rachel T.
fish chowder.review: I'm the big fan of Burmese foods and I have to tell you guys that this restaurant is way much better than Burma Superstar on Clement St.   Focusing on the foods, Burmese Kitchen offers you a great chicken and beef biryani, many great curry which its meat is not cooked too well-done or too harsh (compare to B Star). Also, they offer an amazing Mo-Hing-Ya (Burmese style fish chowder) ... Way way much better than B Star as well. ....,, people plz don't wait an hour for B Star. Come here!!

excerpts: The fish chowder was bland and comes w/
a lot of nuts.
The chicken curry was bland and you'll have to order rice separately cause it doesn't come with any.
fish chowder.author: Lucy C.
fish chowder.review:
Came here excited to try this place out thinking it would be good given that it's in a close vicinity with a few good Burmese restaurants in the area, but apparently that is not the case. 

The food here is very bland and disappointing ! The potato curry was very watery and bland w/ little curry taste. The fish chowder was bland and comes w/ a lot of nuts. The chicken curry was bland and you'll have to order rice separately cause it doesn't come with any. Lastly, the Burmese fried rice is just plain rice with nothing in it, no meat or veggies. 

Even though the food was bad you would hope for good service to at least off-set the disappointment. Unfortunately the servers here very bad as well, it's so hard to flag any of the two servers in this very tiny restaurant.  When I was dining there, coincidentally friends of the servers were dining there as well. They neglected all the other patrons except their friends especially the guy in the red shirt. He was constantly checking up on his friends to see if they liked the food.  One more thing to mention about him is that he was constantly touching and scratching his pimply face then serving your food......................

excerpts: Mohinga - fish chowder - A very hearty soup dish that can be eaten as a main dish or shared between 3-4 people.
fish chowder.author: Roxanne K.
fish chowder.review:
Disclaimer: My husband's relatives own this restaurant, but my review is as unbiased as can be!

I usually am wary about going to a newly opened restaurant because they still have some kinks to work out, but this was different.  Yes, they were a fully functioning and awesome restaurant before their move, but OMG has it gotten so much better!  Everything tastes fresher.

Roti & potato curry - I LOVE THIS DISH.  My only wish is that they serve it with more roti, but that can be easily solved by ordering 2! :)

Tea leaf salad - When we've ordered this at the old location, it was good.  But when we ordered it this time, the flavors seemed to be brighter, fresher, fuller.  Normally when we would take friends to their previous location, we'd get this just because it is a Burmese staple, but now, I can confidently say that this is THE BEST tea leaf salad I've ever had in the bay area!

Mohinga - fish chowder - A very hearty soup dish that can be eaten as a main dish or shared between 3-4 people.

Dan Pauk - biryani chicken - My hubby's favorite and this was no exception.  The rice is cooked to perfection and the chicken  wonderfully seasoned with curry and other spices.

Spicy fish - The fish is lightly fried and served with a chili/garlic sauce. If you can't handle the heat though, maybe skip this or be sure the rest of your group can.  Hehe.

Chicken curry - can't go wrong with chicken curry!

Coconut rice - This pairs so well with the chicken curry. If you like coconut milk, this is a must try! Don't be afraid, it's not too sweet.  It's a light flavor of coconut milk that's slightly toasted/nutty.

Service is great.  Attentive staff without being overbearing.  Parking is a bit tough, but honestly, this restaurant is well worth the walk and wait.  However, I think the neighborhood is a step up from their last location.  Give Burmese Kitchen a chance!  You won't be disappointed!

excerpts: we ordered fish chowder and then garlic noodles.
both very good.
the good thing about it is that it is not salty at all.
fish chowder.author: Shuting Z.
fish chowder.review:
I love this place's aura.  simple, burmese and clean.  we ordered fish chowder and then garlic noodles.  both very good.    the good thing about it is that it is not salty at all. tastes very healthy.

I also tried their Burmese milk tea, which used evaporated milk and has an interesting and good dry flavor.

excerpts:
Moh Hinga Fish Chowder
Pork with Pickled Mango
Kyat Tha Dan Pauk (Chicken Biryani)
Burmese
Milk Tea
fish chowder.author: Kevin C.
fish chowder.review:
My current favorites: 
Tofu Thok (Golden Tofu Salad) 
Moh Hinga Fish Chowder
Pork with Pickled Mango
Kyat Tha Dan Pauk (Chicken Biryani)
Burmese Milk Tea
Tapioca Dessert

Trust me, this place is legit. My parents were both born and raised in Burma, and we've been twice this week. And they are well aware that Burma Superstar, Mandalay and Pagan are close by. We'll definitely be back soon to try more items.

Also, the owners are splendid - hella nice people. They make every visit a joy.

excerpts: Fish chowder was delicious, everything was really good.
Could not have found a better place in San Francisco.
fish chowder.author: Erik Y.
fish chowder.review: The best Burmese restaurant in town. The tea leaf salad is the best. Fish chowder was delicious, everything was really good. Could not have found a better place in San Francisco.

excerpts: The fish chowder was delicious, was spicier than I had anticipated it would be, but was still manageable.
We also ordered the lady fingers (okra), which was a nice veggie dish.
Overall, this place was a pretty good Burmese restaurant - definitely a place to try if you'd like to try Burmese food and avoid the long line at Burma Superstar.
fish chowder.author: Kyle S.
fish chowder.review: I absolutely love Burmese tea leaf salads, so it was a must-order dish for me. They have 2 different types of tea leaf salad, a regular tea leaf salad and the signature tea leaf salad that comes with more fermented tea leaves. I recommend ordering the signature tea leaf salad. It was definitely delicious, but the only thing was that it was a small portion. We ended up having to order 2 of them to have enough for 3 people. The fish chowder was delicious, was spicier than I had anticipated it would be, but was still manageable. We also ordered the lady fingers (okra), which was a nice veggie dish. Overall, this place was a pretty good Burmese restaurant - definitely a place to try if you'd like to try Burmese food and avoid the long line at Burma Superstar.

excerpts: Choice of soup: fish chowder, samosa soup, or chicken coconut noodle soup.
fish chowder.author: Kaykay K.
fish chowder.review:
We went for lunch. Reasonably priced. Good portions. My husband ordered the "Meatlover" lunch plate: a choice of 1 meat dish, and 1 vegetable dish for $11 including steamed rice. Add $1 for coconut rice, brown rice, fried rice or biryani rice.  He chose the pork with pickled mango, pumpkin stew, and biryani rice - all for $12. (Their lunch menu is posted online).

I ordered the Soup and Salad for $12. Choice of soup: fish chowder, samosa soup, or chicken coconut noodle soup. Choice of salad: tea leaf or ginger salad. The salad was small but sufficient. The chicken coconut noodle soup was good and filled me, and I left satisfied.

The owner was very friendly. He said he was testing out the lunch hours. So far it has been slow at lunch, but busy at dinnertime. If lunch remains slow, he may close for lunch and offer only dinner hours.  So folks, come on down.  Keep this place open at lunchtime, please!

excerpts: If you eat seafood and enjoy spice you may like the spicy fish, fish soup with sour vegetables, or fish chowder (more mild).
The pumpkin prawns are good too.
Because my husband doesn't eat meat other than seafood, we haven't really tried many of the meat options, though some friends did order a chicken stew of some kind that they seemed to really enjoy.
As a final note, we love the management here!
They're always really kind and genuine and have been so friendly towards our young son, who is fast becoming a fan of Burmese cuisine.
All in all, one of our very favorite restaurants in town!
fish chowder.author: E. K.
fish chowder.review:
We have been going to Burmese Kitchen since it opened at its previous location on Larkin Street and have come to prefer it to some of the other popular Burmese restaurants in San Francisco because we find the food to be really exceptional and unique. It's also great that you don't have to wait in line for an hour! If you're a vegetarian you will be very satisfied by the options at Burmese Kitchen: Vegetarian food doesn't get more delicious and nutritious than this! We especially love the Golden Tofu Salad, which is unlike anything we'd ever tried before. Not to be confused with standard tofu made from soybeans, this tofu is made in house from yellow beans. I'm not sure what goes into the salad (fried onions, definitely) but it is so rich and tasty I could easily eat it every day. The tea leaf salad is amazing too (order the signature one for an extra generous helping of tea leaves), as is the tamarind salad, the samusas and the roti. If you eat seafood and enjoy spice you may like the spicy fish, fish soup with sour vegetables, or fish chowder (more mild). The pumpkin prawns are good too. Because my husband doesn't eat meat other than seafood, we haven't really tried many of the meat options, though some friends did order a chicken stew of some kind that they seemed to really enjoy. 
As a final note, we love the management here! They're always really kind and genuine and have been so friendly towards our young son, who is fast becoming a fan of Burmese cuisine. All in all, one of our very favorite restaurants in town!

excerpts: We had garlic noodles, golden tofu, and the fish chowder, and they were mostly bland.
fish chowder.author: daphne w.
fish chowder.review:
We had garlic noodles, golden tofu, and the fish chowder, and they were mostly bland.  We ate only a little of the tofu and didn't even bother taking the rest home.

Came in at lunch time, only 1 other table was occupied, and the another person waiting for take out.  Still the service was slow.  We sat for 5 minutes and had to ask for glasses of water.

A bit of disappointment, but luckily there's still Mandalay and Burma Superstar in the 'hood.

excerpts: so I had to order the more traditional dishes like Mo Hing Nga (fish chowder noodle soup),
Ching Maw Jaw (shrimp and sour leaves), curry chicken, kow soy dok (noodle dish)...
We were impressed, especially with the fish chowder noodle soup and flavorful curry chicken!
We'll be going back to try other dishes.
We ordered the Balachan/Malachan to go.
This tastes so good just over plain rice!
There were eight of us.
The service was friendly and efficient.
Go check it out!
fish chowder.author: A L.
fish chowder.review:
I've always wanted to try this restaurant but never made it to the Larkin location, so I was thrilled to see it open in my neighborhood. 
My family's from Burma so I had to order the more traditional dishes like Mo Hing Nga (fish chowder noodle soup), Ching Maw Jaw (shrimp and sour leaves), curry chicken, kow soy dok (noodle dish)... We were impressed, especially with the fish chowder noodle soup and flavorful curry chicken! We'll be going back to try other dishes. We ordered the Balachan/Malachan to go. This tastes so good just over plain rice! 
There were eight of us. The service was friendly and efficient. Go check it out!

excerpts: Ong Noh Kau Swel (coconut chicken soup egg noodle, diced chicken in coconut broth, fried split peas, and hard boil egg, $9.50):
An outstandingly balanced coconut soup--just the right amount of coconut without being too creamy.
coconut chicken soup.author: Edna C.
coconut chicken soup.review:
Every time I try a new Burmese place, I find a new favorite... I guess it's an inevitable paradox when Burmese food is so good and each place stands out so distinctively!

(+++) B.K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad (homestyle with extra fermented tea leaf, fried garlic, sesame seeds, shredded cabbage, assorted peas & peanuts, $9.75): Frankly I'm not sure if the extra $2 is worth it over the regular tea leaf salad; I was just enticed by the name. It is definitely one of the most flavorful tea leaf salads I've ever had--pungently aromatic tea leaf, blended into multidimensional character with the assorted peas, topped with a flamboyant coating of sesame seeds. It comes already mixed so it may look as good as other restaurants where all the ingredients are presented in little piles, but the taste is exquisitely exotic.

(++) Ong Noh Kau Swel (coconut chicken soup egg noodle, diced chicken in coconut broth, fried split peas, and hard boil egg, $9.50): An outstandingly balanced coconut soup--just the right amount of coconut without being too creamy. It could have used more chicken, but the soft noodles and overall composition of comforting ingredients essentially make this fancy chicken noodle soup.

(++) Pork Curry (Pork with pureed onion, garlic, mustard seeds & spices, $8.50): The slow-cooked tender pork and housemade blend of curry make this memorable despite its plain name and presentation. I really like how the curry is vegetable based so it's satisfying but light.

Compared to other Burmese places Burmese Kitchen is a little more more hole-in-the-wall, and by hole-in-the-wall, I just mean in size and fame. It's a smaller place and not as frequently discussed as Burma Superstar or Mandalay, but nonetheless a nice restaurant with a relaxing and refined ambiance (though they could do away with the collage of painted paper plates).

excerpts: We got the tea leaf salad, coconut chicken soup, spicy fish, chicken curry, and chin baung jaw shrimp & sour leaf.
If this isn't highlighted enough in the other reviews, the tea leaf salad was AMAZING!
I was extremely impressed how fresh the leaves were and how flavorful the marinate was.
We only ordered one dish for the four of us
and it wasn't enough.
Coconut chicken soup is probably one of my favorite burmese dishes because it's almost at every family party I've been to
so my relatives get a lot of practice making it.
While it was still pretty good at Burmese kitchen, I wasn't mind blown.
But again, it's hard for me to judge.
tldr; The must haves are the tea leaf salad and coconut rice with chicken (and spicy fish if you can handle heat).
If you want to try something more unique to Burmese culture try the coconut chicken soup but stay safe and if you're adventurous the chin baung jaw.
coconut chicken soup.author: Edric K.
coconut chicken soup.review:
I'm pretty picky when it comes to Burmese food.  Both of my parents are from Burma and are pretty active in the Burmese community in the Bay Area so I'm always skeptical when it comes to Burmese food.  The first and last restaurant I went to was Rangoon Ruby in Palo Alto and was fairly unimpressed in terms of quality per dollar. So I went to Burmese Kitchen with low expectations and had them shattered.

I went with three of my friends and decided to order family style.  We got the tea leaf salad, coconut chicken soup, spicy fish, chicken curry, and chin baung jaw shrimp & sour leaf.

If this isn't highlighted enough in the other reviews, the tea leaf salad was AMAZING!  I was extremely impressed how fresh the leaves were and how flavorful the marinate was.  We only ordered one dish for the four of us and it wasn't enough.  I'd recommend 1 for every 2 people unless you plan on filling up with a variety of dishes.

Coconut chicken soup is probably one of my favorite burmese dishes because it's almost at every family party I've been to so my relatives get a lot of practice making it.  While it was still pretty good at Burmese kitchen, I wasn't mind blown.  But again, it's hard for me to judge. I think it's worth trying if you haven't had it before.

We had the spicy fish and chicken curry with coconut rice and I'd HIGHLY RECOMMEND you do the same!  This is definitely a dish I'd get the next time I come here.  The chicken was very tender and would fall off the bone and paired perfectly with the rice.  The fish was a little too hot for someone in our group, but if you're fine with spicy food it was this is also a must!

If you're looking for something uniquely Burmese, I'd give the chin baung jaw shrimp & sour leaf a try.  Admittedly it was a little weird for two of my friends since sour food isn't really popular in most cultures but if you want to be adventurous I think this is definitely something different.

tldr; The must haves are the tea leaf salad and coconut rice with chicken (and spicy fish if you can handle heat).  
If you want to try something more unique to Burmese culture try the coconut chicken soup but stay safe and if you're adventurous the chin baung jaw.

excerpts: Coconut chicken soup, tea leaf salad of course and lemongrass beef.
Burmese iced coffee is more on the light watery side compared to a thai or Vietnamese iced coffee.
Really friendly service.
To prevent wait time makes reservation
coconut chicken soup.author: Juliana L.
coconut chicken soup.review: Great food! Coconut chicken soup, tea leaf salad of course and lemongrass beef. Burmese iced coffee is more on the light watery side compared to a thai or Vietnamese iced coffee. Really friendly service. To prevent wait time makes reservation

excerpts: At $10.95 the Rice Noodle Salad seemed like a plate of saucy mushy something that just was not at all appealing.
rice noodle salad.author: Caesar A.
rice noodle salad.review:
This really was not at all pleasing to any of my senses, judge for yourselves.

I thought I loved Burmese food until I tried the follow three dishes here. 

At $11.95 the Spicy Pork was nearly cremated. Overly marinated, dried out tough and chewy I couldn't even eat this.

At $10.95 the Rice Noodle Salad seemed like a plate of saucy mushy something that just was not at all appealing.  

And, at $9.95 the Vegan Fried Peas Salad was just not happening either. With may be some shredded cabbage, onion and slices of jalapeño I just didn't find this combination at all appealing.   

I'm at a loss for words here yet although this did not speak to me, you may feel differently.

excerpts:
tea leaf salad was really good but a little on the small side
rice noodle salad was really good, kind of peanut-y.
yum.
coconut curry chicken by far the best.
i could've eaten it for days with the coconut rice.
prawn with pumpkin curry (really butternut squash, not pumpkin) also really good
rice noodle salad.author: Sarah M.
rice noodle salad.review:
ive found my go-to burmese spot! i still love Mandalay, but its always very crowded, so i called this place and there was no wait 0.0 AND ITS SO GOOD WOW. burma superstar no more. the people working here are super nice, it feels like a homey family-run restaurant. 
tea leaf salad was really good but a little on the small side
rice noodle salad was really good, kind of peanut-y. yum.
coconut curry chicken by far the best. i could've eaten it for days with the coconut rice.
prawn with pumpkin curry (really butternut squash, not pumpkin) also really good

excerpts: Their iced tea, tea leaf salad, rainbow salad, potato curry - everything consistently tastes amazing.
You won't find a friendlier atmosphere or owner either.
I've eaten here at least once every couple weeks ever since I moved to the area.
Favorite restaurant around here, hands down.
rainbow salad.author: Tyler B.
rainbow salad.review: This place is the real deal. Their iced tea, tea leaf salad, rainbow salad, potato curry - everything consistently tastes amazing. You won't find a friendlier atmosphere or owner either. I've eaten here at least once every couple weeks ever since I moved to the area. Favorite restaurant around here, hands down.

excerpts: The Rainbow Salad is always a winner and the Fish with Tamarind Sauce and the Chicken Coconut Curry were delicious to share among two people.
This is definitely my go-to spot to satisfy my Burmese food cravings.
They also accept credit card.
rainbow salad.author: Grace L.
rainbow salad.review:
Burmese Kitchen should be all the hype in the Inner Richmond. They moved from the Tenderloin and this location is clean and intimate. There was no wait when we came during a week night and the prices here are so much more reasonable than Burma Superstar. The service is also quaint and kind.
The Rainbow Salad is always a winner and the Fish with Tamarind Sauce and the Chicken Coconut Curry were delicious to share among two people.
This is definitely my go-to spot to satisfy my Burmese food cravings. They also accept credit card.

excerpts: Rainbow Salad - so soggy and wet, not anything like the other rainbow salads I've had.
It's got the consistency of Pad Thai, and there was an off, unidentifiable taste even once getting past the consistency.
rainbow salad.author: Sarah B.
rainbow salad.review:
Got a few things delivered from here, wasn't impressed. Every Burmese experience I've had in the bay area has been amazing, until this one.

Rainbow Salad - so soggy and wet, not anything like the other rainbow salads I've had. It's got the consistency of Pad Thai, and there was an off, unidentifiable taste even once getting past the consistency. Yuck.

Samosa Soup - I haven't had this before but it had good reviews. The broth was good, and the cut-up samosa and accompaniments were good, but not great when mixed together.

Coconut rice - highlight of the meal. real yummy

Fried rice - terrible. not what I think of as fried rice at all. White rices with some chickpeas mixed in, and maybe butter. $2.50 should have tipped me off.

Fried appetizer combo - Samosas were really, really yummy. Fried tofu was okay, and falafel was incredibly dry and too spicy. And I like spicy.

And the sodas were delivered warm. C'mon, I'm not ordering the soda to put in the fridge for later, wanted to have it with the meal Really sorry I didn't like this place more, as it is only Burmese delivery in my area.

excerpts: We started with the Rainbow Salad and then went on to have an eggplant garlic entree and mixed vegetable curry entree with coconut rice - all super tasty and
the leftovers were very tasty as well!
The bill was very reasonable, especially for the quality!
We'll likely be back!
rainbow salad.author: Anne Y.
rainbow salad.review: I am surprised that this restaurant was empty on a Friday night, as we had a delicious dinner last night with great service. We started with the Rainbow Salad and then went on to have an eggplant garlic entree and mixed vegetable curry entree with coconut rice - all super tasty and the leftovers were very tasty as well! The bill was very reasonable, especially for the quality! We'll likely be back!

excerpts: We also tried the rainbow salad, it was different from other places.
Not bad
but it was wetter than I remembered.
It was delicious though.
We ordered the garlic chicken and the pork chana del for our entrees.
The garlic chicken had a lot of flavor and a nice little kick to it.
Chunks of tender breast meat with our cloves of garlic and lemon grass infused throughout the dish.
Pairs well with rice.
The pork chana del was very saucy and had a lot of yellow split peas and that dish goes well with rice also.
Even though the dishes looks small when it comes out, you will be stuffed!
We had leftovers for the next day.
It was such a pleasant surprise for this unassuming restaurant on busy Geary St.
Try it!
at least, no long lines for Burma Star.
rainbow salad.author: Alicia A.
rainbow salad.review: Was attracted by the fancy flashing lights next door for the spicy hot pot restaurant. Looked at the menu and wasn't feeling it. This was right next door, as we looked at the menu, the waiter gave us a take out menu to look at. We decided to give them a try as many of their dishes were gluten free and the hospitality of the waiter. There was only 1 other table besides us. Quaint and small eatery that produces some tasty and spicy dishes.  Started out with the tea leaf salad, it was tasty but too much chewing for my tastes. The dish contains a lot of assorted peas and peanuts, hence the chewing. We also tried the rainbow salad, it was different from other places. Not bad but it was wetter than I remembered. It was delicious though. We ordered the garlic chicken and the pork chana del for our entrees. The garlic chicken had a lot of flavor and a nice little kick to it. Chunks of tender breast meat with our cloves of garlic and lemon grass infused throughout the dish. Pairs well with rice. The pork chana del was very saucy and had a lot of yellow split peas and that dish goes well with rice also. Even though the dishes looks small when it comes out, you will be stuffed! We had leftovers for the next day.  It was such a pleasant surprise for this unassuming restaurant on busy Geary St. Try it! at least, no long lines for Burma Star.

excerpts: We always order the same things --- Rainbow salad, tea leaf salad, coconut noodle soup.
rainbow salad.author: Sai S.
rainbow salad.review:
We have ordered takeout about 10 times now. We always order the same things --- Rainbow salad, tea leaf salad, coconut noodle soup. 

I was going to get it four stars but I bumped it up to five stars because of two things. Consistency and speed. These items are consistently the same and consistently really good. They also make their food relatively quickly which is much appreciated for takeout. Combine that with reasonable prices and you get five stars from me!

excerpts: The rainbow salad, while full of flavors, lacked the synergy of flavors that I've come to expect (three and a half stars, I'd say).
The restaurant is small and the service is friendly and attentive.
I'd like to visit again to try the catfish chowder soup and nan gyi thohk.
rainbow salad.author: Tyrone V.
rainbow salad.review: I'd say Burmese Kitchen is closer to 4 and a half stars, but I'll round up for this review (pending future visits, of course). Chose Burmese Kitchen for a random Thursday lunch, due to the very reasonable entree prices (the lunch menu is a good deal). The tea leaf salad is currently the best I've had. The rainbow salad, while full of flavors, lacked the synergy of flavors that I've come to expect (three and a half stars, I'd say). The restaurant is small and the service is friendly and attentive. I'd like to visit again to try the catfish chowder soup and nan gyi thohk.

excerpts: Get some of their more interesting salads, like the ginger salad or the rainbow salad.
rainbow salad.author: Josh B.
rainbow salad.review:
Strongly recommended for lunch.  They have a set of lunch specials for $10 to $12 which should pretty much cover everyone's tastes.  

And really, BK is currently the best Burmese food in the city.  Definitely better than Superstar.  Get some of their more interesting salads, like the ginger salad or the rainbow salad.

excerpts: Everything was soggy from the rainbow salad to the tofu salad.
The eggplant and green beans were inedible, it tasted like it had been sitting under a heat lamp for hours.
Even the coconut rice was terrible.
Sorry Burmese Kitchen!
I don't like to write negative reviews but you've got a long way to go considering the neighboring competition.
rainbow salad.author: Sara K.
rainbow salad.review: We regularly frequent Mandalay, Pagan and Burma superstar.  I decided to give this place a chance since it's the only Burmese restaurant that delivers.  Huge disappointment! Everything was soggy from the rainbow salad to the tofu salad.  The eggplant and green beans were inedible, it tasted like it had been sitting under a heat lamp for hours.  Even the coconut rice was terrible.  Sorry Burmese Kitchen! I don't like to write negative reviews but you've got a long way to go considering the neighboring competition.

excerpts:
Masala Noodles:  
Good.
Papaya Salad: meh.
masala noodles.author: Max L.
masala noodles.review:
Just awful greasy, overcooked, small portioned food.

The naan: was so greasy you could squeeze it and fat would ooze out.  Also, only 1 naan per order (and no sauces).

Biryani Rice: not awful
Pumpkin Stew:  No curry flavor, just mushed pumpkin.
Fish with Tamarind Sauce:  DRY
Beef lemongrass:  SO dry.  Tasted like it was frozen and reheated or cooked for 5 days.
Roasted Ginger Pork: as above.
Masala Noodles:  Good.
Papaya Salad: meh.
Fried Samosa:  AWFUL.  The ratio of crust to filling is way off.  Too much crust.
BK Tea Leaf Salad:  Good.

ALL the dishes were way, way too small for the price.

All of this was delivered quickly though.

excerpts:
Pros: 
- Vegetarian friendly (although I must say the chicken masala noodles and spicy pork were awesome!)

- Great flavors and textures
- VERY reasonable prices--
all dishes less than $10.
We had 6 adults eat well for about $100, and had plenty of leftovers.
- The rice sides (coconut, biryani, Burmese fried) were tasty and a great buy for the volume at 2.50
masala noodles.author: Smita D.
masala noodles.review:
What a great find. 
- Cons: Parking may be tough, but if you are patient, you can find it. It is MUCH better than trying to park downtown. If you are willing to walk a block, parking is easy. 
- Small, but we made a reservation and surprisingly it was not packed. 

Pros: 
- Vegetarian friendly (although I must say the chicken masala noodles and spicy pork were awesome!)
- Great flavors and textures
- VERY reasonable prices-- all dishes less than $10. We had 6 adults eat well for about $100, and had plenty of leftovers.
- The rice sides (coconut, biryani, Burmese fried) were tasty and a great buy for the volume at 2.50 each
- Signature Tea Leaf Salad was awesome
- Service was prompt and they paid attention to us
- Burmese milk coffee was so tasty and hit the spot on a cold night with a long drive ahead.

Overall a great find and I will be back when I am in the area.

excerpts: I ordered the Chicken Masala noodles which were delicious with tons of flavor but not an overpowering amount.
The home Thai hot tea was a great choice to cleanse the pallet after each bite.
masala noodles.author: Melissa R.
masala noodles.review: Bermese kitchen had an excellent Tea leaf salad, enough to share for two people. I ordered the Chicken Masala noodles which were delicious with tons of flavor but not an overpowering amount. The home Thai hot tea was a great choice to cleanse the pallet after each bite.

excerpts: Roasted Ginger Pork: as above.
roasted ginger pork.author: Max L.
roasted ginger pork.review:
Just awful greasy, overcooked, small portioned food.

The naan: was so greasy you could squeeze it and fat would ooze out.  Also, only 1 naan per order (and no sauces).

Biryani Rice: not awful
Pumpkin Stew:  No curry flavor, just mushed pumpkin.
Fish with Tamarind Sauce:  DRY
Beef lemongrass:  SO dry.  Tasted like it was frozen and reheated or cooked for 5 days.
Roasted Ginger Pork: as above.
Masala Noodles:  Good.
Papaya Salad: meh.
Fried Samosa:  AWFUL.  The ratio of crust to filling is way off.  Too much crust.
BK Tea Leaf Salad:  Good.

ALL the dishes were way, way too small for the price.

All of this was delivered quickly though.

excerpts: Roasted ginger pork, chicken potato curry, and the tea leaf salad are some real good eats.
Husband and wife run the place, and they're both very personable.
They check on each customer to make sure they have a good meal.
I particularly like the thick, professional looking menus.
roasted ginger pork.author: Henry T.
roasted ginger pork.review: Good eats. We ordered a lot of food. My new obsession may now be coconut rice. Wow! I could inhale bowls of that stuff. Roasted ginger pork, chicken potato curry, and the tea leaf salad are some real good eats. Husband and wife run the place, and they're both very personable. They check on each customer to make sure they have a good meal. I particularly like the thick, professional looking menus.

excerpts: My wife had the coconut noodle soup; I had the roasted ginger pork with steamed rice.
Both were tremendous - cooked perfectly with good ingredients and presented well and promptly.
Nothing on the menu was overpriced and the restaurant interior was small but very clean and bright.
Overall, a wonderful experience.
roasted ginger pork.author: Dan K.
roasted ginger pork.review: So, full disclosure up front - neither I nor my wife are Burmese, nor are we particularly familiar with Burmese cuisine. That being said, this was one of the better meals we've had lately. My wife had the coconut noodle soup; I had the roasted ginger pork with steamed rice. Both were tremendous - cooked perfectly with good ingredients and presented well and promptly. Nothing on the menu was overpriced and the restaurant interior was small but very clean and bright. Overall, a wonderful experience.

excerpts: My personal favorite is pork with dal.
I get it every single time and change out the other entrees.
Burmese Kitchen has become my first stop any time someone from out of town visits me in the Richmond.
pork with dal.author: Nick C.
pork with dal.review:
Burmese Kitchen is possibly the greatest restaurant in San Francisco. Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence, so here's why.

Burmese food is unique, but not too weird. It's different enough to be refreshing but familiar enough to be comforting.

It's reasonably priced. The entrees are around 10 bucks and can be shared if you both get rice. IMPORTANT: get the coconut rice. It blew away all my expectations about how tasty something as simple as rice can be.

The interior isn't too fancy, but it's clean. Very appropriate for a casual date. (They also serve drinks.)

There's usually not a line. This is so important to me. When I want to eat, I want to eat.

Service is prompt and friendly. The son that's pretty much always working there is cool.

It's family owned so you feel like you're supporting the neighborhood.

There are plenty of veggie and gluten free options. Everyone raves about the tea leaf salad. I had been to the restaurant 4 or 5 times before actually trying it. It's tasty, but there's so much more to the restaurant than the salad!

My personal favorite is pork with dal. I get it every single time and change out the other entrees. Burmese Kitchen has become my first stop any time someone from out of town visits me in the Richmond.

excerpts: Pork with pickled mango a bit bizarre but definitely interesting.
Plus the pork was super tender.
Again, it felt a certain version of Indian.
pork with pickled mango.author: Victoria E.
pork with pickled mango.review:
Hungry after a nap on a Saturday afternoon. Needed food. Burma Superstar is a bit too far to walk and I often try to avoid the cliched Clement Street anyhow. Our sushi place on Arguello is closed for a week (what?!), Cha Cha Cha is a bit far to walk and probably too crowded. In situations like this, Yelp came to the rescue. I've read about this place, it's a respectful walk of 0.5 miles from the nap joint. Decided to take a walk and give this place a swirl. Is it different from Burma Superstar and Mandalay? I wondered.

It has a lot of Indian influence. Whereas Madalay on California and 6th is more Chinese influenced. Try to avoid Burma Superstar whenever I can as I don't like waiting in line. Wiki'ed Burmese cuisine and I understood its food are influenced by both, as they boarder both countries. Tea leaf salad is great. Very protein rich even though it is vegetarian. There were a lot of different type of nuts. Most unusual is the sprouted beans. Pork with pickled mango a bit bizarre but definitely interesting. Plus the pork was super tender. Again, it felt a certain version of Indian. Coconut rice was however very fluffy and more southeast Asian.

Burmese coffee was mellow with a hint of sweetness to it (tell your wait staff to not put too much sugar or condensed milk in it). 

There are a number of other things I'd try off the menu. It's a good way to give your body enough of a jolt to start the evening. 

We took our time to eat and then exited the restaurant as people started to drizzle in. The wind had picked up. You can hear the fog horn from afar. the sun had gone back into the cloud. A very quiet Saturday afternoon in this quiet Inner Richmond neighborhood. It's hard to imagine how many restaurants are within one mile radius from where we were.  I felt happy and content once again. This place serves yummy food. A keeper.

excerpts: Favorites are tea leaf salad, pork with pickled mango and coconut curry chicken noodle soup.
Texture and flavors are spot on!
pork with pickled mango.author: Jessica S.
pork with pickled mango.review:
Unassuming restaurant but delicious Burmese food and friendly service. I've tried all the Burmese restaurants in SF and this is the best and most authentic (my Dad is from Burma). Skip the lines at Burma Superstar or the attitude of Mandalay. Just eat at Burmese Kitchen!

Favorites are tea leaf salad, pork with pickled mango and coconut curry chicken noodle soup. Texture and flavors are spot on!

excerpts:
We ordered:

Roti and Potato curry
Tea leaf salad
Tamarind spicy fish
Green beans
Pork with pickled mango
(Except the tea leaf salad, very small portion size).
pork with pickled mango.author: Foodlover B.
pork with pickled mango.review:
Four of us arrived lunch today, a Saturday, and had the place to ourselves.

We ordered:

Roti and Potato curry
Tea leaf salad
Tamarind spicy fish
Green beans
Pork with pickled mango

Everything was very good.  The tab was $54. Portions were generous. (Except the tea leaf salad, very small portion size).

 It's close to a 38 muni.

It's much nicer vs their old place in the tenderloin. It's decorated very pretty and so much cleaner. We had been to their old place 4-5 times but it got too gross for us. I'm glad they moved!

excerpts:
We got:
- tea leaf salad
- samosa soup
- roti and potato curry
- chicken and potato curry
- pork with pickled mango
- lemongrass beef
- spicy fish
- garlic rice stick with chicken
- mixed vegetable curry
- ladyfingers (okra)
- coconut rice
pork with pickled mango.author: Kris K.
pork with pickled mango.review:
Great Burmese spot that's super cheap and easy to get into. Maybe slightly smaller portions than Mandalay or Burma Superstar, but a little cheaper, and just about as good. Comparably good to Burma Love, but less than half the price. A little more out of the way, especially compared to their previous Civic Center location, but well worth the trip. We had no trouble getting a table for 8 at 7pm on a Saturday. 

We got:
- tea leaf salad
- samosa soup
- roti and potato curry
- chicken and potato curry
- pork with pickled mango
- lemongrass beef
- spicy fish
- garlic rice stick with chicken
- mixed vegetable curry
- ladyfingers (okra)
- coconut rice

Everything was pretty solid - the lemongrass beef, spicy fish, and appetizers were all big hits, and vegetable curry well liked too. It came out to less than $18/head, for quite the feast. Great service too, water was refilled pretty frequently, despite it only being one woman running the place. Several among the group had not had Burmese before and were big fans. 

Will happily return and it'll be another alternative to Burma Superstar for less wait, along with Mandalay.

excerpts: For our main entrees we had the pork with pickled mango, garlic noodles and coconut rice.
The pork was the only dish that had flavor and was actually decent.
The meat was tender and has a well balanced array of spices.
The garlic noodles however came in a huge blob and stuck together, very bland.
Sadly the coconut rice cannot compete with burmas.
pork with pickled mango.author: Kehaulani K.
pork with pickled mango.review:
I'm a huge fan of Burma Superstar and Mandalay! When this place opened up in my hood I figured based on the reviews it would be amazing. 

We started off with the tea leaf salad which to me had way too many nuts and lentils. Very crunchy and the presentation wasn't like how Burma presents it. I was not a fan.
We then ordered the combo platter appetizer. Let me just say none of this was homemade, rather frozen and deep fried upon ordering. The samosas and falafel were exactly like the ones you get from trader joes frozen section. Totally let down.

For our main entrees we had the pork with pickled mango, garlic noodles and coconut rice. The pork was the only dish that had flavor and was actually decent. The meat was tender and has a well balanced array of spices. The garlic noodles however came in a huge blob and stuck together, very bland. Sadly the coconut rice cannot compete with burmas. There was not even a hint of coconut.

Sorry Burmese kitchen but I won't be returning.

excerpts:
Moh Hinga Fish Chowder
Pork with Pickled Mango
Kyat Tha Dan Pauk (Chicken Biryani)
Burmese
Milk Tea
pork with pickled mango.author: Kevin C.
pork with pickled mango.review:
My current favorites: 
Tofu Thok (Golden Tofu Salad) 
Moh Hinga Fish Chowder
Pork with Pickled Mango
Kyat Tha Dan Pauk (Chicken Biryani)
Burmese Milk Tea
Tapioca Dessert

Trust me, this place is legit. My parents were both born and raised in Burma, and we've been twice this week. And they are well aware that Burma Superstar, Mandalay and Pagan are close by. We'll definitely be back soon to try more items.

Also, the owners are splendid - hella nice people. They make every visit a joy.

excerpts: He chose the pork with pickled mango, pumpkin stew, and biryani rice - all for $12.
pork with pickled mango.author: Kaykay K.
pork with pickled mango.review:
We went for lunch. Reasonably priced. Good portions. My husband ordered the "Meatlover" lunch plate: a choice of 1 meat dish, and 1 vegetable dish for $11 including steamed rice. Add $1 for coconut rice, brown rice, fried rice or biryani rice.  He chose the pork with pickled mango, pumpkin stew, and biryani rice - all for $12. (Their lunch menu is posted online).

I ordered the Soup and Salad for $12. Choice of soup: fish chowder, samosa soup, or chicken coconut noodle soup. Choice of salad: tea leaf or ginger salad. The salad was small but sufficient. The chicken coconut noodle soup was good and filled me, and I left satisfied.

The owner was very friendly. He said he was testing out the lunch hours. So far it has been slow at lunch, but busy at dinnertime. If lunch remains slow, he may close for lunch and offer only dinner hours.  So folks, come on down.  Keep this place open at lunchtime, please!

excerpts:
- Pork with Pickled Mango
- Spicy shrimp
- Nan Ji Thok - rice noodle mixed with veggies and chicken.
This doesn't come in soup, but is still tasty!
- Burmese tea - Burmese tea houses are big in Burma (similar to tea houses in China).
pork with pickled mango.author: Sammantha T.
pork with pickled mango.review:
This was my first time at the new location and the place is clean and nicely decorated.  The staff is friendly and attentive.  I went on a  Friday evening and they were packed!  I usually don't go to Burmese restaurants because my folks make it at home and that's pretty much what I eat almost everyday.  However, Burmese Kitchen is a great place to take your friends out and try different things on the menu because hey, Burmese restaurants are pretty rare.  This place has legit Burmese food and reminds me of everything I love about Burmese cuisines.

Roti and Curry - Delicious!  The roti is a thicker kind and it's delicious with almost anything, in this case, potato curry!  Vegetarian option.

Mohinga - international dish of Burma.  I tried this dish in other Burmese restaurants, but this one hits home.  It's burmese catfish soup with noodle and fried yellow pea.  This dish is eaten as breakfast, lunch, and/or dinner in Burma.  

Coconut chicken curry (Oh nok kaw swe) - I personally prefer this over mohinga.  Both are very delicious.

Tea leaf salad - this dish is hyped here more than in Burma.  It's a mix of tea leaf, nuts, sesame, some veggies, and tomato.  It's fresh and uniquely Burmese.

Fish with Tamarine Sauce - this was my favorite dish.  The fish was tender and had the perfect flavor with rice.  Highly recommended!

Other dishes to consider:
- Pork with Pickled Mango
- Spicy shrimp
- Nan Ji Thok - rice noodle mixed with veggies and chicken.  This doesn't come in soup, but is still tasty!
- Burmese tea - Burmese tea houses are big in Burma (similar to tea houses in China).   You gotta try the tea for the full Burmese experience.

Overall, my experience at Burmese Kitchen was positive.  Friendly staff and great food!

excerpts: My other favorite here is Pork and Pumpkin.
You may think it's weird to have pumpkin in a savory dish, but it is truly yummy with pork.
Theirs is really saucey, so try it.
pork and pumpkin.author: Yuri T.
pork and pumpkin.review:
This is the first time we made it to the new location (on 2/21).  My friends and I were very sad for this place moving from the Civic Center area, but happy that we still get to have their tea leaf salad! :)

Speaking of Tea Leaf Salad - it was good, as we remembered it.  I have had tea lead salad from various Burmese restaurants, but I like theirs the best because it is crunchier than others (they must have more nuts and seeds).  They also have slices of serrano peppers on the side, if you wanted it a bit more spicy.

My other favorite here is Pork and Pumpkin.  You may think it's weird to have pumpkin in a savory dish, but it is truly yummy with pork.  Theirs is really saucey, so try it.  It has never failed me.

Every time we go to this place, we always explore different dish as the other entree dish.  This time, we tried Beef Dal.  I am not much of beans/peas person, and it was OK.  For my taste, it was a bit too much bumpy texture (it has mushed split peas, as well as chana dal, which is another type of peas), but my bf who really likes chana dal liked it.

Overall, a pretty great experience!  However, I still wish it's not that far away in SF...

excerpts: The meat cuts for the pork and pumpkin were tough.
pork and pumpkin.author: A W.
pork and pumpkin.review:
Not very impressed by Burmese Kitchen. I feel like each dish was missing something to make it flavorful and enjoyable. The meat cuts for the pork and pumpkin were tough.

It was just a night full of mistakes to try them, never again.

excerpts: At $11.95 the Spicy Pork was nearly cremated.
spicy pork.author: Caesar A.
spicy pork.review:
This really was not at all pleasing to any of my senses, judge for yourselves.

I thought I loved Burmese food until I tried the follow three dishes here. 

At $11.95 the Spicy Pork was nearly cremated. Overly marinated, dried out tough and chewy I couldn't even eat this.

At $10.95 the Rice Noodle Salad seemed like a plate of saucy mushy something that just was not at all appealing.  

And, at $9.95 the Vegan Fried Peas Salad was just not happening either. With may be some shredded cabbage, onion and slices of jalapeño I just didn't find this combination at all appealing.   

I'm at a loss for words here yet although this did not speak to me, you may feel differently.

excerpts: The noodles were my favorite but as for their spicy pork and spicy jerky was such a let down.
Meat was super dry and hard to chew.
Was expecting more flavors in the meats.
Place is nice and small and service was ok
spicy pork.author: Ivan C.
spicy pork.review: Never ate Burmese food so found this place online. Food wasn't what I expected they def have their own twist on the food. The noodles were my favorite but as for their spicy pork and spicy jerky was such a let down. Meat was super dry and hard to chew. Was expecting more flavors in the meats. Place is nice and small and service was ok

excerpts:
Tamarind Fish Curry: 4.5 stars

Pork Curry: 4.5 stars
Super tender fatty pork.
pork curry.author: Letitia L.
pork curry.review:
Yummy food for a bit less of a hassle than Burma Superstar and the other famous Burmese places. They deliver on Eat24!


---- APPETISERS ----

Roti: 4 stars
Yummy but don't get the $9 one with curry, get the $3 one and dip it into your curry dish.

Okra: 3.5 stars

Tea Leaf Salad: 3.5 stars


---- VEG DISHES ----

Eggplant with Garlic: 4 stars


---- CURRY ----

Tamarind Fish Curry: 4.5 stars

Pork Curry: 4.5 stars
Super tender fatty pork.

Lemongrass Beef Curry: 3.5 stars


---- NOODLES ----

Garlic Noodles: 3 stars

Coconut Curry Chicken Soup: 4.5 stars


---- RICE ----

Beef Biryani: 3 stars
Rice is delicious, but the beef was dry.

excerpts: My brother got the pork curry and there was so much meat.
Lots of bang for your buck portio-wise on this dish.
My dad and I split the Spicy Lady Fingers (okra) and got 3 different types of rices for each of our dishes.
pork curry.author: Candice G.
pork curry.review:
A decent option for Burma Superstar rejects. 

The prices here are about half the price of Burma Superstar, though the ambience isn't quite there and the portion size just slightly smaller. 

They offer a Tea Leaf Salad and an Tea Salad boost type salad with some extras in it, though they don't make a big production out of the salad and mix it up in front of you and instead of your server doing the thing with the lemon, they just give you some slices if lime on the side to  squish yourself. For the salad flavor here, it really doesn't compare to Burma Superstar. Drier here and more bitter with less depth of flavor than at other places, unfortunately. 

I really liked the milk tea I got, though it seemed like maybe it was just English Breakfast with extra cream in it and the portion could have been better for the price on this one.

My brother got the pork curry and there was so much meat. Lots of bang for your buck portio-wise on this dish. My dad and I split the Spicy Lady Fingers (okra) and got 3 different types of rices for each of our dishes. The Spicy Lady Finger pulled through with actually being spicy, which I always appreciate.

We also got a side of roti that for some reason came as we were finishing our main courses but it was really good. I'd for sure get more orders of roti next time. 

Service was fine. Not outstanding but got the job done and seemed like a real one woman show. The ambience could still use some work but I have to give them credit for the creativity with the paper plate wall art. Pretty impressive.

excerpts: (++) Pork Curry (Pork with pureed onion, garlic, mustard seeds & spices, $8.50):
The slow-cooked tender pork and housemade blend of curry make this memorable despite its plain name and presentation.
I really like how the curry is vegetable based
pork curry.author: Edna C.
pork curry.review:
Every time I try a new Burmese place, I find a new favorite... I guess it's an inevitable paradox when Burmese food is so good and each place stands out so distinctively!

(+++) B.K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad (homestyle with extra fermented tea leaf, fried garlic, sesame seeds, shredded cabbage, assorted peas & peanuts, $9.75): Frankly I'm not sure if the extra $2 is worth it over the regular tea leaf salad; I was just enticed by the name. It is definitely one of the most flavorful tea leaf salads I've ever had--pungently aromatic tea leaf, blended into multidimensional character with the assorted peas, topped with a flamboyant coating of sesame seeds. It comes already mixed so it may look as good as other restaurants where all the ingredients are presented in little piles, but the taste is exquisitely exotic.

(++) Ong Noh Kau Swel (coconut chicken soup egg noodle, diced chicken in coconut broth, fried split peas, and hard boil egg, $9.50): An outstandingly balanced coconut soup--just the right amount of coconut without being too creamy. It could have used more chicken, but the soft noodles and overall composition of comforting ingredients essentially make this fancy chicken noodle soup.

(++) Pork Curry (Pork with pureed onion, garlic, mustard seeds & spices, $8.50): The slow-cooked tender pork and housemade blend of curry make this memorable despite its plain name and presentation. I really like how the curry is vegetable based so it's satisfying but light.

Compared to other Burmese places Burmese Kitchen is a little more more hole-in-the-wall, and by hole-in-the-wall, I just mean in size and fame. It's a smaller place and not as frequently discussed as Burma Superstar or Mandalay, but nonetheless a nice restaurant with a relaxing and refined ambiance (though they could do away with the collage of painted paper plates).

excerpts: Their pork curry is to die for.
Excellent service; cosy atmosphere.
The restaurant owners/cooks really care about the food they're serving and it really shows.
I will most definitely be back!
My new local favorite.
pork curry.author: Teresa L.
pork curry.review: The food was SO DELICIOUS! Some of the best meat I've ever had. Their pork curry is to die for. Excellent service; cosy atmosphere. The restaurant owners/cooks really care about the food they're serving and it really shows. I will most definitely be back! My new local favorite.

excerpts: The quality of the beef lemongrass, ginger chicken & ginger pork all weren't that great.
beef lemongrass.author: Cheri C.
beef lemongrass.review:
As a fan of Burmese food, I was disappointed that the quality of this food was mediocre. It wasn't anything special. If you've been to Burma Superstar or Burma Love before, I would stick to those places for a better quality Burmese food. 

We ordered the garlic rice stick dish, which was nothing spectacular. It was basically a clump of noodles that stuck together, with not much taste. The quality of the beef lemongrass, ginger chicken & ginger pork all weren't that great. They also didn't stand out as a Burmese type of flavor. 

However, the tea leaf salad and pumpkin stew were decent. In addition, the service was great as our waiter was very attentive.

excerpts: We ordered the tea leaf salad, mohinga fish chowder soup, beef lemongrass curry, string beans, and coconut rice.
We enjoyed all of the dishes, especially the tea leaf salad.
I appreciate how the coconut rice doesn't have that artificial coconut flavor.
The monhinga soup was something different- curry soup base, noodles, cracker w/
split peas on top.
beef lemongrass.author: Joanna L.
beef lemongrass.review:
Skip the long lines at Burma and come here. 

We ordered the tea leaf salad, mohinga fish chowder soup, beef lemongrass curry, string beans, and coconut rice. We enjoyed all of the dishes, especially the tea leaf salad. I appreciate how the coconut rice doesn't have that artificial coconut flavor. The monhinga soup was something different- curry soup base, noodles, cracker w/ split peas on top. The string beans didn't have too much oil.

The restaurant decor is nice, yet the bathroom in back is dingy. Friendly service though and reasonable prices. I recommend.

excerpts:
Fish with Tamarind Sauce:  DRY
Beef lemongrass:
SO dry.
Tasted like it was frozen and reheated or cooked for 5 days.
beef lemongrass.author: Max L.
beef lemongrass.review:
Just awful greasy, overcooked, small portioned food.

The naan: was so greasy you could squeeze it and fat would ooze out.  Also, only 1 naan per order (and no sauces).

Biryani Rice: not awful
Pumpkin Stew:  No curry flavor, just mushed pumpkin.
Fish with Tamarind Sauce:  DRY
Beef lemongrass:  SO dry.  Tasted like it was frozen and reheated or cooked for 5 days.
Roasted Ginger Pork: as above.
Masala Noodles:  Good.
Papaya Salad: meh.
Fried Samosa:  AWFUL.  The ratio of crust to filling is way off.  Too much crust.
BK Tea Leaf Salad:  Good.

ALL the dishes were way, way too small for the price.

All of this was delivered quickly though.

excerpts: For entrees we ordered the Curry Pork, Beef Masala and Coconut Curry Chicken.
Each was different but amazing.
Presentation was nice and portions were a great size.
beef masala.author: Jorge G.
beef masala.review:
Never had Burmese Food before so this was a first. Gotta say, it was an awesome tasty treat. 

We had the Burmese falafel, tiny but full of flavor, and it packs a spicy kick. For entrees we ordered the Curry Pork, Beef Masala and Coconut Curry Chicken. Each was different but amazing. Presentation was nice and portions were a great size. There was enough to share throughout the table and still have some leftovers. 

The Burmese Fried Rice was also great. Don't assume it's anything like Chinese or Japanese fried rice, it was lighter and not as salty. Highly recommend this place if you're a local or visiting town. Parking's a bit of a pain, but it's well worth it.

excerpts: We ordered the Chicken curry and beef masala with fried rice and it was delicious.
Very tasty.
We went there around 2pm,  there were some customers, but we enjoyed the quiet atmosphere to enjoy the food.
beef masala.author: Melliza S.
beef masala.review: We ordered the Chicken curry and beef masala with fried rice and it was delicious. Very tasty. We went there around 2pm,  there were some customers, but we enjoyed the quiet atmosphere to enjoy the food.

excerpts: We ordered the samosas, roti, fish soup, beef masala, and garlic noodles.
I thought that everything could be seasoned a bit more.
The samosas could use more curry, the beef masala could use more spices, the garlic noodles could use more garlic and the noodles was cooked too long, it was too soft.
Overall food was pretty good.
Service is a bit slow.
We ordered a bottle of wine and it came after 3 dishes of ours had already came out.
beef masala.author: Vinkin Ken T.
beef masala.review: Came here for a friend's birthday dinner around 7pm on a Saturday night. We only had to wait less than 10 mins for a table. They have a sign up sheet with a lot of names already on it, guess we got there at the perfect time. The place was already full. They don't take reservations for less than 6 people. Their prices is cheaper than the other Burmese restaurants I've been too. We ordered the samosas, roti, fish soup, beef masala, and garlic noodles. I thought that everything could be seasoned a bit more. The samosas could use more curry, the beef masala could use more spices, the garlic noodles could use more garlic and the noodles was cooked too long, it was too soft. Overall food was pretty good. Service is a bit slow. We ordered a bottle of wine and it came after 3 dishes of ours had already came out.

excerpts: For our main courses, we had a chicken coconut curry which was tasty and creamy, and a beef masala.
They were delishhhhh!
Oh, and  a tip for drinks: they have Burmese beer!
Overall, it was a great experience.
We will definitely be back and try more of the dishes!
:D
beef masala.author: Emily J.
beef masala.review: Came in here on a Friday night for dinner. The decor is nice and the vibe is cozy. Their menu has so many items to offer so we asked for some recommendations. We started off with a Tamarind salad. The taste is hard to describe but it's insanely good. Then we had a fish & sour leaf soup which was a bit spicy and well-balanced. For our main courses, we had a chicken coconut curry which was tasty and creamy, and a beef masala. They were delishhhhh! Oh, and  a tip for drinks: they have Burmese beer! Overall, it was a great experience. We will definitely be back and try more of the dishes! :D

excerpts: Beef Biryani:

3 stars
Rice is delicious, but the beef was dry.
beef biryani.author: Letitia L.
beef biryani.review:
Yummy food for a bit less of a hassle than Burma Superstar and the other famous Burmese places. They deliver on Eat24!


---- APPETISERS ----

Roti: 4 stars
Yummy but don't get the $9 one with curry, get the $3 one and dip it into your curry dish.

Okra: 3.5 stars

Tea Leaf Salad: 3.5 stars


---- VEG DISHES ----

Eggplant with Garlic: 4 stars


---- CURRY ----

Tamarind Fish Curry: 4.5 stars

Pork Curry: 4.5 stars
Super tender fatty pork.

Lemongrass Beef Curry: 3.5 stars


---- NOODLES ----

Garlic Noodles: 3 stars

Coconut Curry Chicken Soup: 4.5 stars


---- RICE ----

Beef Biryani: 3 stars
Rice is delicious, but the beef was dry.

excerpts: Focusing on the foods, Burmese Kitchen offers you a great chicken and beef biryani, many great curry which its meat is not cooked too well-done or too harsh (compare to B Star).
beef biryani.author: Rachel T.
beef biryani.review: I'm the big fan of Burmese foods and I have to tell you guys that this restaurant is way much better than Burma Superstar on Clement St.   Focusing on the foods, Burmese Kitchen offers you a great chicken and beef biryani, many great curry which its meat is not cooked too well-done or too harsh (compare to B Star). Also, they offer an amazing Mo-Hing-Ya (Burmese style fish chowder) ... Way way much better than B Star as well. ....,, people plz don't wait an hour for B Star. Come here!!

excerpts: The Tea Leaf Salad, Fried Samosas, Beef Biryani, and Fish with Tamarind Sauce were particularly splendid.
beef biryani.author: Abbas A.
beef biryani.review: Burmese Kitchen is hands down a must-eat restaurant with great, authentic food and a friendly atmosphere. The food's high quality and affordability make this restaurant far superior to the bland, culture-less, so-called "Asian" restaurants in other popular (US) cities. The Tea Leaf Salad, Fried Samosas, Beef Biryani, and Fish with Tamarind Sauce were particularly splendid.

excerpts: * Fish with Tamarind Sauce.
My favorite dish of the three.
The tamarind add a nice savory flavor to the fish, without being too strong.
Burmese styled fried rice (side dish).
I don't remember having this before.
fish with tamarind sauce.author: Gui K.
fish with tamarind sauce.review:
Ordered:

* B. K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad. It was okay. It has an interesting combination of nuts, but to me the flavor was a bit mild/dry. My favorite style of tea leaf salads are more on the juicy/sour side and the tea leaves with more intense flavor.
* Pumpkin Stew. Simple and straightforward. Tastes good.
* Fish with Tamarind Sauce. My favorite dish of the three. The tamarind add a nice savory flavor to the fish, without being too strong.
* Burmese styled fried rice (side dish). I don't remember having this before. It was flavorful.

Good prices, but portions are on the smaller side.

The place is clean and looks new. It was quite empty during a Saturday during dinner time, which was a bit surprising. Staff is friendly and attentive.

Burmese Kitchen should be all the hype in the Inner Richmond. They moved from the Tenderloin and this location is clean and intimate. There was no wait when we came during a week night and the prices here are so much more reasonable than Burma Superstar. The service is also quaint and kind.
The Rainbow Salad is always a winner and the Fish with Tamarind Sauce and the Chicken Coconut Curry were delicious to share among two people.
This is definitely my go-to spot to satisfy my Burmese food cravings. They also accept credit card.

basil fish.review: One of our best meals as long as we can remember!  Everything was tasty and delicious.  Nice atmosphere and cordial service!  We loved the tea salad, chicken coconut curry, basil fish, stir-fried okra, with coconut rice and biryani... Topped with tapioca with coconut milk for dessert. Perfect in every way!

excerpts: The prawn and pumpkin was not fresh and salty.
prawn and pumpkin.author: Melvon M.
prawn and pumpkin.review: The prawn and pumpkin was not fresh and salty. The string bean dish was ok. The vegetarian curry has a few pcs of main vegetables except for broccoli. Nothing special. The tea leaf salad is not too bad. Sorry, I will not recommend this restaurant.

pumpkin stew.review: My husband and I had dinner tonight here after receiving a strong recommendation from an old friend. This experience was truly above and beyond! The owner Lee was a very sweet, modest and hospitable woman that really cares about her customers and the restaurant. We are true foodies and know we will be returning to the restaurant at least 1x month from now on - we highly recommend it!
