excerpts: I enjoyed everything we ate, which was the pumpkin stew, potato curry, and tea leaf salad.
I love pumpkin, so that wasn't a hard sell, but fermented tea leaves?
That doesn't sound pleasant at all.
pumpkin stew.author: Lisa S.
pumpkin stew.review:
Having vegan and vegetarian friends is both a curse and a blessing. It's a curse, because I love eating meat, and our meal choices are always limited. It's a blessing, because I sometimes try new foods and places that I wouldn't otherwise attempt.

Case in point, Burmese kitchen. I've never thought to myself, "Hey! I want some Burmese food" or "Hey! I want some vegetarian Burmese food!" This was my friend's suggestion, and even after I agreed, I wasn't sold.

The meal was quite good, though. I enjoyed everything we ate, which was the pumpkin stew, potato curry, and tea leaf salad. I love pumpkin, so that wasn't a hard sell, but fermented tea leaves? That doesn't sound pleasant at all. Luckily, it totally was, and I'd order it again in a heartbeat.

The area outside isn't the greatest, but if you're not too worried about it, this is a nice spot for some food.

excerpts: Pumpkin Stew - was good but not enough to merit a return visit.
pumpkin stew.author: Kim S.
pumpkin stew.review:
Was excited to see a new Burmese place in the area.  I'm not 1 of the followers of Burma Superstar bc I don't get the hype & not willing to stand in the cold for an hour or so for a table for food that's good but nothing mind-blowing.

Anyway, stopped in for lunch at the Burmese Kitchen & was super excited to try the fish w/ tamarind sauce.  It was very disappointing, the fish simply tasted like salt, too much salt.  No other flavors or spices, just salt.  The fish was also overcooked - most likely frozen too.

Biryani Rice - bland & too dry.  Didn't taste any saffron spices & there were about a total of 3 raisins.

Pumpkin Stew - was good but not enough to merit a return visit.

The waiter was inexperienced but nice.

excerpts: We ordered the eggplant, the pumpkin stew, the rainbow noodle salad, samusa soup and roti.
I can't say anything was even good.
The eggplant dish was giant slimy chunks of greenish gray eggplant and the pumpkin stew looked like baby food.
They were both almost inedible.
A terrible texture and very little flavor.
The rest was mediocre at best.
We ended up throwing a lot away because it just wasn't worth eating.
When we walked in to pick up our order, the guy at the front asked if we were excited to try Burmese food.
We told them that we actually really like Burmese food and his face fell.

After tasting their food, I definitely got the feeling that they were trying to cash in on the popularity of Burma Superstar and Mandalay, but this tastes nothing like the food at either of those restaurants.
It's possible that we just ordered the wrong dishes, but those are some of my favorites at other Burmese restaurants.
Don't waste your money or tastebuds on this place.
Not sure how it's rated so highly unless they bought ratings.
pumpkin stew.author: Karen S.
pumpkin stew.review:
This was a huge disappointment. Mandalay was closed and I decided to try this place. We ordered the eggplant, the pumpkin stew, the rainbow noodle salad, samusa soup and roti. I can't say anything was even good. The eggplant dish was giant slimy chunks of greenish gray eggplant and the pumpkin stew looked like baby food. They were both almost inedible. A terrible texture and very little flavor. The rest was mediocre at best. We ended up throwing a lot away because it just wasn't worth eating.
When we walked in to pick up our order, the guy at the front asked if we were excited to try Burmese food. We told them that we actually really like Burmese food and his face fell. After tasting their food, I definitely got the feeling that they were trying to cash in on the popularity of Burma Superstar and Mandalay, but this tastes nothing like the food at either of those restaurants. It's possible that we just ordered the wrong dishes, but those are some of my favorites at other Burmese restaurants. Don't waste your money or tastebuds on this place. Not sure how it's rated so highly unless they bought ratings.

excerpts: He chose the pork with pickled mango, pumpkin stew, and biryani rice - all for $12.
pumpkin stew.author: Kaykay K.
pumpkin stew.review:
We went for lunch. Reasonably priced. Good portions. My husband ordered the "Meatlover" lunch plate: a choice of 1 meat dish, and 1 vegetable dish for $11 including steamed rice. Add $1 for coconut rice, brown rice, fried rice or biryani rice.  He chose the pork with pickled mango, pumpkin stew, and biryani rice - all for $12. (Their lunch menu is posted online).

I ordered the Soup and Salad for $12. Choice of soup: fish chowder, samosa soup, or chicken coconut noodle soup. Choice of salad: tea leaf or ginger salad. The salad was small but sufficient. The chicken coconut noodle soup was good and filled me, and I left satisfied.

The owner was very friendly. He said he was testing out the lunch hours. So far it has been slow at lunch, but busy at dinnertime. If lunch remains slow, he may close for lunch and offer only dinner hours.  So folks, come on down.  Keep this place open at lunchtime, please!

excerpts: I wasn't terribly impressed with the pumpkin stew but it was my personal taste, not anything they did wrong.
pumpkin stew.author: Stacey H.
pumpkin stew.review:
I discovered Burma Kitchen in their old location on Larkin St. I had many delicious lunches there & was bummed when they closed. Imagine my delight when they re-opened in my neighborhood! Yay!

The food is fabulous and the prices are reasonable, this place is so much better than Superstar or Mandalay. I've been working my way through the menu (except for pork & beef) and haven't had a bad thing yet, although I don't recommend getting samosas for takeout because they get soggy when they get cold. Most things have been good, some even spectacular. I wasn't terribly impressed with the pumpkin stew but it was my personal taste, not anything they did wrong. Favorites are the tea leaf salad (always fresh & with plenty of tea leaves) and garlic noodles and potato curry and the fried combo starter. Yum.

excerpts: We ordered falafel, tea leaf salad, roti with potato curry, garlic noodle, and lemongrass beef.
I never liked deep fried stuff - but the falafel here changes my mind totally.
Super crusty outside, fresh and tender inside - with their homemade sauce - perfection!
potato curry.author: Fiona K.
potato curry.review:
Recommend every burmese food lovers to come and explore. This is not the first time I come to Burmese Kitchen, but tonight's orders are just too delicious to be true. By the time of ordering, we expected to pack some unfinished dishes to go, but we ended up finishing everything on the table.
We ordered falafel, tea leaf salad, roti with potato curry, garlic noodle, and lemongrass beef. 
I never liked deep fried stuff - but the falafel here changes my mind totally. Super crusty outside, fresh and tender inside - with their homemade sauce - perfection!

excerpts: We started with the roti and potato curry.
The roti is so good, especially with the comforting curry.
I wish there was more roti for the price
potato curry.author: Vira P.
potato curry.review:
Out of the many Burmese restaurants in the Richmond District, Burmese Kitchen is one of my top two.  It's funny that they were so close to my office, and then they moved to my neighborhood..  I guess I was meant to dine here!

My friend from NYC never had Burmese food, so this place came to mind as Burma Superstar always has a long line, and we were already on the 38.

We started with the roti and potato curry.  The roti is so good, especially with the comforting curry.  I wish there was more roti for the price (plus there was a lot of curry left over), but that bread is pretty filling.

I got the eggs in tamarind sauce, and the coconut rice per recommendation.  It was delicious! You get three hard boiled eggs in a savory, tangy curry, and it goes really well with the coconut rice.  I couldn't finish it, but I wish I did because it did not fare well as leftovers (except for the rice).  So if you order this dish, make sure you eat it there.  I would order this dish again though, because it's $8.50, much cheaper than the $13.50 for two eggs with curry I've had at another restaurant.

The food is quick, and service is friendly.  And I have to give them props for their decor.  The wall is lined with paper plates that are dyed in different, bold colors.  A good diy option for decor on a budget.  The space is small, but it's never crowded, which I like.  I can't stand having the feeling of being rushed to eat dinner.

I read some of the other reviews regarding the tea leaf salad, and I will have to try that next time I'm here.  I'm not an expert on Burmese food, but it seems like that salad is the key indicator for what makes a Burmese restaurant great.

excerpts: *Roti and Potato Curry ($6.50): Vegan, contain gluten
The potato curry had great flavor and was thick and rich, but I found the roti to be way too oily.
The roti was nice and flaky though.
Based on the tea leaf salad, potato curry and garlic noodles, I'd say Burmese Kitchen is just A-OK.
potato curry.author: Elena N.
potato curry.review:
I'd been craving garlic noodles and a tea leaf salad. Decided to try Burmese Kitchen on Saturday, May 7th for lunch. I ordered delivery through Eat24. Placed my order at 1:28pm and it arrived at 2:37pm.

*Roti and Potato Curry ($6.50): Vegan, contain gluten
*B. K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad ($9.95): Vegan, Homestyle with extra fermented tea leaf, fried garlic, sesame seeds, shredded cabbage, assorted peas, peanuts on side
*Garlic Noodles ($9.50): Sei jyet kau swel, Contain gluten, Egg noodles tossed with garlic oil, green onion, chicken

The potato curry had great flavor and was thick and rich, but I found the roti to be way too oily. The roti was nice and flaky though. The tea leaf salad is very dense, so I split the salad throughout four meals. With all the nuts, etc, you will be chewing a lot. It had a subtle heat due to the peppers. The garlic noodles were good, but they all stuck together in a big clump. I had to cut up the noodles and remix them so I could eat them. Good flavor though. I liked the texture of the egg noodles.

I wanted to try more items, but it was just me ordering the delivery, so I refrained from over ordering. Based on the tea leaf salad, potato curry and garlic noodles, I'd say Burmese Kitchen is just A-OK.

excerpts: Their iced tea, tea leaf salad, rainbow salad, potato curry - everything consistently tastes amazing.
You won't find a friendlier atmosphere or owner either.
I've eaten here at least once every couple weeks ever since I moved to the area.
Favorite restaurant around here, hands down.
potato curry.author: Tyler B.
potato curry.review: This place is the real deal. Their iced tea, tea leaf salad, rainbow salad, potato curry - everything consistently tastes amazing. You won't find a friendlier atmosphere or owner either. I've eaten here at least once every couple weeks ever since I moved to the area. Favorite restaurant around here, hands down.

excerpts: I enjoyed everything we ate, which was the pumpkin stew, potato curry, and tea leaf salad.
I love pumpkin, so that wasn't a hard sell, but fermented tea leaves?
That doesn't sound pleasant at all.
potato curry.author: Lisa S.
potato curry.review:
Having vegan and vegetarian friends is both a curse and a blessing. It's a curse, because I love eating meat, and our meal choices are always limited. It's a blessing, because I sometimes try new foods and places that I wouldn't otherwise attempt.

Case in point, Burmese kitchen. I've never thought to myself, "Hey! I want some Burmese food" or "Hey! I want some vegetarian Burmese food!" This was my friend's suggestion, and even after I agreed, I wasn't sold.

The meal was quite good, though. I enjoyed everything we ate, which was the pumpkin stew, potato curry, and tea leaf salad. I love pumpkin, so that wasn't a hard sell, but fermented tea leaves? That doesn't sound pleasant at all. Luckily, it totally was, and I'd order it again in a heartbeat.

The area outside isn't the greatest, but if you're not too worried about it, this is a nice spot for some food.

excerpts: We just stopped in for appetizers and got the Tea leaf salad and potato curry with roti and they were both so delicious, the salad was a bit small but very flavorful.
Our waitress was super sweet and the decor is really cute and cozy.
potato curry.author: Katie C.
potato curry.review: We just stopped in for appetizers and got the Tea leaf salad and potato curry with roti and they were both so delicious, the salad was a bit small but very flavorful. Our waitress was super sweet and the decor is really cute and cozy.

excerpts: As for the food, we ordered the tea leaf salad, a roti with yellow potato curry, the mohinga, and garlic noodles with chicken.

The tea leaf salad was mostly nuts and lentils, and while I liked the crunch of it, I could tell that it wasn't freshly made because it came pre-mixed, versus the presentation I much prefer where they have small piles of each ingredient that they mix in front of you or let you mix yourself.
potato curry.author: Leslie H.
potato curry.review:
We stopped by Burmese Kitchen on Saturday night around 7:30 after being told that the wait at Burma Superstar would be about 2 hours. I kind of wish I had waited, but then I wouldn't have eaten until 9:30... Burmese Kitchen is small, but bustling. It looked like a lot of other people had the same idea of avoiding the wait and getting their food NOW. 

The restaurant itself is pretty small, with a signup sheet attached to the door and two extra chairs just inside, but no real designated waiting area. We waited about 10 minutes to be seated, when the first wave of diners seemed to all finish up at the same time. Their tables are all a bunch of two-tops that they can move as needed to accommodate larger parties. Unfortunately, the corner table we were given was really close to the other two-top. So close that when the hostess came by to take our orders, she had to wedge herself between the two tables. Also, when she was taking orders for the table next to us, she definitely kept hitting me in the shoulder. I think that they could make it a much better dining experience if they removed one of the two-tops from that row. 

As for the food, we ordered the tea leaf salad, a roti with yellow potato curry, the mohinga, and garlic noodles with chicken. None of it was really that good.

The tea leaf salad was mostly nuts and lentils, and while I liked the crunch of it, I could tell that it wasn't freshly made because it came pre-mixed, versus the presentation I much prefer where they have small piles of each ingredient that they mix in front of you or let you mix yourself. It tasted pretty good, but I wouldn't really call it a salad given the lack of vegetables and leafy greens. 

The roti and curry were good, but disappointing in the disproportionate amount of roti to curry: only one roti, though you can order an additional roti for $4. For the small size, I didn't think it was worth it. The curry was underseasoned, even if the potatoes were cooked through, they had no taste, no spice, no flavor. 

The mohinga was okay, but also rather bland. The noodles were beyond overcooked to the point of dissolving in my mouth at each bite. I couldn't really taste any of the fish, maybe it dissolved as well? I did like the crispy lentil cakes, which added the only texture found in the soup. 

My garlic noodles were a HUGE disappointment, so bland and fishy tasting, even though I added chicken. The chicken was old and chewy and had an off flavor, and it didn't mix well with the noodles. The noodles themselves were like thin-cut egg noodles that clumped together and had absolutely no flavor. The only texture came from the fried garlic that garnished the dish, but quickly fell off. I would never recommend ordering this to anyone, especially not at $10 a pop. 

I would say that we made the wrong choice in coming to Burmese Kitchen instead of waiting for Burma Superstar. $42 including tax and tip, and so not worth it. The touted friendly service never made an appearance during our visit, but maybe it's because they were super understaffed and trying to rush diners in and out as quickly as possible.

excerpts: Roasted ginger pork, chicken potato curry, and the tea leaf salad are some real good eats.
Husband and wife run the place, and they're both very personable.
They check on each customer to make sure they have a good meal.
I particularly like the thick, professional looking menus.
potato curry.author: Henry T.
potato curry.review: Good eats. We ordered a lot of food. My new obsession may now be coconut rice. Wow! I could inhale bowls of that stuff. Roasted ginger pork, chicken potato curry, and the tea leaf salad are some real good eats. Husband and wife run the place, and they're both very personable. They check on each customer to make sure they have a good meal. I particularly like the thick, professional looking menus.

excerpts:
We ordered:

Roti and Potato curry
Tea leaf salad
Tamarind spicy fish
Green beans
Pork with pickled mango
(Except the tea leaf salad, very small portion size).
potato curry.author: Foodlover B.
potato curry.review:
Four of us arrived lunch today, a Saturday, and had the place to ourselves.

We ordered:

Roti and Potato curry
Tea leaf salad
Tamarind spicy fish
Green beans
Pork with pickled mango

Everything was very good.  The tab was $54. Portions were generous. (Except the tea leaf salad, very small portion size).

 It's close to a 38 muni.

It's much nicer vs their old place in the tenderloin. It's decorated very pretty and so much cleaner. We had been to their old place 4-5 times but it got too gross for us. I'm glad they moved!

excerpts:
We got:
- tea leaf salad
- samosa soup
- roti and potato curry
- chicken and potato curry
- pork with pickled mango
- lemongrass beef
- spicy fish
- garlic rice stick with chicken
- mixed vegetable curry
- ladyfingers (okra)
- coconut rice
potato curry.author: Kris K.
potato curry.review:
Great Burmese spot that's super cheap and easy to get into. Maybe slightly smaller portions than Mandalay or Burma Superstar, but a little cheaper, and just about as good. Comparably good to Burma Love, but less than half the price. A little more out of the way, especially compared to their previous Civic Center location, but well worth the trip. We had no trouble getting a table for 8 at 7pm on a Saturday. 

We got:
- tea leaf salad
- samosa soup
- roti and potato curry
- chicken and potato curry
- pork with pickled mango
- lemongrass beef
- spicy fish
- garlic rice stick with chicken
- mixed vegetable curry
- ladyfingers (okra)
- coconut rice

Everything was pretty solid - the lemongrass beef, spicy fish, and appetizers were all big hits, and vegetable curry well liked too. It came out to less than $18/head, for quite the feast. Great service too, water was refilled pretty frequently, despite it only being one woman running the place. Several among the group had not had Burmese before and were big fans. 

Will happily return and it'll be another alternative to Burma Superstar for less wait, along with Mandalay.

excerpts: I had the mixed vegetables curry, my sister had the chicken potato curry and we shared a biryani side.
potato curry.author: M-E C.
potato curry.review:
Visited on a Monday night at 6:30pm. We were the only ones at the time but we were unfazed as we had wanted to try this place since we found out Burmese food was fixing to be right around the corner. 

We weren't too hungry so we skipped apps and went right to mains. I had the mixed vegetables curry, my sister had the chicken potato curry and we shared a biryani side. 

While we were waiting, four single tops filed in and the small space didn't seem so empty. The dishes arrived shortly thereafter and our drinks promptly refilled. The biryani I found bland but my sis liked it. No complaints about the curries. All in all we enjoyed our dinner and the quality service.

excerpts: My favorites and regular choice here is the spicy fish (you can ask them to make it mild), Garlic Eggplant, beef and potato curry with rice, delicious all together.
potato curry.author: Dechen S.
potato curry.review: One of my favorite Burmese restaurant. A must have is their green tea leaf salad, hands down the best compared to all the Burmese restaurant I've been to. My favorites and regular choice here is the spicy fish (you can ask them to make it mild), Garlic Eggplant, beef and potato curry with rice, delicious all together.

excerpts: The potato curry was very watery and bland w/ little curry taste.
potato curry.author: Lucy C.
potato curry.review:
Came here excited to try this place out thinking it would be good given that it's in a close vicinity with a few good Burmese restaurants in the area, but apparently that is not the case. 

The food here is very bland and disappointing ! The potato curry was very watery and bland w/ little curry taste. The fish chowder was bland and comes w/ a lot of nuts. The chicken curry was bland and you'll have to order rice separately cause it doesn't come with any. Lastly, the Burmese fried rice is just plain rice with nothing in it, no meat or veggies. 

Even though the food was bad you would hope for good service to at least off-set the disappointment. Unfortunately the servers here very bad as well, it's so hard to flag any of the two servers in this very tiny restaurant.  When I was dining there, coincidentally friends of the servers were dining there as well. They neglected all the other patrons except their friends especially the guy in the red shirt. He was constantly checking up on his friends to see if they liked the food.  One more thing to mention about him is that he was constantly touching and scratching his pimply face then serving your food......................

excerpts: Roti & potato curry - I LOVE THIS DISH.
My only wish is that they serve it with more roti, but that can be easily solved by ordering 2!
potato curry.author: Roxanne K.
potato curry.review:
Disclaimer: My husband's relatives own this restaurant, but my review is as unbiased as can be!

I usually am wary about going to a newly opened restaurant because they still have some kinks to work out, but this was different.  Yes, they were a fully functioning and awesome restaurant before their move, but OMG has it gotten so much better!  Everything tastes fresher.

Roti & potato curry - I LOVE THIS DISH.  My only wish is that they serve it with more roti, but that can be easily solved by ordering 2! :)

Tea leaf salad - When we've ordered this at the old location, it was good.  But when we ordered it this time, the flavors seemed to be brighter, fresher, fuller.  Normally when we would take friends to their previous location, we'd get this just because it is a Burmese staple, but now, I can confidently say that this is THE BEST tea leaf salad I've ever had in the bay area!

Mohinga - fish chowder - A very hearty soup dish that can be eaten as a main dish or shared between 3-4 people.

Dan Pauk - biryani chicken - My hubby's favorite and this was no exception.  The rice is cooked to perfection and the chicken  wonderfully seasoned with curry and other spices.

Spicy fish - The fish is lightly fried and served with a chili/garlic sauce. If you can't handle the heat though, maybe skip this or be sure the rest of your group can.  Hehe.

Chicken curry - can't go wrong with chicken curry!

Coconut rice - This pairs so well with the chicken curry. If you like coconut milk, this is a must try! Don't be afraid, it's not too sweet.  It's a light flavor of coconut milk that's slightly toasted/nutty.

Service is great.  Attentive staff without being overbearing.  Parking is a bit tough, but honestly, this restaurant is well worth the walk and wait.  However, I think the neighborhood is a step up from their last location.  Give Burmese Kitchen a chance!  You won't be disappointed!

excerpts: The Roti and Potato curry is great as is the tea leaf salad and the curry coconut chicken.
The staff is very kind and friendly and I have enjoyed their food for years.
Started dining with them at their old location and
this one is much nicer...
potato curry.author: Will M.
potato curry.review: The absolutely most authentic Burmese food I have found in SF.  The Roti and Potato curry is great as is the tea leaf salad and the curry coconut chicken.   The staff is very kind and friendly and I have enjoyed their food for years.   Started dining with them at their old location and this one is much nicer...

excerpts:
mmm

Beef & Potato Curry--
potato curry.author: Mariko S.
potato curry.review:
What a find! Came here to try it after hearing it reopened--and it was such a good decision! The restaurant itself is intimate, a great spot for a date night. The orange wall and clean wooden tables give it a nice modern look while still remaining comfy and welcoming.

We had: 

Tea Leaf Salad--Best one in the city, and we've tried them all. It isn't too spicy, is a great portion, and very flavorful.

Samosas--So good! Not greasy at all, and stuffed with deliciously seasoned potatoes and peas...

Roti--Thousand layer bread, so delicate and flaky. mmm

Beef & Potato Curry--The beef was so tender and juicy--it melted in your mouth. The potatoes were hot and perfectly cooked, and the curry spices were just right. Exactly what we were looking for on a cold, rainy SF night. 

Tapioca Pudding--brought my fiancee back to her childhood. It was prepared just like her grandma used to make, warm with a bit of coconut/condensed milk. She was in heaven.

And our server--Lee was very sweet to take a few minutes to chat with us about the old location and the new one. She was quick and very busy with many full tables!

Overall--they prices were fair for the right amount of food, and you can taste the love and family recipes. So satisfying, and might be habit forming. 

We will definitely be back!

excerpts: Roti & Potato Curry: this was a wild card for us but turned out to be excellent!
Very filling and flavorful.
Chin Baung Hin Yay Fish & Sour Leaf:
This is SPICY and so delicious.
I'm not a fan of fish soups but this was seriously so good!
Incredibly flavorful, not overpowering, spicy - but just the right amount, and hardy!
Garlic Chicken: three other tables ordered the same thing and each of us were in awe at how perfectly tender and delicious this dish was.
We even eyed each other in affirmation of heavenly cooked the meat was -- so juicy!
potato curry.author: June L.
potato curry.review:
LOVE this restaurant! Atmosphere and service are great and the food, most importantly, is amazing. I've eaten here twice so far and both times have been equally satisfying. This place beats Burma Superstar without a doubt; it's way more authentic and food tastes fresher. Although it's busy, it's still fairly new so not too many people know about it (which is great because I frankly hate waiting in lines!). Coming back here next week for round three! See below for recommended orders.

What we loved:
Tea Leaf Salad. This is light yet hardy, fresh and delicious. 
Roti & Potato Curry: this was a wild card for us but turned out to be excellent! Very filling and flavorful.
Chin Baung Hin Yay Fish & Sour Leaf: This is SPICY and so delicious. I'm not a fan of fish soups but this was seriously so good! Incredibly flavorful, not overpowering, spicy - but just the right amount, and hardy! 
Garlic Chicken: three other tables ordered the same thing and each of us were in awe at how perfectly tender and delicious this dish was. We even eyed each other in affirmation of heavenly cooked the meat was -- so juicy!

excerpts: Next we had the roti with the yellow potato curry.
We both commented that it was excellent comfort food.
The bread was nice and hot, and there were big chunks of potato in the curry.
The roti was pretty small, so we had to eat some curry without bread, but it was still excellent.
Next came the garlic egg noodles.
They weren't very special - definitely the least inspired dish, but I did like the crispy garlic in it.
Finally we had the lemongrass beef.
I don't think I've ever had this dish before, so the closest comparison I can come up with is mas-su-man beef.
It was the same style of stewed beef, with a similar type of gravy on it, but with a milder flavor.
It's a cute little restaurant and the service was quick and friendly.
We'll definitely be back and this time order two of the tea salads and two of the roti with the yellow potato curry.
potato curry.author: Quentin J.
potato curry.review:
We usually go to Volcano Curry when we're in this neighborhood, but we decided to try this place because we haven't had Burmese in a while. We started with the tea leaf salad, which was very tasty.  You could really taste the fermented tea leaves and that contrasted really well with the crispy peas, peanuts, cabbage, & garlic chips. Next we had the roti with the yellow potato curry.  We both commented that it was excellent comfort food. The bread was nice and hot, and there were big chunks of potato in the curry. The roti was pretty small, so we had to eat some curry without bread, but it was still excellent. Next came the garlic egg noodles. They weren't very special - definitely the least inspired dish, but I did like the crispy garlic in it.  Finally we had the lemongrass beef. I don't think I've ever had this dish before, so the closest comparison I can come up with is mas-su-man beef.  It was the same style of stewed beef, with a similar type of gravy on it, but with a milder flavor. 
It's a cute little restaurant and the service was quick and friendly. We'll definitely be back and this time order two of the tea salads and two of the roti with the yellow potato curry.

excerpts:
3.5 stars

Had the roti with potato curry, moh hinga, special tea leaf salad, chicken curry, pork & pumpkin, mixed vegetable curry and coconut rice.
potato curry.author: Chew B.
potato curry.review:
3.5 stars

Had the roti with potato curry, moh hinga, special tea leaf salad, chicken curry, pork & pumpkin, mixed vegetable curry and coconut rice. The dishes had flavor but didn't have something distinctive to make them stand out. While the moh hinga was tasty, the chicken in the chicken curry was not fresh. Both Burma Superstar and Mandalay do a slightly better job. Service was attentive and it was easy to get in which is a strong positive for Burmese Kitchen.

excerpts: and it's delicious with almost anything, in this case, potato curry!
potato curry.author: Sammantha T.
potato curry.review:
This was my first time at the new location and the place is clean and nicely decorated.  The staff is friendly and attentive.  I went on a  Friday evening and they were packed!  I usually don't go to Burmese restaurants because my folks make it at home and that's pretty much what I eat almost everyday.  However, Burmese Kitchen is a great place to take your friends out and try different things on the menu because hey, Burmese restaurants are pretty rare.  This place has legit Burmese food and reminds me of everything I love about Burmese cuisines.

Roti and Curry - Delicious!  The roti is a thicker kind and it's delicious with almost anything, in this case, potato curry!  Vegetarian option.

Mohinga - international dish of Burma.  I tried this dish in other Burmese restaurants, but this one hits home.  It's burmese catfish soup with noodle and fried yellow pea.  This dish is eaten as breakfast, lunch, and/or dinner in Burma.  

Coconut chicken curry (Oh nok kaw swe) - I personally prefer this over mohinga.  Both are very delicious.

Tea leaf salad - this dish is hyped here more than in Burma.  It's a mix of tea leaf, nuts, sesame, some veggies, and tomato.  It's fresh and uniquely Burmese.

Fish with Tamarine Sauce - this was my favorite dish.  The fish was tender and had the perfect flavor with rice.  Highly recommended!

Other dishes to consider:
- Pork with Pickled Mango
- Spicy shrimp
- Nan Ji Thok - rice noodle mixed with veggies and chicken.  This doesn't come in soup, but is still tasty!
- Burmese tea - Burmese tea houses are big in Burma (similar to tea houses in China).   You gotta try the tea for the full Burmese experience.

Overall, my experience at Burmese Kitchen was positive.  Friendly staff and great food!

excerpts: Favorites are the tea leaf salad (always fresh & with plenty of tea leaves) and garlic noodles and potato curry and the fried combo starter.
Yum.
potato curry.author: Stacey H.
potato curry.review:
I discovered Burma Kitchen in their old location on Larkin St. I had many delicious lunches there & was bummed when they closed. Imagine my delight when they re-opened in my neighborhood! Yay!

The food is fabulous and the prices are reasonable, this place is so much better than Superstar or Mandalay. I've been working my way through the menu (except for pork & beef) and haven't had a bad thing yet, although I don't recommend getting samosas for takeout because they get soggy when they get cold. Most things have been good, some even spectacular. I wasn't terribly impressed with the pumpkin stew but it was my personal taste, not anything they did wrong. Favorites are the tea leaf salad (always fresh & with plenty of tea leaves) and garlic noodles and potato curry and the fried combo starter. Yum.

excerpts: The string bean dish was ok.
The vegetarian curry has a few pcs of main vegetables except for broccoli.
Nothing special.
string bean.author: Melvon M.
string bean.review: The prawn and pumpkin was not fresh and salty. The string bean dish was ok. The vegetarian curry has a few pcs of main vegetables except for broccoli. Nothing special. The tea leaf salad is not too bad. Sorry, I will not recommend this restaurant.

excerpts: I had the mixed vegetables curry, my sister had the chicken potato curry and we shared a biryani side.
mixed vegetables curry.author: M-E C.
mixed vegetables curry.review:
Visited on a Monday night at 6:30pm. We were the only ones at the time but we were unfazed as we had wanted to try this place since we found out Burmese food was fixing to be right around the corner. 

We weren't too hungry so we skipped apps and went right to mains. I had the mixed vegetables curry, my sister had the chicken potato curry and we shared a biryani side. 

While we were waiting, four single tops filed in and the small space didn't seem so empty. The dishes arrived shortly thereafter and our drinks promptly refilled. The biryani I found bland but my sis liked it. No complaints about the curries. All in all we enjoyed our dinner and the quality service.

excerpts: Spicy Lotus Roots
: We decided on this since I've never seen it on a Burmese menu.
The roots were well flavored.
Texturally, I was craving something to counterbalance the crunchiness of the roots.
But that's just my Western sensibilities talking!
I checked and this is how this dish is usually made.
spicy lotus roots.author: Jay C.
spicy lotus roots.review:
Vegan Factor: 4.5 Stars
Lots of vegan options. And they're clearly marked and called out in the descriptions!

Food: 4 Stars
1. B.K. Style Signature Tea Leaf Salad: A unique version of the ubiquitous tea leaf salad. a. The tea leaves, traditional in that they weren't diced, were extra fermented--it was more chewy than others, b. less cabbage, c. more nuts! (first time I've seen edamame seeds on this type of salad). The proportions b/w the three was different which made this TLS memorable.

2. Samosas Soup: Karl the Fog visited and this soup was perfect for tonight's weather. It was hearty, warm, and spiced w/ turmeric. The soup also had well-fried falafels (which I rarely see in this soup type) and crunchy cabbage for additional texture.

3. Spicy Lotus Roots: We decided on this since I've never seen it on a Burmese menu. The roots were well flavored. Texturally, I was craving something to counterbalance the crunchiness of the roots. But that's just my Western sensibilities talking! I checked and this is how this dish is usually made. Try this dish if you're looking for something different from the usual, especially since this is the first Burmese restau I've been to that serves this dish in this way.

Repeatability Factor: 4 Stars
Totally. Another win for the Burmese community. And tea leaf salads are my current comfort food.

excerpts: The Biryani rice was spicy.
It went with Okra curry.
Highly recommend this place.
The service was a bit slower when compared to other restaurants, hence 4 stars.
The food deserves 5 stars.
biryani rice.author: Alma L.
biryani rice.review: Delicious Burmese food. I had the Burmese version of Falafel for appetizer. They were crispy and tasty. The Biryani rice was spicy. It went with Okra curry. Highly recommend this place. The service was a bit slower when compared to other restaurants, hence 4 stars. The food deserves 5 stars.

excerpts:
Biryani Rice: not awful
Pumpkin Stew:
No curry flavor, just mushed pumpkin.
biryani rice.author: Max L.
biryani rice.review:
Just awful greasy, overcooked, small portioned food.

The naan: was so greasy you could squeeze it and fat would ooze out.  Also, only 1 naan per order (and no sauces).

Biryani Rice: not awful
Pumpkin Stew:  No curry flavor, just mushed pumpkin.
Fish with Tamarind Sauce:  DRY
Beef lemongrass:  SO dry.  Tasted like it was frozen and reheated or cooked for 5 days.
Roasted Ginger Pork: as above.
Masala Noodles:  Good.
Papaya Salad: meh.
Fried Samosa:  AWFUL.  The ratio of crust to filling is way off.  Too much crust.
BK Tea Leaf Salad:  Good.

ALL the dishes were way, way too small for the price.

All of this was delivered quickly though.

excerpts: Biryani Rice - bland & too dry.
biryani rice.author: Kim S.
biryani rice.review:
Was excited to see a new Burmese place in the area.  I'm not 1 of the followers of Burma Superstar bc I don't get the hype & not willing to stand in the cold for an hour or so for a table for food that's good but nothing mind-blowing.

Anyway, stopped in for lunch at the Burmese Kitchen & was super excited to try the fish w/ tamarind sauce.  It was very disappointing, the fish simply tasted like salt, too much salt.  No other flavors or spices, just salt.  The fish was also overcooked - most likely frozen too.

Biryani Rice - bland & too dry.  Didn't taste any saffron spices & there were about a total of 3 raisins.

Pumpkin Stew - was good but not enough to merit a return visit.

The waiter was inexperienced but nice.

excerpts: I also love the yellow pea dish and biryani rice with saffron.
A wonderful option for vegans!
This place is a gem!
biryani rice.author: A S.
biryani rice.review: I'm so glad I followed Burmese Kitchen to their new location. Despite the handful of Burmese restaurants in the area, none rival their exquisite flavor, and level of attentiveness and friendliness. In my personal opinion, they have the best tea leaf salad around. I also love the yellow pea dish and biryani rice with saffron. A wonderful option for vegans! This place is a gem!

excerpts: I loved their tea leaf salad, roti, chicken curry and biryani rice.
I also couldn't stop oogling at the food at other tables
so I can't wait to go back with the hubby and try something new.
biryani rice.author: C L.
biryani rice.review: I didn't think I would encounter another restaurant that could give Burma Superstar a run for its money but Burmese Kitchen is absolutely delicious.  I loved their tea leaf salad, roti, chicken curry and biryani rice. I also couldn't stop oogling at the food at other tables so I can't wait to go back with the hubby and try something new.

excerpts: Add $1 for coconut rice, brown rice, fried rice or biryani rice.
He chose the pork with pickled mango, pumpkin stew, and biryani rice - all for $12.
biryani rice.author: Kaykay K.
biryani rice.review:
We went for lunch. Reasonably priced. Good portions. My husband ordered the "Meatlover" lunch plate: a choice of 1 meat dish, and 1 vegetable dish for $11 including steamed rice. Add $1 for coconut rice, brown rice, fried rice or biryani rice.  He chose the pork with pickled mango, pumpkin stew, and biryani rice - all for $12. (Their lunch menu is posted online).

I ordered the Soup and Salad for $12. Choice of soup: fish chowder, samosa soup, or chicken coconut noodle soup. Choice of salad: tea leaf or ginger salad. The salad was small but sufficient. The chicken coconut noodle soup was good and filled me, and I left satisfied.

The owner was very friendly. He said he was testing out the lunch hours. So far it has been slow at lunch, but busy at dinnertime. If lunch remains slow, he may close for lunch and offer only dinner hours.  So folks, come on down.  Keep this place open at lunchtime, please!

excerpts: Of all of the dishes, my favorite was the fish noodle soup (mohinga), the biryani rice with chicken, and the shrimp and sour leaf.
My friends loved the coconut noodle soup and spicy fish.
To be honest, everything that we ate was delicious.
They could not stop raving about the food and how it was one of the best they've had in the city.
Also, I found out that Burmese Kitchen caters.
I would definitely consider ordering some dishes for my next work potluck event.
Everyone always asks me to bring home-made Burmese cuisine.
I've found a place that I would be happy to vouch for as authentic.
biryani rice.author: Carolyn L.
biryani rice.review: I rarely eat out for Burmese food. My parents are from Burma, so I tend to be disappointed with the Burmese restaurants out there. However, I was utterly surprised at how authentic the food is here. My friends enjoy Burmese cuisine, so we decided to come to Burmese Kitchen based off of the reviews. We ordered family style and everyone, including myself, was beyond satisfied with this decision. Like the reviews mention, the tea leaf salad is one of the best that I've had; it's just like the home-made ones. Of all of the dishes, my favorite was the fish noodle soup (mohinga), the biryani rice with chicken, and the shrimp and sour leaf. My friends loved the coconut noodle soup and spicy fish. To be honest, everything that we ate was delicious. They could not stop raving about the food and how it was one of the best they've had in the city. Also, I found out that Burmese Kitchen caters. I would definitely consider ordering some dishes for my next work potluck event. Everyone always asks me to bring home-made Burmese cuisine. I've found a place that I would be happy to vouch for as authentic.

excerpts: Outside of delivery the meals I ordered was delicious (fish and sour leaf soup, spicy shrimp and Burmese fried rice).
This was my first time eating from here
and I'll definitely be back.
So yummy.
burmese fried rice.author: Kafilat Y.
burmese fried rice.review: Was craving spicy seafood so I ordered from this place through Eat24 and let me tell you, delivery from this place was 5star worthy!! Received my food well ahead of time and it tasted like it just came fresh out of the kitchen to my door since everything was still hot (rare for many places). Outside of delivery the meals I ordered was delicious (fish and sour leaf soup, spicy shrimp and Burmese fried rice). This was my first time eating from here and I'll definitely be back. So yummy.

excerpts: The Burmese Fried Rice was also great.
Don't assume it's anything like Chinese or Japanese fried rice, it was lighter and not as salty.
Highly recommend this place if you're a local or visiting town.
Parking's a bit of a pain, but it's well worth it.
burmese fried rice.author: Jorge G.
burmese fried rice.review:
Never had Burmese Food before so this was a first. Gotta say, it was an awesome tasty treat. 

We had the Burmese falafel, tiny but full of flavor, and it packs a spicy kick. For entrees we ordered the Curry Pork, Beef Masala and Coconut Curry Chicken. Each was different but amazing. Presentation was nice and portions were a great size. There was enough to share throughout the table and still have some leftovers. 

The Burmese Fried Rice was also great. Don't assume it's anything like Chinese or Japanese fried rice, it was lighter and not as salty. Highly recommend this place if you're a local or visiting town. Parking's a bit of a pain, but it's well worth it.

excerpts: Lastly, the Burmese fried rice is just plain rice with nothing in it, no meat or veggies.
burmese fried rice.author: Lucy C.
burmese fried rice.review:
Came here excited to try this place out thinking it would be good given that it's in a close vicinity with a few good Burmese restaurants in the area, but apparently that is not the case. 

The food here is very bland and disappointing ! The potato curry was very watery and bland w/ little curry taste. The fish chowder was bland and comes w/ a lot of nuts. The chicken curry was bland and you'll have to order rice separately cause it doesn't come with any. Lastly, the Burmese fried rice is just plain rice with nothing in it, no meat or veggies. 

Even though the food was bad you would hope for good service to at least off-set the disappointment. Unfortunately the servers here very bad as well, it's so hard to flag any of the two servers in this very tiny restaurant.  When I was dining there, coincidentally friends of the servers were dining there as well. They neglected all the other patrons except their friends especially the guy in the red shirt. He was constantly checking up on his friends to see if they liked the food.  One more thing to mention about him is that he was constantly touching and scratching his pimply face then serving your food......................

excerpts: Old lunch favorites are still on the menu, but went for dinner so kept the carbs down, with: BK Tea Leaf Salad (better than ever!), Shrimp with Sour Leaf (most unusual flavor!), and a few bites of Burmese Fried Rice (most interesting variations).
A couple of Samosas for an appetizer (very fat and savory).
As usual, the owners circulate among the guests, both regaling guests with stories of the restaurant business and Burmese cuisine and music and soliciting feedback on how they are doing.
Still tinkering with decor and acoustics, but on their way!
Great night out on Geary!
The new locations is so much better than their old neighborhood, too!
